column1: 数珠（じゅず、ずず）は穴が貫通した多くの珠に糸の束を通し輪にした法具。
column2: Juzu (数珠) is a Buddhist ritual implement and a kind of ring composed of many beads which are linked by piercing a bundle of threads into a hole made on each bead.

column1: 仏を念ずる時に用いる珠との意味から「念珠（ねんじゅ）」とも呼ばれる。
column2: As it means beads that are used when praying to Buddha, it is also called 'nenju' (praying beadroll).

column1: 梵語で「ハソマ」という。
column2: In Sanskrit, it is called 'hasoma.'

column1: 念仏の際に音を立てて揉んだり、真言・念仏の回数を数えるのに珠をつまぐる目的などで用いる。
column2: While praying to Buddha, it is used for the purpose of rubbing, jingling and/or counting frequency of mantra and Buddhist invocation.

column1: 念仏の回数を問題にしない浄土真宗などの場合は、仏前での崇敬の念の表れとして用いる。
column2: In sects that do not care about the frequency of Buddhist invocation, such as Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism), it is used as a symbol of reverence to Buddha.

column1: 一般に仏事・法要の際、仏・菩薩・物故者の霊位などに礼拝するときに、合掌した手にかける。
column2: Generally, it is hung on hands that are put flat together on the occasions of Buddhist rites, Buddhist memorial services and/or praying to Buddha, Bodhisattva, memorial tablet of the deceased.

column1: 手へのかけ方は宗派によって相違がある。
column2: The way to hang on the hands is different from sect to sect.

column1: 僧侶が手ではなく首にかけて用いる場合もある。
column2: Monks sometimes hang it on the neck instead of hands.

column1: 起源は諸説あるが、古代インドのバラモン教で用いられていた道具を原型とするとされる。
column2: Concerning its origin, there are various views but it is generally believed that the tool used by Brahmanism in Ancient India is the origin.

column1: それが、釈尊により用いられ、後に中国に伝わる。
column2: The above tool was used by Sakyamuni and introduced into China later.

column1: そして仏教伝来とともに飛鳥時代には日本に伝わったされる。
column2: Thereafter, it was introduced into Japan in the Asuka period along with the introduction of Buddhism.

column1: 鎌倉時代に入り、浄土教が流行し称名念仏が盛んになるとともに一般にも普及する。
column2: In the Kamakura period, when Jodo-kyo (pure land teachings) prevailed and Invocation of the Buddha's Name became popular, it spread widely among ordinary people.

column1: 最近では腕輪念珠（腕珠）と呼ばれる、数珠を小型化し中糸をゴムなどにして腕に着けられるようにしたブレスレット的な数珠がある。
column2: At present, there are bracelet-type juzu, called udewa nenju (or wanju, bracelet nenju), which are miniaturized juzu that uses elastic as an inner string so that it can be hung on the arms.

column1: ただし腕輪念珠は、数珠本来の用途に用いるには大きさに無理がある。
column2: However, udewa nenju is not suitable for use for the original purpose of juzu, due to its size.

column1: 法具なので、大切に扱う事。
column2: It must be handled with care since it is a Buddhist ritual implement.

column1: 携帯時には、数珠袋（念珠袋）など専用の袋にいれる。
column2: When carrying it, it must be put into an exclusive bag such as a juzu bag (nenju bag).

column1: 置く時は、鞄や念珠袋の上、ハンカチなどの上に置き、畳の上などには直に置いてはならない。
column2: When placing it, it must be put on a bag, a nenju bag or a handkerchief and must not be directly put on tatami mats, and so on.

column1: 一般的に数珠を持つ場合は、房を下に垂らし左手に持つか、左の手首に下げるとされている。
column2: It is generally believed that juzu should be held by the left hand with a tassel hanging down or should be hung on the left wrist.

column1: 108という数は煩悩の数を表すとされ、数珠の珠はそれぞれの煩悩を司る108の仏を表し、人間のあらゆる煩悩を数珠が受けるとされている。
column2: It is believed that the number of 108 represents the number of earthly desires, each bead of juzu represents 108 Buddha who preside over each earthly desire and juzu suffers all earthly desires of human beings.

column1: 「本連」または「二連」、「二輪」と呼ばれる数珠は、「主珠（おもだま）」（珠の名称を参照）が108珠ある数珠の事。
column2: Juzu that are called 'Honren' (main strand), 'Niren' (two strand) or 'Nirin' (two loops) are ones that are composed of 108 beads of 'Omodama' (main beads) (refer to the name of beads).

column1: 二重にして使用する事が多い。
column2: It is usually used by making it into double rings.

column1: 「片手」または「略式」と呼ばれる数珠は、本来は108珠である主珠の数を簡略化した数珠の事。
column2: Juzu that are called 'one handed' or 'informal' are ones that are composed of a decreased number of Omodama instead of the original number of 108.

column1: 主珠の数は108珠の半数の54珠、三分一の36珠、四分の一の27珠、六分の一の18珠などさまざまである。
column2: The number of Omodama varies widely from 54 beads which is half of 108, 36 beads which is one third of 108, 27 beads which is a quarter of 108 to 18 beads which is one sixth of 108.

column1: 最近では、22珠や25珠など珠の数にあまりこだわらず、仕上がりの輪の大きさ（手の大きさ）に合わせた珠の数で製作されている。
column2: In recent years, juzu that are composed of the proper number of beads suitable for the size of the ring (size of a hand), instead of sticking to a particular number like 22 beads or 25 beads, are produced.

column1: 百万遍念珠と呼ばれる、1080珠ある数珠もある。
column2: There exist juzu that are composed of 1080 beads called Hyakumanben-nenju (literally, one hundred times of nenju).

column1: 珠の数え方には、「○○珠」以外にも「○○玉」や「○○顆」と呼ぶ事がある。
column2: As for a unit in counting the number of beads, '... ball' (玉, tama) or '... grain' (顆, ka) are also used other than '... bead' (珠, tama).

column1: 本文では、「珠」で統一する事にする。
column2: In this column, 'bead' (珠) is to be used consistently.

column1: 本連数珠の場合、一番大きい珠（1珠ないし2珠）の事を「親珠（おやだま）」または「母珠（もしゅ）」と呼び、輪を主に構成する108珠ある珠の事を「主珠（おもだま）」と呼ぶ。
column2: In the case of Honren-juzu, the biggest bead (one bead or 2 beads) is called 'Oyadama' (parent bead) or 'Moshu' (mother bead) and the 108 beads which mainly compose a ring are called 'Omodama.'

column1: 主珠の間に挟まれている、主球より小さい四つの珠の事を「四天珠（してんだま）」と呼ぶ。
column2: 4 beads which are smaller than Omodama and lie between Omodama are called 'Shitendama.'

column1: その他に、房の部分に「弟子球（でしだま）」「記子（きこ）とも」、「浄名（じょうみょう）」、「つゆ」、「副珠」と呼ばれる珠がある。
column2: Other than the above, beads which are called 'Deshidama' (disciple bead), 'Kikotomo,' 'Jomyo' (pure bead), 'Tsuyu' (dewdrop beads) and 'Fukudama' (sub bead) respectively are attached to tassels.

column1: 〔宗旨により用いられる珠に違いがあるため、詳細は後述。〕
column2: 〔Details to be mentioned later since different beads are used depending on religious Doctrines.〕

column1: 片手数珠の場合は、親玉が一珠のみで、親玉と房の間に「ぼさ（菩薩）」と呼ばれる管状の珠が入る。
column2: In the case of one hand juzu, the number of Oyadama is only 1 and a tube-like bead called 'bosa' (Bodhisattva) is inserted between Oyadama and tassel.

column1: 輪を主に構成する多数の珠は、二重数珠と同じく主珠と呼ぶ。
column2: Many beads which mainly compose a ring are called Omodama, likewise in the case of Niju-juzu (double ring juzu).

column1: 主珠より小さい二つの珠の事を「二天珠（にてんだま）」と呼ぶ。
column2: 2 beads which are smaller than Omodama are called 'Nitendama' (literally, beads of two celestial).

column1: 名称には、「珠」の字以外にも「玉」の字も用いられる。
column2: The Chinese character of '玉' (tama) is also used, other than '珠' (tama), for the name of beads.

column1: 本文では、「珠」で統一する事にする。
column2: 珠' is to be used in this column consistently.

column1: 数珠の珠のかたちは、概ね以下の3種類に分けられる。
column2: By and large, the shapes of juzu beads are categorized into the following three kinds.

column1: 丸玉
column2: Marudama (round-bead)

column1: みかん玉　真言・念仏の回数を数えるときに珠を繰りやすい。
column2: Mikandama (elliptic type) - It can be easily handled when counting the frequency of mantra and Buddhist invocation.

column1: 数珠に仕立てたときに肉厚で重厚感があるように見える。
column2: Juzu that is composed of Mikandama looks meaty and sublime.

column1: 数珠の繰りやすさと美観の利点から、（宗派によって差異があるが）僧侶がみかん玉を好む傾向が多い。
column2: Monks tend to prefer Mikandama because of ease of handling and fine appearance (though there is a difference depending on sects).

column1: 平玉　天台宗で使われることがあるが、日蓮宗では使用しない。
column2: Hiradama (flat-bead) - It is sometimes used in the Tendai sect but not in the Nichiren sect.

column1: 古い文献には七宝が良いとされるが、現在では菩提樹など様々な材質の珠が用いられる。
column2: Although cloisonne enamel was recommended in old documents, beads made from various materials, such as lime tree, are used today.

column1: 珠の材料により価格には、大きな差がある。
column2: Prices of juzu widely vary depending on the bead materials.

column1: 本水晶や珊瑚など明るい色合いのものは女性に好まれる。
column2: Women prefer fine-colored juzu that are made from crystal or coral.

column1: 高級な数珠用の素材としては、金線入り水晶（ルチルクォーツ）、本翡翠（ビルマ翡翠）、象牙、ラピスラズリ、天竺菩提樹などが用いられる。
column2: As materials for high grade juzu, crystal with gold line (rutile quartz), feicui (Burma feicui), ivory, lapis lazuli and Bo tree, and so on, are used.

column1: 安価な数珠用には、石や珊瑚に似せたガラスや樹脂製の珠も用いられている。
column2: For cheap juzu, glass beads and/or plastic beads which resemble stone beads or coral beads are used.

column1: 宗旨･宗派により、材質や色、房の形に決まりがある場合があるので注意が必要である。
column2: Attention should be paid to the fact that there could be different rules on materials, color and the shape of tassels depending on doctrines and/or sects.

column1: 主な珠の材質
column2: Ptincipal Materials for Beads

column1: 宝石･貴石　水晶類（本水晶･紫水晶･茶水晶など）、メノウ（オニキス）、本ヒスイ（ビルマ翡翠）、インドヒスイ、珊瑚類、トルマリンなど
column2: Jewelry and precious stones - crystal and the like (crystal, amethyst, smoky quartz, and so on), agate (onyx), feicui (Burma feicui), green aventurine, coral and the like and tourmaline, and so on.

column1: 木　黒檀、紫檀、タガヤサン（鉄刀木）、ツゲ（柘植）、センダン（栴檀）、琥珀など
column2: Wood - ebony, rosewood, Bombay black wood, Japanese box tree, White cedar and amber, and so on.

column1: 木の実　天竺菩提樹、金剛菩提樹、鳳眼菩提樹、龍眼菩提樹、虎眼菩提樹など
column2: Nuts of trees - Bo tree, Rudraksha, hogan linden, ryugan linden and kogan linden, and so on.

column1: 草の実　星月菩提樹、蓮華菩提樹など
column2: Nuts of grass - seigetsu linden and renge linden, and so on.

column1: 香木　白檀、伽羅など
column2: Fragrant wood - sandal wood and dwarf Japanese yew, and so on.

column1: 象牙
column2: Ivory

column1: ガラス
column2: Glass

column1: セルロイド
column2: Celluloid

column1: 正絹と人絹（ポリエステル）がある。
column2: Pure silk and rayon (polyester) is used.

column1: 房の形は頭付房、切房、撚房、四ツ目紐房、菊房（梵天房）、利休房（手毬房）などがあり、職人によって更に細かい種類がある。
column2: As for the shape of tassel, there are several basic patterns such as kashiratsuki tassel (literally, tassel with a head), kiri tassel (cutting tassel), yori tassel (getting together tassel), yotsumehimo tassel (four-eyed string tassel), kiku tassel (or Brahma tassel, chrysanthemum tassel) and Rikyu tassel (or temari ball tassel) but depending on craftsmen, these could be further broken down.

column1: 天竺菩提樹など、虫害に弱い珠は桐箱に入れて保管するか、防虫剤を使用する。
column2: Beads which are vulnerable to harmful insects, such as those made from Bo tree, must be kept in a paulownia box or treated with insecticide.

column1: 珊瑚･真珠など傷つきやすい柔らかい素材の珠は、特に扱いを気をつける。
column2: Particular caution is required in handling fragile and/or soft beads such as those made from coral or pearl.

column1: ラピスラズリ･赤珊瑚･真珠･孔雀石などの珠は、汗に弱いので保管するときは拭取ってから桐箱などに入れる。
column2: As the beads made from lapis lazuli, red coral, pearl or malachite are vulnerable to sweat, these must be kept in a paulownia box after wiping off sweat.

column1: 以下は一般的な在家用の本式数珠の形式である。
column2: The following are general explanations concerning the forms of formal juzu for ordinary lay believers.

column1: 菩提寺などに確認をするか、専門店で相談するべきである。
column2: In selecting juzu, it is vital to confirm with a family temple or consult with a specialty store.

column1: 天台宗用の数珠は、輪の部分に主珠を108珠・親珠を1珠・四天珠を4珠を用いる。
column2: Juzu for the Tendai sect uses 108 beads of Omodama, a bead of Oyadama and 4 beads of Shitendama to compose a ring.

column1: 珠の配置は、親珠1珠→主珠7珠→四天珠1珠→主珠14珠→四天珠1珠→主珠66珠→四天珠1珠→主珠14珠→四天珠1珠→主珠7珠で一周して輪になる。
column2: These beads are arranged in the following order; 1 bead of Oyadama=>7 beads of Omodama=>1 bead of Shitendama=>14 beads of Omodama=>1 bead of Shitendama=>66 beads of Omodama=>1 bead of Shitendama=>14 beads of Omodama=>1 bead of Shitendama=>7 beads of Omodama, and finally they are shaped as a ring.

column1: 親珠の下の房の結び目には、「浄名」と呼ばれる小珠が一珠付く。
column2: 1 small bead called 'Jomyo' is attached at the knot of a tassel made under Oyadama.

column1: 浄名の下には2本の房が付く。
column2: 2 tassels are attached under Jomyo.

column1: 房の形は、いろいろな形が用いられる。（菊房や利休房（蹴鞠房）を用いる事が多い。）
column2: Various shapes are used for tassels (kiku tassel and Rikyu tassel (kemari tassel) are often used).

column1: 房には弟子珠が付く。
column2: Deshidama is attached to each tassel.

column1: 弟子珠の形は、片方の房は丸珠が10珠,もう片方には、平珠が20珠と特徴がある。
column2: Each Deshidama has its characteristics since Deshidama attached to one tassel is composed of 10 beads of Marudama and Deshidama attached to the other tassel is composed of 20 beads of Hiradama.

column1: それぞれの弟子珠の先に「つゆ」と呼ばれる涙型の珠が付く。
column2: A tear-shaped bead called 'Tsuyu' is attached to the tip of each Deshidama.

column1: 天台宗の数珠の特徴は、主珠に平珠（そろばん珠）と呼ばれる扁平の珠が用いられる事である。
column2: The characteristics of the Tendai sect juzu is that flat beads called Hiradama (Sorobandama) are used for Omodama.

column1: 持ち方（中院流の場合）右手の中指に母珠を掛け、左手の人指し指に緒留を掛ける。
column2: The way of holding (in case of Chuin school) - A prayer should hang Moshu on the middle finger of the right hand and hang odome (literally, lacing up the thong) on the forefinger of the left hand.

column1: そのときに、念珠の輪の形がＸ（エックス）の形になるように1回だけねじる。
column2: At that time, a prayer should twist nenju once so that its shape becomes the shape of an X.

column1: 合掌するときに、両方の房を手のひらの中に入れる。
column2: When putting hands flat together in prayer, a prayer should put both tassels into the palms.

column1: そして、左手を上にしてふせて、右手を下にして、仰げて軽く２～３度すり合わせ、右手を手前にして引いて止める。
column2: Then, a prayer should rub them 2 to 3 times slightly with the left hand up and the palm downward, while the right hand is down and its palm upward and should then stop rubbing by pulling the right hand towards himself/herself.

column1: 数珠を一双(いっそう)（一つの輪）にして持つときは、左手首へ掛けるが、その時には、母珠が左手首の上になるように掛ける。
column2: When holding juzu in Isso (a ring), it should be hung on the left wrist and in this case, it should be hung in a manner where Moshu is placed on the wrist of the left hand.

column1: 数珠を一双に持つと、右手が使えるので経本を右手に持って読経をすることが出来る。
column2: If and when a prayer holds juzu in Isso, he/she can make a sutra recitation while holding a sutra text in the right hand since the right hand is free.

column1: 在家（壇信徒）が中院流の持ち方をしても差支えはない。
column2: There is no problem for lay believers (Buddhist supporters) to hold juzu according to Chuin school.

column1: 真言宗用の数珠は、輪の部分に用いられる主珠・四天珠の数は天台宗用と同じだが、親珠は2珠となる。
column2: As for juzu for the Shingon sect, the number of Omodama and Shitendama used for a ring is the same as with juzu for the Tendai sect but the number of Oyadama is 2 beads.

column1: 珠の配置は、親珠1珠→主珠7珠→四天珠1珠→主珠14珠→四天珠1珠→主珠33珠→親珠1珠→主珠33珠→四天珠1珠→主珠14珠→四天珠1珠→主珠7珠で一周して輪になる。
column2: These beads are arranged in the following order; 1 bead of Oyadama=>7 beads of Omodama=>1 bead of Shitendama=>14 beads of Omodama=>1 bead of Shitendama=>33 beads of Omodama=>1 bead of Oyadama=>33 beads of Omodama=>1 bead of Shitendama=>14 beads of Omodama=>1 bead of Shitendama=>7 beads of Omodama, and they finally form the shape of a ring.

column1: 四天玉に近い側の親珠に付く房の結び目にのみ、浄名が一珠付く。
column2: One bead of Jomyo is attached only to the knot of a tassel that is attached to Oyadama situated on the side of Shitendama.

column1: 2つの親珠には、房が2本ずつ付く（計4本）。
column2: 2 tassels are attached to each of 2 Oyadama (4 tassels in total).

column1: 房の形は、いろいろな形が用いられる（菊房や利休房〈蹴鞠房〉を用いる場合が多い)。
column2: Various shapes are used for tassels (kiku tassel and Rikyu tassel (kemari tassel) are often used).

column1: 各房に弟子珠が5珠と「つゆ」が1珠付く（弟子珠・計20珠、つゆ・計4珠。
column2: 5 beads of Deshidama and 1 bead of 'Tsuyu' are attached to each tassel (Deshidama: 20 beads in total, Tsuyu: 4 beads in total).

column1: 女性用の八寸の真言宗用の本連は、八宗用と呼ばれて販売されていて、宗派を問わず用いる事ができるとされている。
column2: Formal juzu of the Shingon sect for females, for which the length is approximately 24 cm, are called juzu for Hasshu sect (eight sects) and are on sale as one which is usable irrespective of sect.

column1: 真言宗の僧侶が用いる数珠の仕様の一例を挙げれば、108珠・貫線を赤色・房を白色にする。
column2: An example in the design of juzu used by monks of the Shingon sect is the one which is composed of 108 beads, red kansen (string to connect beads) and white tassels.

column1: 貫線を赤色にする理由については、さまざまな説があり、定説はない。
column2: As for the reason why kansen is colored red, there are many theses but no established thesis.

column1: 数珠には命（魂）が宿っているものと見なし、貫線を血管、血液に見立てている説などがある。
column2: One thesis asserts that kansen represents a blood vessel and/or blood since a life (a soul) dwells in juzu.

column1: 数珠の仕様は真言宗では事相（真言密教の儀礼・作法）の分野に入る。
column2: In the Shingon sect, designs of juzu belong to the category of phenomenon (courtesy and/or manners of Shingon Esoteric Buddhism).

column1: 僧侶用の数珠（108珠で貫線が赤色・房を白色）を在家（壇信徒）が使っても特に差し支えはない。
column2: There is no problem for lay believers (Buddhist supporters) to use juzu for monks (108 beads, red kansen, white tassels).

column1: 五大力念珠（ごだいりきねんじゅ）醍醐山伝法学院長・服部如実が感得して作らせた念珠。
column2: Godairiki nenju - This is nenju which Nyojitsu HOTTORI, the president of the Daigosan Denpo Gakuin (Denpo (the teachings of Buddhism) Academy on Mt. Daigo), ordered to be produced when his hope was achieved through devotion to Buddhism.

column1: 真言宗108珠の念珠であるが、2種類の材質の珠を用い、房を5色の紐（ひも）にしているが特徴。
column2: Although it is nenju of the Shingon sect, which is composed of 108 beads, its characteristics are the use of beads made from two kinds of materials, as well as tassels composed of strings of five different colors.

column1: 醍醐寺において授与品として販売されている。
column2: It is on sale at Daigo-ji Temple as a prize for awarding.

column1: 浄土宗・時宗用の数珠は、二つの数珠を交差させたような独特の形。
column2: Juzu for Jodo Sect and Ji Sect has a unique shape which looks like one that has mixed the two juzu.

column1: 男性用と女性用とで、主珠などの数に違いがある。
column2: There exist some differences, such as the number of Omodama, between juzu for males and for females.

column1: 二つの輪には、それぞれ親珠があるが、房を直接親玉に付けない。
column2: Oyadama is attached to each of 2 rings but tassels are not directly attached to Oyadama.

column1: 二つの輪のうち、片方にのみ「副珠」と呼ばれる小粒の珠が、主珠と交互に入る。
column2: A small bead called 'Fukudama' is attached to one of two rings alternately with Omodama.

column1: 房は、副珠がある方の輪に金属製の二連の丸環を付け、その環に2房付けられる。
column2: A metal double-ring is attached to the ring to which Fukudama is attached and 2 tassels are attached to the ring.

column1: 房の形は、菊房や利休房（手毬房）が主に用いられる。
column2: As for the shape of tassels, kiku tassel and Rikyu tassel (temari ball tassel) are mainly used.

column1: 房の結び目に浄名が1珠付く。
column2: 1 bead of Jomyo is attached to the knot of the tassel.

column1: 房には弟子珠が付く。
column2: Deshidama is attached to tassels.

column1: 片側は丸珠が6珠、もう片方は、平珠が10珠付く。
column2: 6 beads of Marudama are attached to the one tassel and 10 beads of Hiradama are attached to the other.

column1: 弟子珠の先に「つゆ」が一つずつ付く。
column2: 1 bead of 'Tsuyu' is attached to the tip of each Deshidama.

column1: 日課念珠とも呼ばれる。
column2: It is also called Nikka (daily) nenju.

column1: 浄土宗では、本式念珠を用いるのが好ましいとされる。
column2: In the Jodo Sect, it is believed to be desirable to use formal Nenju.

column1: この他にも、携帯用の36珠の物や百万遍念珠と呼ばれる大念珠も用いられる。
column2: Other than the above, a portable juzu that is composed of 36 beads or dai (big)-nenju called Hyakumanben-nenju are also used.

column1: 男性用は、三万浄土（三万繰）と呼ばれ、片方の輪の主珠が27珠、もう片方は、主珠20珠に副珠21珠が交互に入る。
column2: Juzu for males is called Sanman jodo (literally, thirty thousands of pure land, or Sanman-guri (thirty thousands of telling)) of which one ring is composed of 27 beads of Omodama and the other is composed of 20 beads of Omodama and 21 beads of Fukudama which are allocated alternately.

column1: 念仏を唱える時繰り、副珠以外のすべての珠を使って繰ると27×20×6×10＝32,400遍唱えられる。
column2: It is used for telling the juzu while reciting Buddhist invocation, and it is possible to recite 32,400 times (27 times 20 times 6 times10 makes 32,400) by telling the juzu with all beads other than Fukudama.

column1: そこからこの名がつく。
column2: The above is the origin of the name.

column1: 女性用は八寸浄土（六万繰）と呼ばれ、片方の輪が主珠40珠、もう片方は、主珠27珠･副珠28珠からできている。
column2: Juzu for females is called Hassun jodo (literally, 24 cm of pure land, or Rokuman-guri (sixty thousands of telling)) of which one ring is composed of 40 beads of Omodama and the other is composed of 27 beads of Omodama and 28 beads of Fukudama.

column1: 弟子珠の数は三万浄土と同じ。
column2: The number of Deshidama is the same as that of Sanman jodo.

column1: つまり副珠以外のすべての珠を使って繰ると、男性用の倍40×27×6×10＝64,800遍唱えられる。
column2: Therefore, it is possible to recite 64,800 times (40 times 27 times 6 times 10 makes 64,800), twice the number for males, by telling the juzu with all beads other than Fukudama.

column1: 浄土真宗では、念珠を繰りながら念仏を唱える事が無い為、珠の数は関係無い。
column2: In Jodo Shinshu Sect, there is no practice to telling the nenju while reciting Buddhist invocation and therefore, no rule exists concerning the number of beads.

column1: 珠の材質に関しても制限はない。
column2: No rule exists concerning the materials of beads either.

column1: 形状には拘らないが、合掌礼拝の際に用いる法具として大切にする。
column2: The form of the nenju does not matter, but it is highly esteemed as a ritual implement to be used while putting hands flat together in prayer.

column1: 男性門徒の場合：片手念珠の紐房を用いる事が好ましいとされる。
column2: In the case of male believers : It is believed to be desirable to use a himo (code) tassel of one-handed nenju.

column1: 主珠の数に決まりは無く、大きさで決められ18～27珠の念珠が用いられる。
column2: As there is no rule on the number of Omodama, the number is decided depending on the size of beads, and the nenju that is composed of 18 to 27 beads are generally used.

column1: 浄土真宗本願寺派（お西）の女性門徒：女性も、本連の念珠を用いない事を勧められる場合が多い。
column2: Female believers of the Hongan-ji School of the Jodo Shinshu Sect (O-nishi (Nishi Hongan-ji Temple)): Female believers are often recommended not to use Honren Nenju.

column1: なお玉の数は、女性用片手念珠の場合36珠などだが、やはり数に決まりは無い。
column2: Although a one-handed nenju for females is usually composed of 36 beads, there is no particular rule on the number of beads.

column1: 女性用片手念珠は、切房・頭無しの撚房（新松房）・頭付撚房が主に用いられる。
column2: For one-hand nenju for females, kiri tassel, kashiranashi yori tassel (twisted tassel, or shinmatsu tassel (new pine tassel) and kashiratsuki yori tassel (twisted tassels with head) are mainly used.

column1: 真宗大谷派（お東）の女性門徒：お西同様に、片手念珠で構わない。
column2: Female believers of the Otani School of the Jodo Shinshu Sect (O-higashi (Higashi Hongan-ji Temple): Likewise the case of O-nishi, one-hand nenju can be used.

column1: 房は、切房や新松房が主に用いられる。
column2: Kiri tassel and shinmatsu tassel are mainly used for tassels.

column1: しかし女性が、一般に八寸門徒と呼ばれる本連念珠を用いても問題は無い。
column2: Notwithstanding the above, there is no problem for females to use Honren nenju which is generally called hassun monto (literally, 24 cm for followers).

column1: 八寸門徒の形は、主珠・親珠の数、四天珠の配置は真言宗の数珠と同じ。
column2: In hassun monto, number of Omodama and Oyadama, allocation of Shitendama are the same as the juzu of Shingon Sect.

column1: 房に特徴があり、数取りが出来ない様に蓮如上人が考案した「蓮如結び」と呼ばれる独特な結び方がしてある。
column2: Tassels have a distinctive feature because they are knotted in a unique manner, called 'rennyo-musubi' devised by Rennyo Shonin, so that they cannot be used for counting.

column1: 四天珠がある側の親珠に付く房は、浄名が一つ、弟子珠は親珠から5珠目ずつの所で結ばれその先に5珠ずつ付く。
column2: One bead of Jomyo is attached to the tassel attached to Oyadama of the Shitendama side and 5 beads of Deshidama are attached to the tip of each tassel knotted at the position of the 5th bead from Oyadama.

column1: 弟子珠の先には、それぞれ「つゆ」が一つ付く。
column2: One bead of 'Tsuyu' is attached to the tip of each Deshidama.

column1: つまり弟子珠をX型に上に詰めて動かないようしてある。
column2: In other words, Deshidama is packed upwards in an X shape so that they are fixed.

column1: 反対側の親玉に付く房は、結び目（蓮如結び）を付ける。
column2: A knot (rennyo-musubi) is made on the tassel attached to Oyadama on the opposite side.

column1: その先には、弟子珠・「つゆ」を入れずに房を付ける。
column2: The tassel is attached without attaching Deshidama and 'Tsuyu.'

column1: 房の形は、頭付房をつける場合が多い。
column2: As for the shape of tassels, kashiratsuki tassel is mainly used.

column1: 本連念珠を持つ時の持ち方
column2: The Way of Holding Honren Nenju

column1: 大谷派の場合は、二重にして2つの親珠を親指の所で挟み、4つの房を左側に垂らす。
column2: In the case of the Otani School, it should be used in the form of a double ring with 2 beads of Oyadama fixed at a thumb and 4 tassels hung down on the left side.

column1: その時、弟子珠がある方の親珠を指先側に、蓮如結びがある方の親玉を手前側にして手に掛ける。
column2: It should be hung on a hand with Oyadama of the Deshidama side situated at the fingertip side and Oyadama of the rennyo-musubi side situated at the body side.

column1: 本願寺派の場合は、二重にして房を下に垂らす。
column2: In the case of Hongan-ji School, it should be used in the form of a double ring and the tassels should be hung down.

column1: なお男性用サイズの尺二寸以上の大型で、長房の本連念珠も見かけるが、本来は僧侶用の装束念珠である。
column2: Although large-sized Honren nenju for males, with a length of over 38 cm and which have a nagafusa (long tassel), are seen, it is basically shozoku nenju (nenju for costume) for monks.

column1: 臨済宗用の数珠は、主珠・親珠・四天珠の個数と配置は、天台宗用の数珠と同じ。
column2: As for juzu of the Rinzai Sect, the number and allocation of Omodama, Oyadama and Shitendama are the same as those of the Tendai Sect.

column1: ただし、主珠の形は丸珠。
column2: However, the shape of Omodama is marudama.

column1: 親珠の下に「ぼさ」が付く。
column2: Bosa' (literally, Bosatsu (Bodhisattava)) is attached to Oyadama.

column1: 浄名・弟子珠は無い。
column2: Jomyo and Deshidama are not attached.

column1: 房の形は紐房が多いが、切房なども用いられる。
column2: While himo tassel is often used, kiri tassel is also used.

column1: 曹洞宗用の数珠は、主珠・親珠・四天珠の個数と配置は、真言宗の数珠と同じ。
column2: As for juzu of the Soto Sect, the number and allocation of Omodama, Oyadama and Shitendama are the same as those of the Shingon Sect.

column1: 房は、四天珠のある側の親玉にのみ付く。
column2: A tassel is attached only to Oyadama on the Shitendama side.

column1: 房の形は、臨済宗に准ずる。
column2: The shape of the tassel is almost the same as that of the Rinzai Sect.

column1: 房の付く親珠の方が、付かない親玉より若干大きい。
column2: Oyadama to which a tassel is attached is slightly bigger than one to which a tassel is not attached.

column1: 「ぼさ」も房のある親珠のみ付く。
column2: Bosa' also is attached to Oyadama to which a tassel is attached.

column1: 臨済宗の数珠に似ているが、曹洞宗の数珠は百八環金と呼ばれる金属製の環が通してある事が特徴。
column2: Although it looks like juzu for Rinzai Sect, juzu for Soto Sect have a distinctive feature of using a metal ring called hyakuhachi-kankin (literally, one hundred and eight golden ring).

column1: 高級な数珠には、銀製の環を用いることもある。
column2: A silver ring is sometimes used for high-grade juzu.

column1: 日蓮宗用
column2: Juzu for Nichiren Sect

column1: 日蓮宗用の数珠は、主珠・親珠・四天珠の個数と配置は、真言宗の数珠と同じ。
column2: As for juzu for the Nichiren Sect, the number and allocation of Omodama, Oyadama and Shitendama are the same as those of the Shingon Sect.

column1: 房に特徴があり、親珠から出る房の形が対称では無い。
column2: Tassels have a distinctive feature since tassels attached to Oyadama are not symmetrical.

column1: 四天珠がある側（右手の中指に掛ける側）の親珠〔浄名珠とも〕に付く房は2本で、浄名が一つ、弟子珠は親珠から5珠目ずつの所で結ばれその先に5珠ずつ付く。
column2: 2 tassels with a bead of Jomyo are attached to Oyadama (also called Jomyodama) situated on the Shitendama side (the side to be hung on the middle finger of the right hand) and knots are made on each tassel at the position of the 5th beads from Oyadama and 5 beads of Deshidama are attached on their tips.

column1: それぞれの弟子珠先にはに「つゆ」が付く。
column2: Tsuyu' is attached to the tip of each Deshidama.

column1: 四天珠が無い側（左手の中指に掛ける側）の親珠〔緒留とも〕に付く房は3本で、親珠の下に結び目がある。
column2: 3 tassels are attached to Oyadama (also called odome) situated on the side where Shitendama doesn't exist (the side to be hung on the middle finger of the left hand) and a knot is situated under Oyadama.

column1: 3本の内の2本は、弟子珠がそれぞれ5珠ずつ付き、「つゆ」もそれぞれに付く。
column2: Out of 3 tassels, 5 beads of Deshidama as well as 'Tsuyu' are attached to 2 tassels for each.

column1: 残りの一本は、『数取』と呼ばれ他の2本より長さが短く、弟子珠が10珠付く。
column2: The remaining 1 tassel called "kazutori" (counting) is shorter than the other 2 tassels and 10 beads of Deshidama are attached to it.

column1: 『数取』には「つゆ」が付かない。
column2: Tsuyu' is not attached to "kazutori."

column1: 日蓮宗の場合、在家信者も必ず本式念珠を用いる事になっている（略式念珠を用いない)。
column2: In the Nichiren Sect, even lay believers must use formal nenju (informal nenju is not be used).

column1: ●上記は、主に在家用の数珠についてである。
column2: - The above explanations are basically made regarding juzu for lay believers.

column1: 僧侶用は、装束などにより細かい規定があり、この限りではない。
column2: As for juzu for monks, the above may not be applicable since there are more detailed rules concerning costumes, and so on.

column1: ●宗旨・宗派によっても、数珠の仕様に細かな点で違いがある。
column2: - There are subtle differences in the designs of juzu depending on sects/schools.

column1: ●地方によっては、珠や房の色に決まりがある。
column2: - In some regions, there are restrictions on the color of beads and/or tassels.

column1: （葬儀には、主珠（白又は透明）･房（白色）、法要には、主珠（色のある物）･房（色房）など）
column2: (For funeral, Omodama (white or transparent), tassels (white); for Buddhist memorial service, Omodama (colored ones), tassels (colored tassels), and so on.)

column1: 念珠専門店などでは、オーダーメイドにて製作してくれる店もある。
column2: Custom-made juzu are available at some shops specialized in nenju.

column1: 本水晶と紫水晶を用いてのグラデーションの数珠を作るなど、市販品にはない凝った物も入手できる。
column2: Juzu of gradation, such as the ones made from crystal or amethyst, which is not available on the market, are also available.

column1: 数珠は、中糸が切れる前に修理に出す。
column2: Juzu should be repaired before the inner string is broken.

column1: 房が痛んだ場合も、通常は交換できる。
column2: When tassels are damaged, they can be replaced under normal conditions.

column1: 高価な数珠はもちろんの事、形見の数珠などは中糸を交換する事により永く使用することができる。
column2: By replacing the inner string, juzu, especially the expensive one or the one of a keepsake, can be used for a long time.

column1: 天竺菩提樹や星月菩提樹（無漂白な物）などは、時間とともに飴色に変わっていき味わいが増すとされる。
column2: It is said that the color of juzu made from Bo tree or seigetsu linden (unbleached) will gradually change the color in amber over time and have depth to its color.

column1: 修理は、念珠専門店、数珠修理に対応している仏壇店などで引受けてもらえる。
column2: Repairs are undertaken by shops specializing in nenju or Buddhist altar stores which deal with the repair of juzu.

column1: 厄が切れるとの考えから、交換しない場合もある。
column2: There exist some people who do not replace an inner string based on the thought that the cutting of string leads to the cutting of mishap.

column1: また、自然に切れた場合も、前記の理由により縁起が悪い訳では無いとされる。
column2: For the same reason, it is believed that the natural cutting of string doesn't necessarily mean bad luck.

column1: 『南総里見八犬伝』に登場する8つの霊玉は、伏姫の持っていた水晶の数珠のうち8つの大玉が飛び散った物で、残りの100個の小玉は連ねられ、ゝ大法師が所持する数珠となっている。
column2: 8 reidama (spirit beads) which appear in "Nanso Satomi hakken den" (The story of eight dog samurai and a princess of Satomi family in Nanso region) are 8 big beads that flown from crystal-made juzu that was possessed by Princess Fusehime and the remaining 100 small beads are connected and becomes juzu that Chudai hoshi possesses.

column1: 他宗教でも、例えばキリスト教ではロザリオのように、同様の物が使用されることがある。
column2: Similar things are used in other religions, such as Rosario in Christianity.

column1: 字の前後を入れ替えて「珠数」と書く場合もある。
column2: Sometimes juzu is written in Chinese characters as '珠数' instead of '数珠' by changing the order of each Chinese character.

column1: 「じゅず」という読みを「数珠」と書くのは、この熟語を作った中国の文法では動詞を先にする事になっているからである。
column2: According to the grammar of the Chinese language, which is the origin of a pair of these Chinese characters, a verb should be placed before a noun and this is the reason why 'juzu' is written as '数珠.'

column1: 「珠を数える」を中国語では「数珠」と書く。
column2: In Chinese, 'to count the number of beads' is written as '数珠.'

column1: 印相（いんそう、いんぞう）は、ヒンドゥー教および仏教の用語で、両手で示すジェスチャーによって、ある意味を象徴的に表現するものである。
column2: Inso is a Buddhist and Hinduism term which refers to the gesture of the hands having a certain symbolic meaning.

column1: サンスクリット語ムドラー(mudraa)の漢訳であり、本来は「封印」「印章」などを意味する。
column2: It is a translation of a Sanskrit term mudraa, which originally means 'seal,' 'stamp,' and so forth.

column1: 日本語では印契(いんげい)、あるいは単に印(いん)とも言い、おもに仏像が両手で示す象徴的なジェスチャーのことを指す。
column2: In Japanese terms, it has the same meaning as the term ingei (印契) or its simplified form in (印), referring mainly to the symbolic gesture of a Buddhist statue.

column1: 寺院その他で見かける仏像には、鎌倉大仏のように両手を膝の上で組み合わせるもの、東大寺盧舎那仏像のように右手を挙げ、左手を下げるものなど、両手の示すポーズ、すなわち印相には決まったパターンがある。
column2: There are several fixed patterns of inso in a Buddhist statue existing in a Buddhist temple or the like, which include the followings: one formed by hands clasped in the lap, like that of Kamakura Daibutsu (the Great Buddha of Kamakura); one formed by the right hand being raised and the left hand resting on the lap, like that of the huge image of Rushana Buddha of Todai-ji Temple.

column1: それぞれの印相には諸仏の悟りの内容、性格、働きなどを表わす教義的な意味があり、仏像がどの印相を結んでいるかによって、その仏像が何であるか、ある程度推測がつく。
column2: Each form of inso has a doctrinal meaning that represents the details, nature and function of the spiritual awakening experienced by a Buddha; accordingly, ascertaining what form of inso is assumed by a Buddhist image allows, to some extent, the guessing of what Buddha is represented by the image.

column1: 密教の曼荼羅などには、さまざまな印相を結ぶ仏、菩薩像が表現されているが、ここでは日本の寺院などで見かける代表的なもの数種類について略説する。
column2: Buddhas and Bosatsu (Bodhisattva) assuming various forms of inso are depicted in mandala (place of practicing Buddhism to attain spiritual enlightenment) of Esoteric Buddhism; however, this column briefly explains about several typical types of inso that are seen in Buddhist temples, and so on.

column1: おもな印相
column2: Major Types of Inso

column1: 施無畏印（せむいいん）
column2: Semui-in (mudra for bestowing fearlessness)

column1: 手を上げて手のひらを前に向けた印相。
column2: It is the inso formed by a hand raised with the palm facing outward.

column1: 漢字の示す意味通り「恐れなくてよい」と相手を励ますサインである。
column2: As the meaning of the kanji, this is a sign indicating to a viewer that he or she 'does not need to fear' to encourage him or her.

column1: 不空成就如来が結ぶ。
column2: It is assumed by Fukujoju Nyorai (Amoghasiddhi, one of the Five Wisdom Buddhas).

column1: 与願印（よがんいん）
column2: Yogan-in (wish-granting mudra)

column1: 手を下げて手のひらを前に向けた印相。
column2: It is the inso formed by a hand pointing downward with the palm facing outward.

column1: 座像の場合などでは手のひらを上に向ける場合もあるが、その場合も指先側を下げるように傾けて相手に手のひらが見えるようにする。
column2: In the case of a seated statue, the palm may face upward; in this case, however, the finger side of the palm is tilted downward so that a viewer can see the palm.

column1: 相手に何かを与えるしぐさを模したもので宝生如来などが結ぶ。
column2: This form imitates a gesture made when a person gives something to others and is assumed by Hosho Nyorai Hosho Nyorai (Ratnasambhava, one of the Five Wisdom Buddhas), and so on.

column1: 施無畏与願印（せむいよがんいん）
column2: Semui-Yogan-in

column1: 右手を施無畏印にし、左手を与願印にした印。
column2: It is the inso formed by a combination of the right hand taking the form of Semui-in and the left hand taking the form of Yogan-in.

column1: 坐像の場合は左手のひらを上に向け、膝上に乗せる。
column2: In the case of a seated statue, the palm of the left hand points upward while resting on the lap.

column1: これは信者の願いをかなえようというサインである。
column2: This is a sign indicating that believers' wishes will be granted.

column1: 施無畏与願印は、如来像の示す印相として一般的なものの1つで、釈迦如来にこの印相を示すものが多い。
column2: Semui-Yogan-in is one of the typical forms of inso shown by an statue of nyorai (Tathagata), and many statues of Shakyamuni Nyorai show inso of this form.

column1: 与願印を示す左手の上に薬壷が載っていれば薬師如来である。
column2: An statue of nyorai with the palm of the left hand taking the form of Yogan-in and bearing a medicine pot is a statue of Yakushi Nyorai (the healing Buddha).

column1: ただし、薬師如来像には、本来あった薬壷の失われたものや、もともと薬壷を持たない像もある。
column2: However, some of the statues of Yakushi Nyorai lack a medicine pot because of loss or originally there was no medicine pot.

column1: また、阿弥陀如来像のなかにも施無畏与願印を表わすものがあり、この印相のみで何仏かを判別することは不可能な場合が多い。
column2: In addition, some of the statues of Amida Nyorai (Amitabha Tathagata) represent Semui-Yogan-in; therefore, it is impossible in many cases to identify what Buddha is represented by this inso only.

column1: 図1は香港・ランタオ島の天壇大仏で、施無畏与願印を結ぶ。
column2: Figure 1 shows Tian Tan Buddha assuming Semui-Yogan-in, which is located in Lantau Island, Hong Kong.

column1: 転法輪印（てんぽうりんいん）
column2: Tenborin-in (teaching mudra)

column1: 釈迦如来の印相の1つで、両手を胸の高さまで上げ、親指と他の指の先を合わせて輪を作る。
column2: It is one of the forms of inso that may be assumed by Shakyamuni Nyorai, which is formed by both hands turned upward in front of the chest with the tips of the thumbs of both hands put together and the tips of the same fingers of both hands put together to form a circle.

column1: 手振りで相手に何かを説明しているしぐさを模したもので「説法印」とも言う。
column2: This imitates a gesture made when a person explains something to another, and therefore is called Seppo-in (the term "seppo" means preaching).

column1: 「転法輪」（法輪を転ずる）とは、「真理を説く」ことの比喩である。
column2: The term 'tenborin' refers literally to spinning the dharma wheel and metaphorically to 'expounding the truth.'

column1: 親指とどの指を合わせるか、手のひらを前に向けるか自分に向けるか上に向けるかなどによって様々なバリエーションがある。
column2: Because of the existence of many patterns for which fingers and a thumb are put together, in what direction a palm is oriented (outward, inward, upward or otherwise), and so forth, there are many variations of this inso.

column1: 例えば胎蔵界曼荼羅釈迦院の釈迦如来の場合、両手の指先を上に向け、右手は前に、左手は自分側に向ける。
column2: In the case of Shakyamuni Nyorai depicted in Shakyamuni-in (one of the 12 sections ("in" in Japanese) constituting Taizokai mandala) in Taizokai ((Womb Realm) mandala, for example, the right and left hands face outward and inward, respectively, with the finger tips of both hands pointing upward.

column1: この場合、右手は聴衆への説法を意味し左手は自分への説法を意味する。
column2: In this case, the right hand represents preaching to the audience while the left hand represents preaching to oneself.

column1: 定印（じょういん）
column2: Jo-in (samadhi mudra, gesture of meditation)

column1: 坐像で、両手の手のひらを上にして腹前（膝上）で上下に重ね合わせた形である。
column2: It is used with a seated statue formed by the palms of both hands facing upward and put on top of one another in front of the abdomen (in the lap).

column1: これは仏が思惟（瞑想）に入っていることを指す印相である。
column2: This indicates that the Buddha is absorbed in contemplation (meditation).

column1: 釈迦如来、大日如来（胎蔵界）の定印は左手の上に右手を重ね、両手の親指の先を合わせて他の指は伸ばす。
column2: It is assumed by Shakyamuni Nyorai or Dainichi Nyorai (the Great Sun Buddha) (in Taizokai) formed by the right hand put on top of the left hand with the tips of both thumbs put together and other fingers stretched.

column1: これを法界定印(ほっかいじょういん)といい、座禅の時結ぶ事でなじみ深い印相である。
column2: This gesture is specifically called Hokkaijo-in, which is famous for being taken on the occasion of Zen meditation.

column1: 阿弥陀如来の定印は密教では法界定印とされるが、浄土教などでの場合は同じように両手を重ねて親指と人差し指（または中指、薬指）で輪をつくるものもある。
column2: According to Esoteric Buddhism, Jo-in assumed by Amida Nyorai is supposed to be Hokkaijo-in; however, a variation formed by both hands placed together in the same manner and the thumbs and the forefingers (or otherwise, the middle or annular fingers) forming a circle may be assumed by Amida Nyorai of the Jodo Sect, and so on.

column1: 阿弥陀如来の印相には沢山のバリエーションがあるので、後に詳述する。
column2: There are many variations of inso assumed by Amida Nyorai, which will be explained in full detail.

column1: 触地印（そくちいん）
column2: Sokuchi-in (Earth-Touching Mudra)

column1: 降魔印ともいう。
column2: It is also referred to as Goma-in (literally, mudra of conquering the devil).

column1: 座像で、手のひらを下に伏せて指先で地面に触れる。
column2: It is used with a seated statue and formed by a palm facing downward with finger tips touching the earth.

column1: 伝説によると、釈迦は修行中に悪魔の妨害を受けた。
column2: Shakyamuni is said, according to legend, to have sustained interference with his ascetic practices by a devil.

column1: その時釈迦は指先で地面に触れて大地の神を出現させ、それによって悪魔を退けたという。
column2: It is said that Shakyamuni touched the earth with finger tips at that time to cause a god of the earth to appear, thereby defeating the devil.

column1: このため触地印は、誘惑や障害に負けずに真理を求める強い心を象徴する。
column2: Therefore, Sokuchi-in symbolizes a strong mind pursuing the truth without being overcome by temptations or obstacles.

column1: 釈迦如来のほか、阿しゅく如来や天鼓雷音如来が結ぶ。
column2: It is assumed by Ashuku Nyorai (Immovable Buddha) or Tenkuraion Nyorai (or Divyadundubhimeganirghosa, literally, Buddha of Thunderous Sound of the Heavenly Drum) besides Shakyamuni Nyorai.

column1: 智拳印（ちけんいん）
column2: Chiken-in (the knowledge-fist mudra)

column1: 左手は人差し指を伸ばし、中指、薬指、小指は親指を握る。
column2: It is formed by the left hand with the forefinger stretched and the thumb clenched by the middle, annular and little fingers.

column1: 右手は左手人指し指を握り、右親指の先と左人指し指の先を合わせる。
column2: And the right hand clenching the forefinger of the left hand with the tip of the thumb of the right hand and the tip of the forefinger of the left hand put together.

column1: 大日如来(金剛界)、一字金輪仏頂、多宝如来が結ぶ。
column2: It is assumed by Dainichi Nyorai (in the diamond-world mandala), Ichiji Kinrin Buccho (the principal Buddha of the "Court of the Perfected") or Taho Nyorai (Prabhuta-ratnam in Sanskrit).

column1: 降三世印（こうざんぜいん）
column2: Kozanze-in (Mudra of Subjection)

column1: 小指を絡めて胸の前で交差させる印。
column2: It is formed by the little fingers firmly crossed in front of the chest.

column1: 阿弥陀如来の印相
column2: Types of Inso Assumed by Amida Nyorai

column1: 阿弥陀如来の印相には数種類あるが、いずれの場合も親指と人差し指（または中指、薬指）で輪をつくるのが原則である。
column2: There are several types of inso assumed by Amida Nyorai, any of which is formed in principle by the thumbs and the forefingers (or otherwise, the middle or annular fingers) forming a circle.

column1: 定印(じょういん)
column2: Jo-in

column1: 前述のとおり。
column2: It is formed as mentioned above.

column1: 阿弥陀如来の場合は、両手を胸の高さまで上げ親指と人差し指（または中指、薬指）で輪をつくるものもある。
column2: In the case of Amida Nyorai, there may be a statue assuming inso formed by both hands pointing upward in front of the chest with the thumbs and the forefingers (or otherwise, the second or third fingers) forming a circle.

column1: 日本での作例としては、宇治市の平等院鳳凰堂本尊像、図2の鎌倉市・高徳院本尊像（鎌倉大仏）などがある。
column2: Examples of statues assuming Jo-in existing in Japan include the principal statue in Hoo-do Hall (the Phoenix Pavilion) of Byodoin Temple in Uji City and the principal statue in Kotokuin Temple in Kamakura City (Kamakura Great Buddha) shown in Figure 2.

column1: 説法印(せっぽういん)
column2: Seppo-in (the exposition of the Dharma mudra)

column1: 転法輪印のこと。
column2: It refers to Tenborin-in.

column1: 両手を胸の高さまで上げ、親指と人差し指（または中指、薬指）で輪をつくる。
column2: It is formed by both hands pointing upward in front of the chest with the thumbs and the forefingers (or otherwise, the middle or annular fingers) forming a circle.

column1: 日本での作例としては、京都・広隆寺講堂本尊像などがあるが、比較的珍しい印相である。
column2: Examples of statues assuming Tenborin-in existing in Japan include the principal statue enshrined in the hall of Koryu-ji Temple in Kyoto; however, this inso is relatively rare.

column1: 当麻曼荼羅の中尊像もこの印相である。
column2: The central Buddhist image in Taima mandala also assumes this inso.

column1: 来迎印(らいごういん)
column2: Raigo-in (Reasoning Mudra)

column1: 施無畏与願印に似て、右手を上げて左手を下げて共に手のひらを前に向け、それぞれの手の親指と人差し指（または中指、薬指）で輪をつくる。
column2: Similar to Semui-Yogan-in, it is formed by the right hand turned upward and the left hand turned downward with both palms facing outward and the thumb and forefinger (or otherwise, the middle or annular finger) of each hand forming a circle.

column1: 信者の臨終に際して、阿弥陀如来が西方極楽浄土から迎えに来る時の印相である。
column2: This inso is assumed by Amida Nyorai coming to fetch a believer on his or her deathbed.

column1: 日本での作例としては、京都・三千院の阿弥陀三尊の中尊像などがある。
column2: Examples of statues assuming Raigo-in existing in Japan include the central Buddhist statue among the statues of the three Amida divinities in Sanzenin Temple in Kyoto.

column1: 浄土宗、浄土真宗の本尊像は基本的にこの印相である。
column2: The principal statue enshrined in a temple of the Jodo sect or the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) assumes in principle this inso.

column1: 図3は茨城県の牛久大仏で、来迎印を結んでいる。
column2: Figure 3 shows Ushiku Daibutsu (the Great Buddha of Ushiku) in Ibaraki Prefecture, which assumes Raigo-in.

column1: 東京都世田谷区の浄真寺（通称九品仏）には9体の阿弥陀如来像が安置され、それぞれが異なった9通りの印相を示している。
column2: In Joshin-ji Temple (commonly known as Kuhonbutsu) in Setagaya-ku Ward, Tokyo, nine statues of Amida Nyorai, which assume nine different types of inso respectively, are enshrined.

column1: これは「観無量寿経」に説く九品（くぼんおうじょう）の思想に基づくものである。
column2: This is based on the idea of kubon-ojo (the nine classes of people reborn in the Land of Happiness according to the nine levels of religiousness), as preached in 'Kanmuryoju-kyo sutra' (The Sutra of Visualization of the Buddha of Measureless Life, meaning Amida).

column1: 極楽往生のしかたには、信仰の篤い者から極悪人まで9通りの段階があるとされ、「上品上生」（じょうぼんじょうしょう）から始まって「上品中生」「上品下生」「中品上生」「中品中生」「中品下生」「下品上生」「下品中生」「下品下生」に至る。
column2: It is assumed that there are nine grades of gokuraku ojo (dying peacefully to be born in the Pure Land) from very religious people to accomplished villains as listed below: starting with 'jobon josho' (Upper grade: upper birth), 'jobon chusho' (Upper grade: middle birth), 'jobon gesho' (Upper grade: lower birth), 'chubon josho' (Middle grade: upper birth), 'chubon chusho' (Middle grade: middle birth), 'chubon gesho' (Middle grade: lower birth), 'gebon josho' (Lower grade: upper birth), 'gebon chusho' (Lower grade: middle birth) and 'gebon gesho' (Lower grade: lower birth).

column1: 浄真寺の九品仏の場合、阿弥陀如来の印相のうち、定印を「上生印」、説法印を「中生印」、来迎印を「下生印」とし、親指と人差し指（中指、薬指）を接するものをそれぞれ「上品」「中品」「下品」に充てる。
column2: In the case of the nine statues of Amida Nyorai enshrined in Joshin-ji Temple, the three types of inso assumed by Amida Nyorai, that is, Jo-in, Seppo-in and Raigo-in are assigned as 'Josho-in' (inso representing josho (upper birth)), 'Chusho-in' (inso representing chusho (middle birth)) and 'Gesho-in' (inso representing gesho (lower birth)), respectively, and combinations of the thumbs and the forefingers put together, those of the thumbs and the middle fingers put together and those of the thumbs and the annular fingers put together are assigned to 'jobon' (upper grade), 'chubon' (middle grade) and 'gebon' (lower grade), respectively.

column1: なお、九品往生を9通りの印相で表わす教義的根拠は明確でなく、日本において近世になってから考え出されたもののようである。
column2: It should be noted, however, that there are no explicit doctrinal grounds for the representation of kuhon ojo (nine grades of birth in the Pure Land) by nine types of inso and they seem to have been contrived in early-modern times in Japan.

column1: 印鑑における印相
column2: Inso Referring to the Design of a Seal

column1: 印鑑の印影デザインを印相と呼び、占いの対象とする場合がある。
column2: The design of a seal imprint is called inso, and fortune may be told from such a design.

column1: 左右対称の文字配列は不吉とされ、また長く使っていると欠損箇所が生じるので、その出方で占う。
column2: A symmetric arrangement of characters is assumed to be inauspicious; moreover, fortune is told from the appearance of the fracture of a seal arising from long-term use.

column1: 阿野全成（あのぜんじょう／ぜんせい、仁平3年（1153年）-建仁3年6月23日(旧暦)（1203年8月1日））は平安時代末期、鎌倉時代初期の僧で、源義朝の七男。
column2: Zenjo ANO (1153 - August 8, 1203) was a priest from late Heian period to early Kamakura period and the seventh son of MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo.

column1: 阿野法橋全成とも。
column2: He was also known as Hokkyo (the third highest rank for Buddhist priests) Zenjo (or Zensei) ANO.

column1: 母は常盤御前。
column2: His mother was Tokiwa Gozen.

column1: 幼名・今若丸。
column2: His childhood name was Imawakamaru.

column1: 義円・源義経の同母兄、源頼朝の異母弟。
column2: Gien and MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune were his younger brothers by the same mother, and MINAMOTO no Yoritomo was his elder brother by a different mother.

column1: 妻は北条時政の娘阿波局(北条時政の娘)。
column2: His wife was Awa no Tsubone (Tokimasa HOJO's daughter).

column1: 子は播磨公頼全（はりまのきみよりまさ）、阿野時元、藤原公佐室、他。
column2: His children included: Harimanokimi (the lord of Harima Province) Yorimasa, and Tokimoto ANO, a wife of FUJIWARA no Kimisuke (藤原公佐室).

column1: 今若が7歳の平治元年（1159年）、平治の乱で父義朝が敗死したため幼くして醍醐寺にて出家させられ、隆超（または隆起）と名乗り、ほどなく全成と改名。
column2: Since Imawaka's father Yoshitomo was defeated and died in the Heiji War when he was at an early age of 7 in 1159, he was forced to enter the priesthood at Daigo-ji Temple and named himself Ryucho (隆超) (or Ryuki (隆起)), then Zenjo after a short while.

column1: 通称醍醐禅師、もしくはその荒くれ者ぶりから悪禅師とも呼ばれた（『平治物語』）。
column2: He was commonly known as Daigo Zenji (Master of Zen Buddhism), or Aku (evil) Zenji from his crudeness ("Heiji Monogatari" (The Tale of Heiji).

column1: 治承4年（1180年）8月17日、異母兄の源頼朝が伊豆国で挙兵。
column2: On September 15, 1180, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, his elder brother by a different mother, raised an army in Izu Province.

column1: それを知った全成は寺を抜け出し、同年8月26日石橋山の戦いで頼朝が敗北した直後に佐々木定綱ら兄弟と行き会い、相模国渋谷荘に匿われる。
column2: Upon knowing this fact, Zenjo slipped out of the temple and happened to meet Sadatsuna SASAKI and Sadatsuna's brothers shortly after Yoritomo was defeated in the Battle of Ishibashiyama on September 24, and was given refuge by them in Shibuya no sho Manor in Sagami Province.

column1: 10月1日には下総国鷺沼の宿所で頼朝と対面を果たす。
column2: On October 28, he managed to meet Yoritomo at a lodging in Saginuma, Shimousa Province.

column1: 源氏一門で最初の合流であった。
column2: This was the first reunion of members of the Minamoto clan.

column1: 全成は京都で令旨が出された事を知り、密かに寺を抜け出して修行僧に扮して下ってきた事を語り、頼朝は泣いてその志を喜んだ。
column2: Zenjo told Yoritomo that he had secretly slipped out of the temple in Kyoto upon knowing about ryoji (orders issued by princes, empresses, and so on) and then went down to the place having disguised himself as a trainee priest, and Yoritomo appreciated Zenjo's resolution by weeping with joy.

column1: 頼朝の信任を得た全成は武蔵国長尾寺（現川崎市多摩区の妙楽寺）を与えられ、頼朝の妻・北条政子の妹である阿波局(北条時政の娘)と結婚。
column2: Winning Yoritomo's confidence, Zenjo was rewarded with Nagao-ji Temple in Musashi Province (the present Myoraku-ji Temple in Tama-ku Ward, Kawasaki City) and married Awa no Tsubone (a daughter of Tokimasa HOJO) who was a younger sister of Masako HOJO, Yoritomo's wife.

column1: 阿波局は頼朝の次男千幡丸（後の源実朝）の乳母となり、以降頼朝政権において地味ながら着実な地位を築いた。
column2: Awa no Tsubone became a wet nurse for the second son of Yoritomo, Senmanmaru (later MINAMOTO no Sanetomo), and thereafter established an unspectacular but solid position in the Yoritomo administration.

column1: しかし正治元年（1199年）に頼朝が死去し、甥の源頼家が将軍職を継ぐと、全成は源実朝を擁する舅の北条時政と義兄弟の北条義時と結び、頼家一派と対立するようになる。
column2: However, Yoritomo's death and the succession to the office of a shogun by MINAMOTO no Yoriie (Zenjo's nephew) in 1199 resulted in Zenjo being allied with Tokimasa HOJO (Zenjo's father-in-law) and Yoshitoki HOJO (Zenjo's brother-in-law) who supported MINAMOTO no Sanetomo and came to be opposed to Yoriie's followers.

column1: 建仁3年（1203年）5月19日の深夜0時頃、先手を打った頼家は武田信光を派遣し、全成を謀反人として捕縛し鎌倉御所に押し込めた。
column2: Yoriie moved one step ahead of Zenjo and dispatched Nobumitsu TAKEDA around midnight on July 6, 1203, to have him arrest Zenjo as a rebel and shut Zenjo up in Kamakura Gosho (the residence of a shogun of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)).

column1: 全成は5月25日に常陸国に配流され、6月23日、頼家の命を受けた八田知家によって誅殺された。
column2: Zenjo was exiled to Hitachi Province on July 12 and killed on August 8 by Tomoie HATTA under orders of Yoritomo.

column1: 享年51。
column2: He was fifty-one years old.

column1: 7月16日には京都の東山延年寺で、子の播磨公頼全が在京御家人によって殺害された。
column2: On August 31, Harimanokimi Yorimasa, Zenjo's son, was killed at Higashiyama Ennen-ji Temple in Kyoto by an immediate vassal of the shogun residing in Kyoto.

column1: 全成の墓は、静岡県沼津市の大泉寺に嫡男阿野時元のものと並んで現存し、市の史跡に指定されている。
column2: The tomb of Zenjo exists in Daisen-ji Temple in Numazu City, Shizuoka Prefecture, adjoining the tomb of Tokimoto ANO, Zenjo's legitimate son, and is designated as a historic relic of the city.

column1: 武家としての阿野氏は時元の系統に受け継がれる。
column2: The Ano clan as a samurai family was taken over by the lineage of Tokimoto.

column1: その子孫は、南北朝時代(日本)期までは確実に存在したことが記録に残っているが、同じ河内源氏の系統に繋がる源氏庶流の足利氏などと比べても、非常に小さな勢力でしかなかった。
column2: According to records, the lineage surely existed until the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, however, the lineage was much less influential, compared with the Ashikaga clan, a branch family of the Minamoto clan, which lineage was the same Kawachi-Genji (Minamoto clan) as that of the Ano clan.

column1: これは、全成や時元が謀反人として誅殺されたという事実が大きく作用しているが、また別の要因として、阿野氏が源義朝の子孫であり、義朝の数代前の分家である足利氏などと比べても源頼朝に近い血統であったため、北条氏から非常に警戒されていたためということが考えられる。
column2: This was considerably attributable to the fact that Zenjo and Tokimoto were killed as rebels, and another fact that the Hojo clan was extraordinarily wary of the Ano clan because the Ano clan was the lineage of MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo which was closer to MINAMOTO no Yoritomo than that of the Ashikaga clan, which branched from several generations before Yoshitomo.

column1: また全成の娘は藤原北家藤原魚名流の藤原公佐と結婚しており、その子阿野実直は母方の名字を称し公家としての阿野家の祖となっている。
column2: On the other hand, Zenjo's daughter married FUJIWARA no Kimisuke, a lineage of FUJIWARA no Uona of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, and her son Sanenao ANO founded the Ano family as a court noble from his maternal surname.

column1: 後醍醐天皇の寵愛を受け後村上天皇の母となった阿野廉子はその末裔である。
column2: Renshi ANO (阿野廉子), who was in Emperor Godaigo's favor and gave birth to Emperor Gomurakami, was a descendant of the Ano clan.

column1: また、幕末期に活躍した玉松操もこの阿野家の末流に連なる人物である。
column2: Misao TAMAMATSU, who played an active role in the end of Edo period, was also a descendant of the Ano family.

column1: 荼枳尼天（だきにてん、荼吉尼天とも）は、仏教の神。
column2: Dakiniten (written as 荼枳尼天 or 荼吉尼天 in kanji characters) is a Buddhist goddess.

column1: 「荼吉尼」は梵語のダーキニー（英字：Dakini）を音訳したものである。
column2: The term 'Dakini' is the transliteration of the Sanskrit term dākinī (spelled Dakini in English).

column1: 元はインドの女神であった。
column2: Dakiniten derives from a goddess from India.

column1: 元々は農業神であったが、後に性や愛欲を司る神とされ、さらには人肉、もしくは生きた人間の心臓を食らう夜叉神とされるようになった。
column2: Dakiniten was originally a goddess of farming, but later came to be assumed to govern sexual desire and later came to be assumed to be a female fierce god eating human flesh or live human hearts.

column1: また、ヒンドゥー教ではカーリーの眷属とされる。
column2: In Hinduism, this goddess is assumed to be a dependent of Kali (a Hindu goddess).

column1: この神が仏教に取り入れられ、大日如来が化身した大黒天によって調伏されて、死者の心臓であれば食べることを許可されたとされた。
column2: This goddess was introduced into Buddhism, and it was supposed that she had been exorcised by Daikokuten (the god of Wealth), that is, the incarnation of Dainichi Nyorai (Cosmic Buddha), and then permitted to eat human hearts, if dead.

column1: 自由自在の通力を有し、六月前に人の死を知り、その人の心臓をとってこれを食べるといわれる。
column2: She is said to have unrestricted supernatural powers, knows the death of a person six months ahead, and takes and eats the person's heart.

column1: 日本
column2: Belief in Dakiniten in Japan

column1: 真言密教では、胎蔵界の外金剛院・南方に配せられ、形像は小天狗の白狐にまたがる形をしているため、辰狐王菩薩（しんこおうぼさつ）とも呼ばれる。
column2: In the Shingon Esoteric Buddhism, Dakiniten is located in the southern part of Gekongoin (the most peripheral section of the Womb World) of the Womb World (one of the two worlds in Esoteric Buddhism, representing Dainichi Nyorai's spirit of salvation having every possibility of generation as a womb, where a fetus grows), and this goddess is depicted as a small tengu (mountain spirit (portrayed as winged and having a long nose)) sitting astride a white fox; therefore, she is also called Shinkoo Bosatsu (Fox King).

column1: また天皇の即位灌頂儀礼においてダキニ天を祀っていたという記録も存在する。
column2: There exist records showing that prayers were offered for Dakiniten at an Esoteric Buddhism ceremony performed on the occasion of an emperor's enthronement.

column1: 平清盛や後醍醐天皇などがダキニ天の修法を行っていたことでも知られ、『源平盛衰記』には平清盛はこの修法を途中で止めた旨が記されている。
column2: In addition, several persons including TAIRA no Kiyomori and Emperor Godaigo were known to have performed a method of Dakiniten in esoteric Buddhism, however, "Genpei Seisuiki" (The Rise and Decline of the Minamoto and Taira clans) states that TAIRA no Kiyomori discontinued this method.

column1: しかし、この尊天は祀るのが非常に難しく、一度祀ると自分の命と引きかえに最後までその信仰を受持することが必須とされ、もしその約束を破ると、その修法を止めた途端に没落する、あるいは災禍がもたらされるとも考えられている。
column2: This goddess is extraordinarily difficult to enshrine because it is supposed that any person is required, once this goddess is enshrined, to keep believing therein in exchange for his or her life until his or her last moment and also that should such a duty be neglected (in other words, should incantation to worship the deity be discontinued), such a person would immediately become ruined or meet with disaster.

column1: したがって、これは外法として考えられ忌まれる信仰でもあった。
column2: Thus, Dakiniten was considered to be a non-Buddhist religion and belief in it tabooed.

column1: 元々インドにおいてダーキニーはジャッカルにまたがるとされていたが、中国や日本に伝わった時（中国や日本にはジャッカルはいないため）代わりに狐を当てたともいわれている。
column2: Dakini was originally supposed to sit astride a jackal in India but the fox was substituted for the jackal in introduction to China and Japan (because jackals were not present in those countries).

column1: すなわち、狐（夜干）に乗るダキニ天の像というのは、（大元のインドには存在せず）胎蔵曼荼羅や正当な密教経典・儀記には記されない姿であり、中世の日本などで生み出された姿・像である。
column2: In other words, an image of Dakiniten riding a fox (which has not existed in India) has not been depicted in Taizo Mandala (Womb Realm Mandala) or the orthodox scriptures or ritual manuals of Esoteric Buddhism and was created in medieval Japan and the like.

column1: それによって日本では、神道の稲荷と習合するきっかけとなった、とされている。
column2: It is supposed that the creation of the above image resulted in Dakiniten coming to be syncretized with a Shintoist god, Inari (the fox god) in Japan.

column1: 日本では福徳神として信仰される。
column2: In Japan, Dakiniten is believed to be a goddess of good fortune.

column1: インドでのその後
column2: Belief in Dakini in later India

column1: 日本に密教が伝わっていった後の後期密教においては、性的なイメージが付加され、裸体でシャレコウベなどをもつ女神の姿で描かれるようになっていった。
column2: In later Esoteric Buddhism after the introduction to Japan, a sexual image was added to Dakini, which resulted her to be depicted as a naked goddess having a skull.

column1: 立川流(密教)
column2: Tachikawa School (Esoteric Buddhism)

column1: 荼枳尼天は後々に性愛を司る神と解釈されたため、日本では鎌倉時代から南北朝時代(日本)にかけて、真言密教立川流(密教)という密教の一派が次第に形成され興隆を極めた。
column2: Dakiniten later came to be deemed as a goddess governing sexual love, which resulted in Tachikawa School of Shingon Esoteric Buddhism being gradually founded from the Kamakura period until the period of the Northern and Southern Courts and flourished in Japan.

column1: しかしこれは荼枳尼天を祀り髑髏を本尊とし性交の儀式を以って即身成仏を体現したとされている。
column2: It is supposed to enshrine Dakiniten, set a skull as a principle image and attain Buddhahood while still in the flesh by sexual intercourse as a rite.

column1: 立川流はこれを理由として邪教視され、江戸時代にはついに途絶えたという。
column2: For this reason, Tachikawa School was said to be regarded as a heresy and was finally exterminated in the Edo period.

column1: しかしこれは、すべて立川流を邪教視して弾圧した側の文献に依るもので、肝心の立川流の文献はほぼ焚書扱いになっており、また南朝側と北朝側の政治背景から権力闘争に巻き込まれ邪教扱いされたという背景もあるため、それらの教義や儀式などが事実であったかどうかは現在でも議論されるところとなっている。
column2: However, it is still controversial as to whether the doctrines and rites of Tachikawa School mentioned above were true or not because the above theories are all based on documents written by those who regarded Tachikawa School as a heresy and oppressed it, and most of the documents written by devotees of Tachikawa School, which are vital for verification of the genuineness of those theories, were subjected to book burning and Tachikawa School was treated as a heresy against the backdrop of its involvement in the political power struggle between the Southern and Northern Dynasties.

column1: 三門（さんもん）とは寺院の正面に配置される門のこと。
column2: The term Sanmon refers to a gate located in front of a temple.

column1: 三門は空門・無相門・無願門の三境地を経て仏国土に至る門、三解脱門（さんげだつもん）を表すとされる。
column2: Sanmon is assumed to represent Sangedatsumon (Three Gates of Liberation), which consists of three gates symbolizing three mental states, that is, kumon (gate symbolizing emptiness), musomon (gate symbolizing formlessness) and muganmon (gate symbolizing desirelessness), to pass through before reaching the Buddhist paradise.

column1: 建築史的見解では、初期の寺院の門構えは南面する正門、東西二つの副門から構成されており、これを称して三門と呼んだという。
column2: From the viewpoint of architectural history, it is said that a main gate facing the south and two auxiliary gates facing the east and west, respectively, as provided for temples in ancient times, were called Sanmon.

column1: 時代が下ると左右に脇門が付属する大門の形となり、さらに大門のみとなったが、三門の呼び方は残ったとされる。
column2: In more recent years, temples were provided with a large outer gate accompanied by side gates on the left and right sides, and later, temples came to have a large outer gate only; however, it is assumed that such a large outer gate remained to be called Sanmon.

column1: 三門の名称の由来は、貪・瞋・痴の三煩を解脱する境界の門、声聞・縁覚・菩薩の三乗が通る門などの説がある。
column2: There are several theories as to the derivation of the term Sanmon, including the following: that the term symbolizes the gates one has to pass through in order to be delivered from the three evil passions of avarice, anger and stupidity; or that the term symbolizes the gates to the three paths to Buddhahood of Shomon (learning), Engaku (self-attained enlightenment) and Bosatsu (bodhisattva).

column1: 三門には扉を設けないものがある。
column2: In some cases, Sanmon do not have a door.

column1: これは一切衆生が仏門に入る事を拒まない仏の大慈悲心を表すものといわれる。
column2: It is said that this represents Buddha's deep compassion which does not deny the entry of sentient beings into the Buddhist priesthood.

column1: 山門とは別に三門を構える例もある。
column2: Some temples have gates that are referred to using the Japanese kanji "三門" (pronounced "sanmon", the literal meaning of this term is "three gates") in addition to gates that are referred to using the Japanese kanji "山門" (also pronounced "sanmon", the literal meaning of this term is "mountain gates").

column2: Three Greatest Gates

column2: Three Greatest Gates in Japan

column2: There are two opinions about which gates are three greatest gates in Japan.
