He passed away aged 69 in 1346.

column1: 増命（ぞうみょう、承和(日本)10年（843年）－延長(元号)5年11月11日(旧暦)（927年））は、平安時代前期の天台宗の僧。
column2: Zomyo (843 - December 12, 927) was a Tendai Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the first part of the Heian period.

column1: 父は左大史桑内安峰。
column2: His father was Sadaishi (First Secretary of the Left) Yasumine KUWANOUCHI.

column1: 死後に静観僧正の号を下賜される。
column2: After his death, he was posthumously granted the name Jokan Sojo.

column1: 第10代天台座主（在任延喜6年10月17日(旧暦)-同22年5月26日(旧暦)）。
column2: He served as the tenth Tendai Zasu (head priest of the Tendai Sect) from November 11, 906 until June 28, 922.

column1: 比叡山西塔院の延最に師事、円仁から天台教学を学び、円珍から灌頂を受けた。
column2: Zomyo studied under Ensai of Saito-in Temple on Mt. Hiei, learnt the Tendai Sect teachings from Ennin, and was consecrated by Enchin.

column1: 868年（貞観_(日本)10年に26歳の若さで当時の清和天皇のために『宗論御八講』を著す。
column2: In the year 868, he wrote "Shuron Gohakko" (eight lectures of disputes about teachings of the sect) for the then Emperor Seiwa at the young age of 26.

column1: 888年（仁和元年）西塔院主となり、比叡山の他の院に比べて衰微していた西塔の再興に尽力する。
column2: He became the head priest of Saito-in Temple in the year 888 and put great effort into restoring the temple which was in a far more dilapidated condition than other temples on Mt. Hiei.

column1: 899年（昌泰2年）園城寺長吏、906年（延喜6年）には天台座主に任じられた。
column2: He was made Chori (chief priest) of Onjo-ji Temple in the year 899 before going on to be appointed Tendai Zasu in 906.

column1: 宇多法皇の出家の際、受戒・受灌の師となり、増命のいた西塔院・千光院を法皇がしばしば訪問している。
column2: When Cloistered Emperor Uda entered the Buddhist priesthood, Zomyo gave him the Buddhist precepts and conducted his ordination, with the Cloistered Emperor frequently visiting Zomyo at Saito-in Temple and Senko-in Temple at which he was based.

column1: また、宮中において玉体安泰などの祈願をしばしば行っている（特にこの頃は菅原道真の怨霊の噂が絶えず、皇太子保明親王急死の折には百日にわたる修法を行っている。
column2: He often conducted prayers for the health of the emperor at the imperial palace (it was during this time that rumors regarding the vengeful spirit of SUGAWARA no Michizane were prevalent, and he held a 100 day long ritual following the sudden death of Crown Prince Yasuakira.

column1: またこの頃唐から漂着した僧侶が胸の病に苦しんでいる事を知って祈祷を施して平癒させている）。
column2: Also, prayers that he held after becoming aware that a monk from Tang Dynasty China was suffering from a chest complaint led to his full recovery).

column1: 915年（延喜15年）少僧都に昇任し、925年（延長3年）には僧正に至った。
column2: In the year 915, he ascended to the rank of Shosozu (junior secondary prelate) before being promoted to Sojo (high-ranking Buddhist priest) in 925.

column1: 927年（延長5年）には奏上して自らに灌頂した師である円珍に智証大師の号を下賜されるのに尽力した。
column2: Zomyo reported to the emperor in the year 927 and attempted to convince him to grant Enchin, the priest who ordained him, the name Chisho Daishi.

column1: 同年中に死去したため、下賜されるのを見る事は無かった。
column2: He passed away in the same year, so did not live to see his master be granted the name.

column1: 会理（えり、仁寿2年（852年）－承平(日本)5年（935年））は、平安時代中期の真言宗の僧。
column2: Eri (852 - 935) was a Shingon Sect Buddhism monk who lived during the mid-Heian period.

column1: 出自については不詳である。
column2: His place of birth is not known.

column1: 出家した後、宗叡（しゅうえい）・聖宝（しょうぼう）に真言密教を学び、その後禅念からも受法した。
column2: After entering the Buddhist priesthood, he studied Shingon Esoteric Buddhism from Shuei and Shobo before he received the dharma from Zennen.

column1: 928年（延長(元号)6年）権律師・東寺二長者に任じられ、醍醐天皇が病気の際には孔雀経法や念仏を持って奉仕した。
column2: In the year 928, he was promoted to the rank of Gon Risshi (generally in Shingon sect, fifteenth-ranking Buddhist priest, literally, "supernumerary master of discipline") and appointed the second abbot of To-ji Temple, and he also conducted Kujaku Kyobo (the ritual for averting disasters, particularly in prayers for rain, against illness in the imperial family, and for safe childbirth of the empress) and nenbutsu (Buddhist invocation) rituals when Emperor Daigo fell ill.

column1: その後権少僧都に至っている。
column2: He later ascended to the rank of Gon Shosozu (Junior lesser prelate).

column1: 仏像彫刻や仏画に秀で、東寺食堂に安置される千手観音像や上醍醐の薬師如来像が遺作として現存している。
column2: Eri excelled in the carving and painting of Buddhist images, and surviving examples of his work include the statue of the Thousand-armed Kannon housed in the dining hall of To-ji Temple and the Yakushi Nyorai statue of Kamidaigo-ji Temple.

column1: また、東大寺大仏殿の柱絵や東寺灌頂院に安置される祖師像を描き、会理の活動は真言宗寺院のみならず南都・比叡山にまで及んだ。
column2: He also painted the pillar paintings of the Great Buddha Hall at Todai-ji Temple and the image of the patriarch at the Kanjo-in sub-temple of To-ji Temple, but his activities were not confined only to Shingon Sect temples as he was also active on Mt. Hiei and the southern capital of Nara.

column1: 真済（しんぜい、延暦19年（800年）－貞観_(日本)2年2月25日(旧暦)（860年3月25日））は、平安時代前期の真言宗の僧。
column2: Shinzei (800 - March 25, 860) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the first part of the Heian period.

column1: 父は巡察弾正紀御園。
column2: His father was Junsatsu Danjo (official who patrols and surveys land) KI no Misono.

column1: 高雄僧正・紀僧正・柿本僧正とも称される。
column2: He is also known as Takao no Sojo, Ki no Sojo and Kakinomoto no Sojo.

column1: 俗名は紀松永とする説がある。
column2: His secular name is reputed to have been KI no Matsunaga.

column1: 僧でありながら、紀氏朝臣の姓を賜っていた。
column2: Although a monk, he was granted the kabane (hereditary title) of KI no Ason.

column1: 空海に才能を見出され、824年（天長元年）24歳という異例の若さで阿闍梨となった。
column2: His talent was discovered by Kukai which led to him becoming Ajari (high priest) at the exceptionally young age of 24 in the year 824.

column1: 836年（承和(日本)3年）真然とともに唐へ渡ることを試みるが失敗し、以後12年間高雄山寺に篭って修行した。
column2: In the year 836, he attempted to travel to Tang Dynasty China with Shinzen but failed and confined himself to Takaosan-ji Temple for the following 12 years where he practiced ascetism.

column1: この間、内供奉十禅師・神護寺別当・権律師・東寺二長者に任じられている。
column2: During this period, he was appointed one of the naikubu-juzenshi (the ten priests selected for Buddhist services in the imperial court), betto (administrator) of Jingo-ji Temple, Gon Risshi (generally in Shingon sect, fifteenth-ranking Buddhist priest, literally, "supernumerary master of discipline") and second abbot of To-ji Temple.

column1: 856年（斉衡3年）僧正に任じられたが真済はこれを辞退し、師である空海に大僧正が追贈された。
column2: Shinzei was offered the rank of Sojo (high-ranking Buddhist priest) in the year 856 but he declined and his master Kukai was posthumously granted the rank of Daisojo (highest rank of the Buddhist priesthood).

column1: 860年（貞観2年）に61歳で没し、松光山大光院に葬られた。
column2: He passed away aged 61 in the year 860 and was buried at Shokozan Daiko-in Temple.

column1: 詩文にも優れ、空海の著作・詩文を集めた「性霊集」を編集している。
column2: Shinzei also excelled at poetry, and compiled the 'Shoryoshu' collection of prose and poetry by Kukai.

column1: 真然（しんぜん、延暦23年（804年）－寛平3年9月11日(旧暦)（891年10月21日））は、平安時代前期の真言宗の僧。
column2: Shinzen (804 - October 21, 891) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the first part of the Heian period.

column1: 俗姓は佐伯氏。
column2: He was born into the Saeki clan.

column1: 讃岐国多度郡の出身。
column2: He came from Tado County, Sanuki Province.

column1: 中院僧正・後僧正とも称される。
column2: He is also known as Naka-no-In Sojo and Nochino Sojo.

column1: 空海の甥と伝えられている。
column2: It is said that he was the nephew of Kukai.

column1: 出家後奈良大安寺に住し、真雅に師事して真言密教を学び、空海の没後の高野山の経営に尽力した。
column2: After entering the Buddhist priesthood, he resided at Daian-ji Temple in Nara where he studied Shingon Esoteric Buddhism under Shinga and put great effort into the administration of Mt. Koya following Kukai's death.

column1: 836年（承和(日本)3年）に真済とともに唐へ渡ろうしたが失敗している。
column2: In the year 836, he attempted to travel to Tang Dynasty China with Shinzei but failed.

column1: 874年（貞観_(日本)16年）権律師に任じられ、その後僧正まで昇任した。
column2: He ascended to the rank of Gon Risshi (generally in Shingon sect, fifteenth-ranking Buddhist priest, literally, "supernumerary master of discipline") in the year 874 before being promoted to Sojo (high-ranking Buddhist priest).

column1: 884年（元慶8年）東寺長者に任じられ、891年（寛平3年）に没するまで在職した。
column2: He was appointed chief abbot of To-ji Temple in 884, a post that he held until his death in 891.

column1: この間、東寺の真雅から借りていた「三十帖冊子」を高野山に持ち出したことは、その後東寺と高野山との紛争の原因となった。
column2: His removing of the 'Sanjujo Sasshi' (30 volumes of esoteric Buddhist scripture hand-copied by priest Kukai when he was staying in China) lent to him by Shinga from Mt. Koya during this period is said to have been the origin of a dispute between To-ji Temple and Mt. Koya.

column1: 授翁宗弼（じゅおうそうひつ、1296年－1380年）は、鎌倉時代後期から南北朝時代(日本)にかけての臨済宗の僧。
column2: Juo Sohitsu (1296 - 1380) was a Rinzai Sect Buddhist monk who lived from the latter part of the Kamakura period to the Northern and Southern Courts period (Japan).

column1: 父は藤原宣房。
column2: His father was FUJIWARA no Nobufusa.

column1: 諱は宗弼、字は授翁。
column2: His real name was Sohitsu and his posthumous name was Juo.

column1: 諡号は円鑑国師・微妙大師。
column2: His posthumous Buddhist names were Enkan Kokushi and Bimyo Daishi.

column1: 後醍醐天皇に仕えながら大徳寺の宗峰妙超に参禅し、宗弼という法名を授かった。
column2: While in the service of Emperor Godaigo, he practiced Zen under Shuho Myocho of Daitoku-ji Temple and was granted the Buddhist name Sohitsu.

column1: 建武の新政の際には後醍醐天皇をいさめたが受け入れられず、ひそかに洛北岩倉で不二大徳に支持して得度した。
column2: He warned Emperor Godaigo during the Kenmu Restoration but these were not heeded and he covertly supported Funi Daitoku at Iwakura in Rakuhoku (north of the capital of Kyoto) and entered the Buddhist priesthood.

column1: 20年間隠遁した後、京都妙心寺の関山慧玄に参禅してその法を継ぎ、妙心寺2世となった。
column2: After 20 years of seclusion, he practiced Zen under Kanzan Egen of Myoshin-ji Temple in Kyoto and succeeded his teachings to become the 2nd head priest of Myoshin-ji Temple.

column1: 宗叡（しゅうえい・しゅえい、大同(日本)4年（809年）－元慶8年3月26日(旧暦)（884年4月29日））は、平安時代前期の真言宗の僧。
column2: Shuei (809 - April 29, 884) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the first part of the Heian period.

column1: 俗姓は小谷氏。
column2: He was born into the Odani clan.

column1: 京都の出身。
column2: He came from Kyoto.

column1: 読み方については「しゅうえい」とも「しゅえい」ともいう。
column2: His name can be pronounced either 'Shuuei' or 'Shuei'.

column1: 入唐八家の（最澄・空海・常暁・円行・円仁・恵運・円珍・宗叡）一人。
column2: He was one of the eight priests (Saicho, Kukai, Jogyo, Engyo, Ennin, Eun, Enchin and Shuei) who travelled to Tang Dynasty China.

column1: 14歳で比叡山に入り載鎮に師事して出家し、のちに興福寺の義演から法相教学を、延暦寺の義真から天台教学を、円珍から金剛界・胎蔵界両部を、実慧から真言密教を学び、禅林寺(京都市)の真紹から灌頂を受けた。
column2: At age 14, he went to Mt. Hiei where he entered the Buddhist priesthood under Saichin before later learning the Hosso Sect teachings from Gien of Kofuku-ji Temple, the Tendai Sect teachings from Gishin of Enryaku-ji Temple, Diamond Realm and Womb Realm mandalas from Enchin, Shingon Sect teachings from Jitsue, and being consecrated by Shinsho of Zenrin-ji Temple (Kyoto City).

column1: 862年（貞観_(日本)4年）真如法親王とともに唐へ渡った。
column2: In the year 862, he travelled to Tang Dynasty China with Cloistered Imperial Prince Shinnyo.

column1: 五台山(中国)・天台山を巡礼し、また汴州の玄慶、長安の法全などに密教を学んで、865年（貞観7年）に帰国。
column2: He made pilgrimages to Mt. Wutai and Mt. Tiantai and studied esoteric Buddhism under monks including Xuanqung of Bianzhou and Faquan of Changan before returning to Japan in the year 865.

column1: 869年（貞観11年）に権律師、879年（元慶3年）僧正に任じられ、東大寺別当・東寺二長者も歴任している。
column2: Shuei was promoted to Gon-Risshi (generally in Shingon sect, fifteenth-ranking Buddhist priest, literally, "supernumerary master of discipline") in 869, and in the year 879 was successively appointed Sojo (high-ranking Buddhist priest), betto (administrator) of Todai-ji Temple and second abbot of To-ji Temple.

column1: 清和天皇の帰依を受け、天皇が出家する際にはその戒師もつとめた。
column2: He received the devotion of Emperor Seiwa and served as kaishi (the priest who imparts the Buddhist commandments) when the emperor entered the priesthood.

column1: 定昭（じょうしょう、906年-983年）は、平安時代中期の真言宗の僧。
column2: Josho (906 - 983) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the mid-Heian period.

column1: 父は左大臣藤原師尹。
column2: His father was FUJIWARA no Morotada, Minister of the Left.

column1: 定照とも書き、嵯峨僧都・一乗院僧都とも称される。
column2: His name is also written with different Chinese characters and he is also known as Saga Sozu and Ichijoin Sozu.

column1: 興福寺の忍斅（にんこう）に法相宗を学び、寛空に灌頂を受けて大覚寺別当に任じられた。
column2: He studied the Hosso Sect teachings under Ninko of Kofuku-ji Temple and consecrated by Kanku before being appointed betto (administrator) of Daikaku-ji Temple.

column1: 966年（康保3年）に権律師、979年（天元(日本)2年）には大僧都に昇任している。
column2: Josho was promoted to Gon-Risshi (generally in Shingon sect, fifteenth-ranking Buddhist priest, literally, "supernumerary master of discipline") in the year 966 and ascended to the rank of Daisozu (the highest rank of Buddhist priesthood) in the year 979.

column1: また、東寺長者・興福寺別当・金剛峯寺座主を歴任し、興福寺一乗院を創建した。
column2: In addition, he was successively appointed chief abbot of To-ji Temple, betto (administrator) of Kofuku-ji Temple and zasu (head priest) of Kongobu-ji Temple as well as founding the Ichijo-in sub-temple of Kofuku-ji Temple.

column1: 晩年は「法華経」読誦に専念した。
column2: In his final years, he devoted himself to the recitation of the Lotus Sutra.

column1: 常暁（じょうぎょう、生年不詳－貞観_(日本)8年11月30日(旧暦)（867年1月9日））は、平安時代前期の僧。
column2: Jogyo (birth date unknown - January 9, 867) was a Buddhist monk who lived during the first part of the Heian period.

column1: 出自については不詳である。
column2: His birthplace is unknown.

column1: 小栗栖律師・入唐根本大師とも称される。
column2: He is also known as Ogurisu Risshi and Nyuto Konpon Daishi.

column1: 入唐八家（最澄・空海・常暁・円行・円仁・恵運・円珍・宗叡）の一人。
column2: He was one of the eight priests (Saicho, Kukai, Jogyo, Engyo, Ennin, Eun, Enchin and Shuei) who travelled to Tang Dynasty China.

column1: 初め元興寺の豊安（ぶあん）に三論（中論・十二論・百論）の教学を学び、その後空海から灌頂を受けた。
column2: He began by studying the three treatises (the Treatise on the Middle Way, the Treatise on the Twelve Gates, and the One-Hundred-Verse Treatise) under Buan of Gango-ji Temple before being consecrated by Kukai.

column1: 838年（承和(日本)5年）三論の留学僧として唐に渡った。
column2: In the year 838, he travelled to Tang Dynasty China to study the three treatises.

column1: 揚州で元照に三論の教学を、文サイ（サイは王へんに祭）に密教と大元帥法（怨敵・逆臣の調伏、国家安泰を祈る真言密教の法）を学び、翌839年（承和6年）日本に帰国した。
column2: He studied the three treatises under Wenji in Yangzhou, esoteric Buddhism and Daigen Suiho (esoteric Buddhist rituals to pray for the defeat enemies and traitors as well as the security of the nation) under Bunsai before returning to Japan in the year 839.

column1: 840年（承和7年）山城国宇治の法琳寺に大元帥明王像を安置して修法院とすることを請い許された。
column2: In the year 840, he housed a statue of Daigensui Myoo at Horin-ji Temple in Uji, Yamashiro Province and was granted permission to use it as an esoteric ritual temple.

column1: ついで宮中の常寧殿で大元帥法を初めて行っている。
column2: Jogyo went on to be the first to conduct Daigen Suiho rituals at the imperial Joneiden palace.

column1: 以後大元帥法は後七日御修法（ごしちにちのみしほ）に準じる扱いとなった。
column2: Daigen Suiho subsequently became part of the Goshichinichi-no-mishiho (a seven-day New Year ritual).

column1: 864年（貞観6年）権律師に任じられた。
column2: He was appointed Gon Risshi (generally in Shingon sect, fifteenth-ranking Buddhist priest, literally, "supernumerary master of discipline") in the year 864.

column1: 大元帥法（だいげんすいほう/だいげんのほう）は、密教における大法（呪術）の1つ。
column2: Daigen Suiho is one of the magic rituals of esoteric Buddhism.

column1: 大元帥明王を本尊として、怨敵・逆臣の調伏、国家安泰を祈って修される法で、839年（承和(日本)6年）常暁が唐から法輪寺(斑鳩町)に伝えた物。
column2: Daigen Suiho is a ritual in which practitioners pray to an image of Daigensui Myoo for the defeat of enemies and traitors as well as the security of the nation that was introduced to Japan's Horin-ji Temple (Ikaruga-cho) from Tang Dynasty China by Jogyo in the year 839.

column1: 以来、毎年正月8日から17日間宮中で行われるようになった。
column2: It was subsequently practiced at the imperial palace from the 8th to the 17th day of the first month of every new year.

column1: この法は宮中のみで行われ、臣下がこの法を修めることは許されなかった。
column2: This ritual was held only within the imperial palace and it was not permitted to be practiced by retainers.

column1: 長徳元年（995年）に起きた長徳の変では、内大臣藤原伊周がこれを行ったという口実により大宰府に左遷された。
column2: FUJIWARA no Korechika, Minister of the Interior was demoted to Dazai-fu (local government office in Kyushu region) based on the excuse that he performed it during the Chotoku Incident that broke out in the year 995.

column1: 国阿（こくあ、正和3年（1314年）－応永12年9月11日(旧暦)（1405年10月4日））は、南北朝時代(日本)から室町時代中期にかけての時宗の僧。
column2: Kokua (1314 - October 4, 1405) was a Ji Sect Buddhist monk who lived from the Northern and Southern Courts period (Japan) to the mid-Muromachi period.

column1: 時宗国阿派・霊山派の祖。
column2: He is the founder of the Kokua School and Ryozen School of the Ji Sect.

column1: 「双林寺縁起」によれば、出身は播磨国で、俗名を箸崎国明と称し、1355年（文和4年/正平(日本)10年）に出家して国阿弥陀仏と称したという。
column2: According to 'Sorinji Engi' (the history of Sorin-ji Temple), he was born in Harima Province as Kuniaki HASHIZAKI but was given the name Koku Amidabutsu after entering the Buddhist priesthood in 1355.

column1: 熊野などの山岳における修行につとめ、「伊勢・熊野参詣の道者不浄を嫌わず参詣すべし」との神託を受け、その主張を広めて人気を博した。
column2: He practiced at mountains including Kumano, received a divine message telling him 'Do not loath the impurity of Ise and Kumano pilgrims but allow them to pray regardless,' and spreading this message made him extremely popular.

column1: 京都東山(京都府)霊山に正法寺(京都市東山区)を建立して霊山派の本寺となり、また雙林寺(京都市)を再興して国阿派の本寺となった。
column2: Kokua founded Shobo-ji Temple (Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City) at Ryozen in Kyoto's Higashiyama (Kyoto Prefecture) which became the headquarters of the Ryozen School, and restored Sorin-ji Temple (Kyoto City) which became the headquarters of the Kokua School.

column1: 増誉（ぞうよ、長元5年（1032年）－永久(元号)4年1月29日(旧暦)（1116年2月14日））は、平安時代中期の天台宗の僧。
column2: Zoyo (1032 - February 14, 1116) was a Tendai Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the mid-Heian period.

column1: 父は大納言藤原経輔。
column2: His father was Dainagon (Major Counselor) FUJIWARA no Tsunesuke.

column1: 一乗院大僧正と称される。
column2: He is also known as Ichijoin Daisojo.

column1: 園城寺（三井寺）の乗延に師事し、行円の下で得度、行観（ぎょうかん）から灌頂を受けた。
column2: Zoyo studied under Joen of Onjo-ji Temple (Mii-dera Temple) before entering the Buddhist priesthood under Gyoen and being consecrated by Gyokan.

column1: 大峰山・葛城山で山岳修行を行い、早い時期から霊験を現したという。
column2: He practiced mountain asceticism at Mt. Omine and Mt. Katsuragi and is said to have performed miracles from an early period.

column1: また、白河天皇、堀河天皇両天皇の護持僧としても活躍した。
column2: He also served as the gojiso (personal monk) of Emperor Shirakawa and Emperor Horikawa.

column1: 1090年（寛治4年）白河上皇の熊野参詣の先達をつとめて最初の熊野検校に任じられ、洛東に聖護院を建立した。
column2: In 1090, he served as a guide during Retired Emperor Shirakawa's pilgrimage to Kumano and was appointed as the first Kumano Kengyo (official supervisor of Kumano) before founding Shogo-in Temple.

column1: 天王寺別当・園城寺長吏を歴任、1105年（長治2年）天台座主に任じられるが、延暦寺の反対により翌日辞任に追い込まれた。
column2: He was successively appointed betto (administrator) of Tenno-ji Temple and chori (chief priest) of Onjo-ji Temple as well as Tendai Zasu (head priest of the Tendai Sect) in 1105 but was forced to resign on the following day by opposition from Enryaku-ji Temple.

column1: その後は、尊勝寺など13ヶ寺の別当を兼任した。
column2: Following this, he simultaneously served as betto (administrator) of 13 temples including Sonsho-ji Temple.

column1: 1116年（永久4年）に85歳で没し、園城寺長吏の職は行尊が後継者となった。
column2: Zoyo passed away in 1116 aged 85; his post of chori (chief priest) of Onjo-ji Temple being succeeded by Gyoson.

column1: 浄蔵（じょうぞう、寛平3年（891年）－康保元年11月21日(旧暦)（964年12月27日））は、平安時代中期の天台宗の僧。
column2: Jozo (891 - December 27, 964) was a Tendai Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the mid-Heian period.

column1: 父は三善清行。
column2: His father was Kiyoyuki MIYOSHI.

column1: 宇多天皇に師事して出家。
column2: He entered the Buddhist priesthood under Emperor Uda.

column1: 比叡山で玄昭に密教を、大慧に悉曇を学んだ。
column2: At Mt. Hiei, he studied esoteric Buddhism under Gensho and the Siddham script under Daiei.

column1: 935年（承平(日本)5年）から940年（天慶3年）にかけて平将門が関東で乱をおこすと、その調伏のため修法を行い霊験があり、その他にも験があたったという。
column2: Among other miracles attributed to Jozo, he successfully prayed to subjugate a rebellion in the Kanto region led by TAIRA no Masakado from 935 to 940.

column1: 美声の声明を行うことでも知られ、また天文・医薬にも通じていた。
column2: He is also known for his beautiful chanting of Buddhist hymns as well as his proficiency in astronomy and medicine.

column1: 勝賢（しょうけん、保延4年2月18日(旧暦)（1138年3月30日）－建久7年6月22日(旧暦)（1196年7月19日））は、平安時代中期の真言宗の僧。
column2: Shoken (March 30, 1138 - July 19, 1196) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the mid-Heian period.

column1: 東大寺87世、醍醐寺18･20･22世座主。
column2: He served as the 87th head priest of Todai-ji Temple and the 18th, 20th and 22nd head priest of Daigo-ji Temple.

column1: 父は藤原通憲（信西）。
column2: His father was FUJIWARA no Michinori (Shinzei).

column1: 初名は勝憲。
column2: His original name was Shoken.

column1: 通り名を侍従僧正、覚洞院権僧正。
column2: He is commonly known as Jiju Sojo and Kakutoin Gon no Sojo.

column1: 忍辱仙流の祖である寛遍（『醍醐寺三宝院流伝授目録』）に師事し、1158年（保元3年）権律師に任じられる。
column2: Shoken studied under Kanpen ("Daigoji Sanpoin ryu Denju Mokuroku" (Catalog of books for initiation of Sanpoin, Daigo-ji Temple)), Ninnikusen School founder, and was promoted to the rank of Gon Risshi (generally in Shingon sect, fifteenth-ranking Buddhist priest, literally, "supernumerary master of discipline") in 1158.

column1: 翌1159年（保元4年）醍醐寺の実運に灌頂を受け、また常喜院の心覚からも法を受けた。
column2: In 1159, he was consecrated by Jitsuun of Daigo-ji Temple and received the dharma from Shinkaku of Joki-in Temple.

column1: 1160年（永暦元年）以降、醍醐寺座主に3度任じられたが、一時期同門の乗海の反対により高野山へ逃れた時期もある。
column2: He was appointed zasu (head priest) of Daigo-ji Temple on three occasions since 1160 but there was a brief period during which opposition from Jokai led to him leaving for Mt. Koya.

column1: 父信西の関係で後白河法皇との結びつきは強く、木曽義仲の上洛の際に法皇の安穏と天下泰平を祈祷したり、祈雨の為に孔雀経法を修すなどした。
column2: As the son of Shinzei, he had a close relationship with Cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa, and he prayed for peace and tranquility of the Cloistered Emperor and the nation during Yoshinaka KISO's visit to Kyoto as well as conducting a Kujaku Kyobo ritual for rain.

column1: 東寺長者・東大寺別当を歴任。
column2: Shoken was successively appointed choja (head priest) of To-ji Temple and betto (administrator) of Todai-ji Temple.

column1: 1185年（文治元年）8月10日には権僧正に任じられた。
column2: On August 10, 1185, he was granted the rank Gon no Sojo (a highest ranking priest, next to a sojo).

column1: 弟子に仁和寺の守覚法親王がいる。
column2: His disciples included Cloistered Imperial Prince Shukaku of Ninna-ji Temple.

column1: 著書に『灌頂秘訣』1巻・『六月抄』がある。
column2: Among his written works are "Kanjo Hiketsu" volume 1 and "Rokugatsu sho."

column1: 俊海（しゅんかい、生没年不詳）は、平安時代末から鎌倉時代前期の真言宗の僧。
column2: Shunkai (date of birth and death unknown) was a Shingon sect priest who lived from the end of the Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

column1: 父は藤原俊忠で、藤原俊成は兄にあたる。
column2: His father was FUJIWARA no Toshitada, and FUJIWARA no Toshinari was his brother.

column1: 子には僧であり歌人として知られる寂蓮がいる。
column2: His children included Jakuren, who was known as a priest and waka poet.

column1: 醍醐寺阿闍梨。
column2: He was Ajari at the Daigo-ji Temple.

column1: 貞崇（じょうすう（ていすう）、貞観_(日本)8年（866年）－天慶7年7月23日(旧暦)（944年8月19日））は、平安時代中期の真言宗の僧。
column2: Josu (also known as Teisu) (866 - August 19, 944) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the mid-Heian period.

column1: 俗姓は三善氏。
column2: He was born into the Miyoshi clan.

column1: 京都の出身。
column2: He came from Kyoto.

column1: 真言院僧都・鳥栖寺僧都とも称される。
column2: He is also known as Shingonin Sozu and Torinosudera Sozu.

column1: 幼くして貞観寺恵宿の室に入り、902年（延喜2年）醍醐寺聖宝から伝法灌頂をうけた。
column2: Josu entered the Buddhist priesthood under Eshuku of Jogan-ji Temple at a very young age and went on to be consecrated by Shobo of Daigo-ji Temple in the year 902.

column1: 一時期金峰山（きんぶさん）に篭ったこともあったが、927年（延長(元号)5年）醍醐天皇の護持僧となってから、938年（天慶元年）に法華三昧堂を建立するなど醍醐寺における真言教団の成立に大きく貢献した。
column2: He briefly secluded himself at Mt. Kinbu but in the year 927 became the gojiso (personal monk) of Emperor Daigo before founding Hokke Sanmai-do halls in 938 as well as playing a major role in the establishing the Shingon Esoteric Buddhism denomination at Daigo-ji Temple.

column1: なお、東寺長者・醍醐寺座主・金剛峰寺座主などを歴任している。
column2: In addition, he was successively appointed choja (chief abbot) of To-ji Temple, zasu (head priest) of Daigo-ji Temple and zasu (head priest) of Kongobu-ji Temple.

column1: 頼瑜（らいゆ、嘉禄2年（1226年）－嘉元2年1月1日(旧暦)（1304年2月7日））は、鎌倉時代中期から後期にかけての真言宗の僧。
column2: Raiyu (1226 - February 7, 1304) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived from the mid- to late-Kamakura period.

column1: 俗姓は土生川氏。
column2: He was born into the Dojogawa clan.

column1: 字は俊音。
column2: His posthumous name was Shunon.

column1: 号は俊音房。
column2: His priest title was Shunonbo.

column1: 紀伊国那賀郡の出身。
column2: He was born in Naga County, Kii Province.

column1: 高野山大伝法院で学び、奈良で三論宗・華厳・瑜伽・唯識を学んだのち、広沢流・報恩院流を学んだ。
column2: Raiyu studied at Daidenpo-in Temple on Mt. Koya from where he went to learn Sanron Sect teachings, Kegon Sect teachings, yoga and the Yuishiki (consciousness-only) doctrine in Nara before studying the teachings of the Hirosawa School and the Hoonin School.

column1: 大伝法院・醍醐寺両寺に属し、1272年（文永9年）高野山中性院の住持となった。
column2: He served both Daidenpo-in Temple and Daigo-ji Temple, and was appointed head priest of Chusho-in Temple on Mt. Koya in 1272.

column1: 実勝から灌頂を受け、1280年（弘安3年）中性院流を開いたが、金剛峯寺と摩擦が生じ、1288年（正応元年）大伝法院と密厳院を紀伊国根来寺に移して新義真言宗の基礎を築いた。
column2: Raiyu was consecrated by Jissho and founded the Chushoin school in 1280 but friction arose with Kongobu-ji Temple, and in 1288 he relocated Daidenpo-in Temple and Mitsugo-in Temple to Negoro-ji Temple in Kii Province where he built the foundations of the Shingi Shingon Sect.

column1: 袋中（たいちゅう、天文(元号)21年1月29日(旧暦)（1552年2月23日）－寛永16年1月21日(旧暦)（1639年2月23日））は、江戸時代前期の浄土宗の学僧。
column2: Taichu (February 23, 1552 - February 23, 1639) was a Jodo sect priest in the early Edo period.

column1: 俗姓は佐藤氏。
column2: His secular surname was Sato clan.

column1: 陸奥国菊多郡の出身。
column2: He was from Kikuta-no-kori, Mutsu Province.

column1: 弁蓮社入観・良定と号する。
column2: His pseudonym (pen name) was Benrenja Nyukan, Ryojo.

column1: 14歳の時、故郷陸奥国菊多郡の能満寺で出家し、名越檀林で浄土教学を学んだ。
column2: At the age of 14, he became a priest at Noman-ji Temple in Kikuta-no-kori, Mutsu Province, his homeland, and learned Jodo doctrine at Nagoe Danrin Buddhist School.

column1: 1577年（天正5年）江戸増上寺で浄土宗白旗派の奥義を極め、故郷の成徳寺13世となる。
column2: In 1577, he dived into the esoteric points of the Shirahata Sect of the Jodo Sect at Zojo-ji Temple in Edo and became the 13th head priest at Jotoku-ji Temple in his homeland.

column1: 1603年（慶長8年）51歳の時、中国（明）に渡ろうとして失敗して琉球に漂着した。
column2: In 1603, at the age of 51, he failed in the attempt to go to China (Ming) and drifted ashore on Ryukyu.

column1: ここで琉球王尚寧王の帰依を得て城外に桂林寺を開いて布教に努めた。
column2: There he received a donation from King Shonei, King of Ryukyu; established Keirin-ji Temple outside the castle; and was engaged in missionary work.

column1: 1606年（慶長11年）帰朝し、京都三条の檀王法林寺を再興し、東山五条に袋中庵を建立した。
column2: In 1606, he returned to Kyoto, reestablished Dannohorin-ji Temple in Kyoto Sanjo, and established Taichu-an in Kyoto Gojo.

column1: また、京都・奈良に諸事を建立し、その数は20余寺に達したという。
column2: He also established as many as twenty temples in Kyoto and Nara.

column1: 1639年（寛永16年）、京都・飯岡の西方寺にて88歳で死去。
column2: In 1639, he passed away at the age of 88 at Saiho-ji Temple in Ioka, Kyoto.

column1: 著書に『琉球神道記』がある。
column2: His writings included "Ryukyu Shinto-ki."

column1: 寛遍（かんぺん、康和2年（1100年）-永万2年6月30日(旧暦)（1166年7月28日））は、平安時代後期の真言宗の僧。
column2: Kanpen (1100 - July 28, 1166) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the latter part of the Heian period.

column1: 父は大納言源師忠。
column2: His father was Dainagon (Major Counselor) MINAMOTO no Morotada.

column1: 尊勝院大僧正・忍辱山大僧正とも称される。
column2: He is also known as Sonshoin Daisojo and Ninnikusen Daisojo.

column1: 山城国円教寺の寛蓮に師事して出家し、寛助に灌頂を受けた。
column2: Kanpen entered the Buddhist priesthood under Kanren of Engyo-ji Temple in Yamashiro Province and was consecrated by Kanjo.

column1: その後大和国忍辱山円成寺を再興し、一字金輪法を日課とした。
column2: He went on to restore Ninnikusen Enjo-ji Temple in Yamato Province and conducted the Ichijikinrin-ho (ritual of the one word golden wheel) on a daily basis.

column1: 広隆寺別当・東寺長者・東寺法務・東大寺別当・仁和寺別当・円教寺別当を歴任し、1161年（応保元年）大僧正に至った。
column2: Kanpen was successively appointed betto (administrator) of Koryu-ji Temple, choja (head priest) of To-ji Temple, homu (director) of To-ji Temple, betto (administrator) of Ninna-ji Temple and betto (administrator) of Engyo-ji Temple, as well as being granted the rank of Daisojo (a Buddhist priest of the highest order) in 1161.

column1: この間には、高野山大塔落慶供養の導師をつとめ、また、尊寿院を建立し、鳥羽天皇の皇后美福門院（藤原得子）が寄進した「御手印縁起」を尊寿院におさめた。
column2: During this period, he served as officiating monk at the dedication ceremony of the Daito (pagoda that according to Shingon doctrine represents the central point of a mandala) of Mt. Koya, and founded Sonju-in Temple and housed within it a copy of 'Goshuin Engi' (a history of Mt. Koya with the red seal) that was donated by Emperor Toba's wife, Empress Bifukumon-in (FUJIWARA no Tokushi).

column1: 事相にすぐれ、その後忍辱山流の祖とされる。
column2: He excelled at practical training and became the founder of the Ninnikusen School

column1: 寛助（かんじょ、天喜5年（1057年）－天治2年1月15日(旧暦)（1125年2月19日））は、平安時代後期の真言宗の僧。
column2: Kanjo (1057 - February 19, 1125) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the latter part of the Heian period.

column1: 父は右大弁源師賢。
column2: His father was Udaiben (Major Controller of the Right) MINAMOTO no Morokata.

column1: 成就院大僧正・弁大僧正・法関白とも称される。
column2: He is also known as Jojuin Daisojo, Ben Daisojo and Ho Kanpaku.

column1: 仁和寺経範の室に入って密教を学び、性信入道親王（しょうしんにゅうどうしんのう）から灌頂を受けた。
column2: Kanjo entered the Buddhist priesthood under Tsunenori of Ninna-ji Temple and studied esoteric Buddhism before being consecrated by priest-Imperial Prince Shoshin.

column1: 白河天皇からの信任が厚く、1099年（康和元年）権律師に任じられて以降、遍照寺(京都市)別当・仁和寺別当・東寺長者・東寺法務を歴任した。
column2: He was deeply trusted by Emperor Shirakawa and after being granted the rank of Gon Risshi (generally in Shingon sect, fifteenth-ranking Buddhist priest, literally, "supernumerary master of discipline") in 1099 and was successively appointed as betto (administrator) of Hensho-ji Temple (Kyoto City), betto (administrator) of Ninna-ji Temple, choja (head priest) of To-ji Temple and homu (director) of To-ji Temple.

column1: 1113年（永久(元号)元年）鳥羽天皇の病気平癒の修法の報償として、東寺結縁灌頂の小阿闍梨（こあじゃり）が僧綱に任じられる慣例のもとを築いた。
column2: In 1113 the custom that the Ko-Ajari (lower ranking high priest) ordained at To-ji Temple would become appointed to the Sogo (Office of Monastic Affairs) was established as thanks when Kanjo conducted a ritual that cured Emperor Toba's illness.

column1: その後も、広隆寺別当・法勝寺別当・東大寺別当を歴任し、1121年（保安(元号)2年）大僧正に任じられた。
column2: After this he served as betto (administrator) of Koryu-ji Temple, Hossho-ji Temple and Todai-ji Temple, and ascended to the rank of Daisojo in 1121.

column1: 性信入道親王（しょうしんにゅうどうしんのう、寛弘2年6月1日(旧暦)（1005年7月1日）-応徳2年9月27日(旧暦)（1085年10月18日））は、平安時代中期の皇族・僧。
column2: Priest-Imperial Prince Shoshin (July 1, 1005 - October 18, 1085) was a member of the Imperial Family and monk in the mid Heian period.

column1: 父は三条天皇、母は藤原済時の娘藤原娍子。
column2: His father was Emperor Sanjo and his mother was FUJIWARA no Seishi, the daughter of FUJIWARA no Naritoki.

column1: 三条天皇第4皇子。
column2: He was the fourth prince of Emperor Sanjo.

column1: 真言宗仁和寺の第2世門跡。
column2: He was the second monzeki (successor of a temple) of Shingon sect Ninna-ji Temple.

column1: 通称は大御室。
column2: He was commonly called O-Omuro.

column1: 諱は師明、号は光明寿院、密号は金剛行。
column2: His imina (personal name) was Moroakira, his pseudonym (a pen name) was Komyojuin, and his Mitsugo (name given in Kanjo (a ceremony to be the successor)) was Kongogyo.

column1: 1011年（寛弘8年）に親王宣下。
column2: He was given the title of Imperial Prince in 1011.

column1: 1018年（寛仁2年）に出家し、1023年（治安(元号)3年）に仁和寺の済信（せいじん）から伝法灌頂を受けた。
column2: He entered into the priesthood in 1018 and was given Denpo Kanjo (ceremony to invest someone with Ajari (rank of master)) from Seijin of Ninna-ji Temple in 1023.

column1: 1059年（康平2年）高野山に参詣して、護摩を800余日間行い、高野山山上に灌頂院造営を発願した。
column2: He visited Mt. Koya in 1059 and performed the Buddhist rite of burning Goma (holy fire) for more than eight hundred days and vowed to build, with an imperial order, Kanjo-in Temple on the top of Mt. Koya.

column1: 1073年（延久5年）後三条天皇の出家の戒師を勤めた。
column2: He served as a kaishi (the priest who imparts the Buddhist commandments) for Emperor Gosanjo when he entered into the priesthood in 1073.

column1: 後冷泉天皇の病気平癒をはじめ多くの修法を行ってその験著しく、1083年（永保3年）その功により二品に叙せられた。
column2: He performed many prayers and esoteric Buddhism services including a cure of Emperor Goreizei's disease and his prayers produced a great effect and he was appointed to a nihon (the second court rank for Imperial Princes) for his achievements in 1083.

column1: 弟子には寛意、行禅、長信らがいる。
column2: His disciples included Kani, Gyozen, and Choshin.

column1: 済信（さいじん・せいじん、天暦8年1月30日(旧暦)（954年3月12日）-長元3年6月11日(旧暦)（1030年7月14日））は、平安時代中期の真言宗の僧。
column2: Saishin (also called Seijin) (March 12, 954 - July 14, 1030) was a monk of Shingon sect in the mid Heian period.

column1: 父は左大臣源雅信（敦実親王という説もある）。
column2: His father was MINAMOTO no Masanobu, Sadaijin (Minister of the Left) (Some people say that his father was Imperial Prince Atsumi).

column1: 真言院僧正・北院大僧正・仁和寺僧正・観音院僧正とも称される。
column2: He was also called Shingonin Sojo (high-ranking Buddhist priest), Kitain Daisojo (a Buddhist priest of the highest order), Sojo of Ninna-ji Temple, or Sojo of Kannon-in Temple.

column1: 雅慶に師事して真言密教を学び、法相教学も兼習している。
column2: He studied Shingon Esoteric Buddhism under Gakei and he also studied Hosso sect doctrine.

column1: 989年（永祚(日本)元年）寛朝に灌頂を受け、権律師に任じられた。
column2: He received the teachings of Buddhism from Kancho and was appointed to Gon-Risshi (generally in Shingon sect, fifteenth-ranking Buddhist priest, literally, "supernumerary master of discipline") in 989.

column1: 以後、東大寺別当・勧修寺長吏・東寺長者法務を歴任している。
column2: He later successively held the positions of betto (the superior of a temple) of Todai-ji Temple, chori (the head priest) of Kaju-ji Temple, and To-ji Choja Homu (Director of Temple Affairs and the chief abbot of To-ji Temple).

column1: 1019年（寛仁3年）大僧正に至り翌1020年（寛仁4年）僧として初めての牛車宣旨をうけた。
column2: He rose to be a daisojo in 1019 and was given the Gissha no senji (special permission from the Emperor to enter the imperial palace in an ox-drawn cart) for the first time as a monk the next year, 1020.

column1: 灌頂大会や修法の導師を多くつとめ、1027年（万寿4年）には藤原道長の葬儀における導師を勤めた。
column2: He often performed as a doshi (officiating monk) at Kanjo-daies and esoteric Buddhism services and served as a doshi at the funeral ceremony for FUJIWARA no Michinaga in 1027.

column1: 十三仏信仰（じゅうさんぶつしんこう）とは、十王信仰に基づき日本で創作された閻魔王を初めとする冥途の裁判官である十王及びその後の審理（七回忌・十三回忌・三十三回忌）を司る裁判官の本地垂迹説とされる仏に対する信仰である。
column2: Jusanbutsu shinko refers to the belief in Juo, ten kings, who are judges in Meido hell including Enma-o (the King of Hell) who were created in Japan based on the Juo-shinko (ten Kings (ten Judges of Hell) belief) and in buddhas, according to the Honji-suijaku setsu (theory of original reality and manifested traces), whose present forms are judges who conduct the later trials (the sixth, the twelfth, and the 32nd anniversaries).

column1: これらの仏は審理において実際の裁判所における弁護士の役目を勤めることとなるとされる。
column2: It is said that these buddhas act as lawyers just as in a trial at the court.

column1: 初七日（七日目）　不動明王（秦広王）
column2: A memorial service on the seventh day after death Fudo Myoo (Shinko-o (the first judge of Ju-o))

column1: 二七日（十四日目）　釈迦如来（初江王）
column2: A memorial service on the Fourteenth Day Shaka Nyorai (Shoko-o (the second judge of Ju-o))

column2: A memorial service on the Twenty-First Day Monju Bosatsu (Sotei-o (the third judge of Ju-o))

column1: 四七日（二十八日目）　普賢菩薩（五官王）
column2: A memorial service on the Twenty-Eighth Day Fugen Bosatsu (Gokan-o (the fourth judge of Ju-o))

column1: 五七日（三十五日目）　地蔵菩薩（閻魔王）
column2: A memorial service on the Thirty-Fifth Day Jizo Bosatsu (Enma-o (the King of Hell))

column1: 六七日（四十二日目）　弥勒菩薩（変成王）
column2: A memorial service on the Forty-Second Day Miroku Bosatsu (Henjo-o (the sixth judge of Ju-o))

column1: 七七日（四十九日目）　薬師如来（泰山王）
column2: A memorial service on the Forty-Ninth Day Yakushi Nyorai (Taizan-o (the seventh judge of Ju-o))

column2: A memorial service on the One Hundred Day Kanzeon Bosatsu (Byodo-o (the eighth judge of Ju-o))

column1: 一周忌（一年目）　勢至菩薩（都市王）
column2: The first anniversary of death Seishi Bosatsu (Toshi-o (the ninth judge of Ju-o))

column2: The second anniversary of death Amidanyorai (Godotenrin-o (the tenth judge of Ju-o))

column2: The sixth anniversary of death Ashuku-nyorai (Rengeo, lotus king)

column2: The twelfth anniversary of death Dainichinyorai (Gion-o (the second judge after Ju-o))

column2: The 32nd anniversary of death Kokuzo Bosatsu (Hokai-o (the third judge after Ju-o))

column1: (※1)死亡した時を一回目として三回目と数えるため、実際は死亡した年から数えると2年目である。
column2: (*1) Since the date of death is counted in the first year, the third year is actually the second year when it is counted from the year of death.

column2: The sixth, the twelfth, and the 32nd anniversaries are also counted in the same way.

column2: (*2) '閦: Shuku' is a machine dependent character.

column2: Eight buddhas listed in Jusanbutsu buddhas join as guardian Buddhas of the Oriental zodiac.

column2: Matching buddhas for each Oriental zodiac are as follows:

column2: Tiger - Kokuzo Bosatsu

column2: Hare - Monju Bosatsu

column2: Monkey - Dainichinyorai

column2: Cock - Fudo Myoo

column2: Dog - Amidanyorai

column1: (※3)正確には一般的にいう観世音菩薩、つまり「聖観音」ではなく、「六観音」と呼ばれる「変化観音」の一つである「千手観音」だが、変化観音はすべて聖観音の化身であるとされるため敢えて「観世音菩薩」と表記。
column2: (*3) Actually, this kannon is not a general Kanzeon Bosatsu, that is, 'Sho Kannon' but 'Senju Kannon,' one of 'Henge Kannons' (the transformations in which Kannon (Deity of Mercy) appears in order to save sentient beings) called 'Roku Kannon,' but here 'Kanzeon Bosatsu' is daringly used as all Henge Kannons are said to be an incarnations of Sho Kannon.

column1: 円行（えんぎょう、延暦18年（799年）－仁寿2年3月6日(旧暦)（852年3月29日））は、平安時代の真言宗の僧。
column2: Engyo (799 - March 29, 852) was a monk of Shingon sect in the Heian period.

column1: 出身は京都。
column2: He was born in Kyoto.

column1: 入唐八家（最澄・空海・常暁・円行・円仁・恵運・円珍・宗叡）の一人。
column2: He was one of the eight priests who went to China (Saicho, Kukai, Jogyo, Engyo, Ennin, Eun, Enchin, and Shuei).

column1: 初め元興寺歳栄に師事して華厳宗の僧として得度・受戒した。
column2: He first studied under Saiei of Gango-ji Temple and entered priesthood and received religious precepts as a Kegon sect monk.

column1: 823年（弘仁14年）空海から金剛界・胎蔵界両部の大法を受け、また杲隣（ごうりん）から灌頂を受けた。
column2: He received Daiho (great traditions of Esoteric practices) of both Kongokai (Diamond Realm) and Taizokai (Womb Realm) from Kukai in 823 and also received kanjo (a ceremony to be the successor) from Gorin.

column1: 実恵の推挙により入唐請益僧（にっとうしょうやくそう）となり、838年（承和(日本)5年）円仁・円載・常暁らと唐に渡った。
column2: He became a nitto-shoyaku-so, a monk who was approved to go to China, with recommendation by Jichie (Jitsue) and he went to Tang with Ennin, Ensai, Jogyo, and others in 838.

column1: 青龍寺義真から法を受けた。
column2: He succeeded to the teachings from Gishin of Qinglongsi Temple.

column1: 翌839年（承和6年）に帰国し「請来目録」を奉った。
column2: He came back from Tang the following year, 839, and presented 'Shorai Catalogue' (Esshuroku).

column1: その後勅命により山城国霊巌寺を開創し、また天王寺の初代別当に任じられた。
column2: He later founded Reigan-ji Temple, Yamashiro Province by an imperial order and was also appointed to the first betto (the superior of a temple) of Tenno-ji Temple.

column1: 播磨国太山寺の開祖とも伝えられる。
column2: It is also said that he was the founder of Taisan-ji Temple in Harima Province.

column1: 顕智（けんち、嘉禄2年（1226年）-延慶(日本)3年7月4日(旧暦)（1310年7月30日）?）は、鎌倉時代中期の浄土真宗の僧。
column2: Kenchi (1226 - July 30, 1310 ?) was a monk of the Jodo Shinshu (True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) in the mid Kamakura period.

column1: 初め比叡山で出家・修行し、賢順と号したという。
column2: It is said that he first became a priest in Mt. Hiei and practiced asceticism, and he used Kenjun as a pseudonym.

column1: 浄土真宗の祖親鸞の弟子真仏に師事し、その後親鸞の直弟子となって顕智と改めたという。
column2: He studied under Shinbutsu, a disciple of Shinran who was a founder of Jodo Shinshu, and later became Shinran's direct disciple and changed his name to Kenchi.

column1: 常に親鸞に随行し、親鸞が京に戻る際にも従った。
column2: He always went with and followed Shinran and attended on him when he came back to Kyoto.

column1: 真仏が没した後の1258年（正嘉2年）には、真宗高田派の本山である専修寺の3世を継ぎ、覚信尼を助けて大谷廟堂の造営に力を注いだ。
column2: In 1258, after Shinbutsu died, he succeeded the third Senju-ji Temple, Shinshu Sect Takada school head temple and helped Kakushinni and devoted himself to build Otani-byodo Mausoleum.

column1: 一説によれば浄土真宗で初めて法印・大僧都に叙任されたと伝えられる。
column2: According to one theory, he was appointed to Hoin (the highest rank among Buddhist priests) and Daisozu (the upper Buddhist priests in the second highest position) for the first time in Jodo Shinshu.

column1: 賢俊（けんしゅん、正安元年（1299年）-正平(日本)12年/延文2年7月16日(旧暦)（1357年8月2日））は、南北朝時代(日本)の真言宗の僧。
column2: Kenshun (1299-August 2, 1357) was a monk of Shingon sect in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

column1: 父は権大納言日野俊光。
column2: His father was Toshimitsu HINO, a Gon Dainagon (provisional major counselor).

column1: 兄弟に日野資名。
column2: Sukena HINO was his brother.

column1: 俗名は日野賢俊（ひのたかとし）。
column2: His secular name was Takatoshi HINO.

column1: 菩薩寺大僧正。
column2: He was the daisojo (a Buddhist priest of the highest order) of Bosatsu-ji Temple.

column1: 醍醐寺宝池院流賢助に師事して密教を学ぶ。
column2: He studied the Esoteric Buddhism under Kenjo of Hochiin school, Daigo-ji Temple.

column1: 南北朝時代の内乱では足利尊氏方につき、後醍醐天皇の信任を受け権勢を誇っていた文観を排除し、1336年（建武(日本)3年/延元元年）、権大僧正に任じられて醍醐寺座主・根来寺座主となる。
column2: In the internal disturbances in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), he took Takauji ASHIKAGA's side and excluded Monkan, a monk who had wielded power taking advantage of Emperor Godaigo's trust, and in 1336, he was appointed to the Gon Daisojo (second-ranking Buddhist priest), becoming the head of Daigo-ji Temple and Negoro-ji Temple.

column1: 同年2月尊氏が九州に走った際にはそれに従い、陣中の群議にあたった。
column2: When Takauji made an escape to Kyushu region in April and May of the same year, he accompanied Takauji and unified Takauji's troops at the front by integrating divergent opinions among subordinates.

column1: また持明院統（北朝(日本)）の光厳天皇の院宣と錦旗を尊氏に伝える役割を果たし、室町時代の足利将軍家と日野家の関係の端緒となる。
column2: He also fulfilled his duty to convey a command from a retired emperor Emperor Kogen of Jimyoin-To Line (imperial lineage from Emperor Gofukakusa to Emperor Gokomatsu, Northern Court of Japan) and hand the Imperial standard (made of gold brocade) to Takauji, which laid the foundation of the relationship between the Ashikaga Shogunal family and the Hino family.

column1: 尊氏の護持僧として権勢をふるい、醍醐寺に食邑として6万石を寄進されて伽藍を整備し、さらに京都に新三宝院を造営・寄進されてその院主となった。
column2: Wielding power as Takauji's gojiso (a monk working for a noble family), he not only established a Buddhist temple at Daigo-ji Temple after receiving a donated fief of 60,000 koku (approximately 10.8 million liters of crop yield), but also established Shin Sanpoin in Kyoto, becoming the Inju (the chief of a temple) after the new established temple was donated.

column1: 1340年（暦応3年/興国元年）に東寺長者、1342年（康永元年/興国3年）法務大僧正に就任。
column2: He assumed the post of To-ji choja (the chief abbot of To-ji Temple) in 1340 and the post of Homu Daisojo (the highest Buddhist priest managing Buddhistic ceremonies and giving a certificate to monks and nuns) in 1342.

column1: 1350年（観応元年/正平5年）東寺長者の職を辞して尊氏の九州鎮定にしたがっている。
column2: He resigned his post as To-ji choja in 1350 to accompany Takauji to the Kyushu region for suppressing dissidents.

column1: 『三宝院賢俊像』は醍醐寺所蔵、また『三宝院賢俊僧正日記』がある。
column2: In addition to "The portrait of Sanpoin Kenshun" owned by Daigo-ji Temple, "Sanpoin Kenshun Sojo Nikki" (Diary of Kenshun, Sanpoin Temple) is left.

column1: 願暁（がんぎょう、生年不詳－貞観_(日本)16年3月27日(旧暦)（874年4月21日））は、平安時代前期の学僧。
column2: Gangyo (date of birth unknown, passed away on April 21, 874) was a learned priest pursuing his studies in the former Heian period.

column1: 元興寺の薬宝や大安寺の勤操（ごんそう）に師事して三論宗教学を学び、法相宗・密教にも通じた。
column2: He studied Sanron Sect under Yakuho of Gango-ji Temple and Gonso of Daian-ji Temple and learned a lot about Hosso sect/esoteric Buddhism.

column1: 845年（承和(日本)12年）維摩会講師となり、翌846年（承和13年）の延暦寺定心院落慶の際には職衆をつとめた。
column2: He became a lecturer at Yuimae in 845 and served as shikishu (assistant priest) at the celebration of the construction of Joshinin of Enryaku-ji Temple in 846.

column1: 861年（貞観3年）東大寺大仏御頭供養の際に宝樹1本を寄進し、864年（貞観6年）に新設された法橋上人位に任じられた。
column2: He donated one hoju at Todaiji Daibutsu Onkashira Kuyo (Inauguration ceremony of fixing the head of Great Buddha of Todai-ji Temple) in 861 and was given the newly-established title, Hokkyo-shonin-i (a title of honor that was given to Buddhist sculptors, painters, poets, etc) in 864.

column1: 弟子には聖宝・隆海などがいる。
column2: His disciples included Shobo and Ryukai.

column1: 勤操（ごんそう・ごんぞう、天平勝宝6年（754年）－天長4年5月8日(旧暦)（827年6月25日））は、奈良時代後期から平安時代前期にかけての三論宗の僧。
column2: Gonso was a Sanron sect priest (born in 754 and passed away in June 25, 827) in the latter Nara period and the former Heian period.

column1: 俗姓は秦氏。
column2: His secular name was Hata clan.

column1: 大和国高市郡の出身。
column2: He was from Takaichi County, Yamato Province.

column1: 岩淵上人とも称される。
column2: He was also called Iwabuchi Jonin (a holy priest Iwabuchi).

column2: Gonso studied San-lun Teachings under Shinrei and Zengi at Daian-ji Temple, and was chosen as Senzo Dosha (entering the Buddhist priesthood chosen from thousands of priests).

column1: 比叡山根本中堂の落慶供養の際には堂達をつとめた。
column2: Gonso worked as the chief priest of the service at a dedication ceremony at Konponchudo on Mt. Hiei.

column1: 796年（延暦15年）同門であった栄好の追善のために高円山（たかまどやま）の麓の岩淵寺で法華八講を創始した。
column2: In 796, at Iwabuchi-dera Temple located at the foot of Mt. Takamado, he started Hokke hakko (ceremonial series of eight lectures on the eight scrolls of the Lotus Sutra) for the repose of the soul of Eiko, who had been in the same school.

column1: 813年（弘仁4年）大極殿最勝講で法相宗義を論破し律師に任じられた。
column2: In 813, Gonso argued the Hosso teachings down at Daigoku-den Saisho-ko and was designated as Risshi (the third rank of priest following Sojo and Sozu).

column1: 弘福寺（川原寺）別当や当時造営中であった西寺の別当を歴任して826年（天長3年）大僧都に至った。
column2: Gonso worked as betto (chief administrator) of Gufuku-ji Temple (also known as Kawara-ji Temple) and Sai-ji Temple, which was under construction at that time, and became Daisozu (the upper Buddhist priests in the second highest position) in 826.

column1: 当時の日本では新しい宗義であった最澄の天台宗・空海の真言宗にも理解を示した。
column2: Gonso also showed understanding for new sects, the Tendai sect established by Saicho and the Shingon sect established by Kukai.

column1: 没後に僧正の僧位が追贈されている。
column2: He was raised to Sojo in Soi (rank of Buddhist priest) after his death.

column1: 益信（やくしん、天長4年（827年）－延喜6年3月7日(旧暦)（906年4月8日））は、平安時代前期の真言宗の僧。
column2: Yakushin (827 - April 8, 906) was a Shingon sect priest in the former Heian period.

column2: His secular surname was Ki clan.

column1: 行教の実弟。
column2: He was Gyokyo's real brother.

column1: 備前国の生まれ。
column2: He was born in Bizen Province.

column1: 円成寺僧正・本覚大師とも称される。
column2: He was also called Enjoji Sojo and Hongaku Daishi.

column1: 真言宗広沢流の祖。
column2: He was the founder of Hirosawa school of Shingon sect.

column1: 初め明詮に法相教学を学び、宗叡に密教の法を受け、源仁に灌頂を受けた。
column2: He first studied Hosokyo-sect under Myosen, studied the doctrine of the esoteric Buddhism under Shuei, and received kanjo (a ceremony to be the successor) from Gennin.

column1: 888年（仁和4年）権律師に任じられ、その後僧正まで昇任した。
column2: He was designated as Gon-Risshi (generally in Shingon sect, fifteenth-ranking Buddhist priest, literally, "supernumerary master of discipline") in 888, and then promoted to Sojo (high-ranking Buddhist priest).

column1: その間、東寺長者法務・東大寺別当・石清水八幡宮検校を兼務している。
column2: During that time, he also worked as To-ji Choja Homu (Director of Temple Affairs and the chief abbot of To-ji Temple), Todai-ji Betto and Kengyo (temple or shrine administrator) of Iwashimizu Hachiman-gu Shrine.

column1: 899年（昌泰2年）宇多上皇が出家する際の受戒の師となり、あとに灌頂も授けた。
column2: In 899, when the Retired Emperor Uda became a priest, he worked as Uda's mentor for his receiving the religious precept and later gave Uda kanjo as well.

column1: また、内侍司藤原淑子の帰依も受け、その東山山荘を寺として円成寺と称した。
column2: Yakushin also made FUJIWARA no Yoshiko, Naishi no tsukasa (female palace attendant) a Buddhist, her Higashiyama mountain villa was donated as a temple and he named it the Enjo-ji Temple.

column1: その後益信の門流は広沢流とよばれるようになった。
column2: After that, his school came to be called Hirosawa school.

column1: 俊芿（しゅんじょう、仁安(日本)元年8月10日(旧暦)（1166年9月6日）－嘉禄3年3月8日(旧暦)（1227年4月25日））は、鎌倉時代前期の僧。
column2: Shunjo (September 6, 1166 - April 25, 1227) was a priest in the former Kamakura period.

column1: 出自については不詳である。
column2: It is unknown in which clan or family he was born.

column1: 肥後国の出身。
column2: He was from Higo Province.

column1: 字は我禅。
column2: His azana (popular name) was Gazen.

column1: 号は不可棄。
column2: His pseudonym (pen name) was Fukaki.

column1: 勅号は大興正法国師。
column2: His temple name given from an emperor was Daiko Shobo Kokushi (National Master Daiko Shobo).

column2: In 1183, Shunjo became a priest at the age of 18 and in 1184 he received gusokukai at Kanzeon-ji Temple Dazaifu City.

column2: He strongly felt the importance of the precepts of Buddhism and went to China (Southern Sung Dynasty) in 1199.

column2: In 1569, he became a Buddhist monk with Nikkin, a monk of Chogen-ji Temple in Wakasa Province, with his mentor and in 1571, two years later, he studied under Nichiju, a monk of Honman-ji Temple in Kyoto.

column2: In 1588, he succeeded the position of eighth chief priest of Honman-ji Temple from his mentor Nichiju.

column1: 文禄年間頃は不受不施を主張していたが、慶長年間に入ると受不施の立場に変り、1602年（慶長7年）身延山久遠寺21世として入寺している。
column2: Although he took the position of Fuju-fuse (a school of Nichiren Sect which asserts that fuse (money etc. given to monks) must not be received or given from those who believe in other sutras than Hokke-kyo Sutra) during the era of Bunroku, he later changed his position to Ju-fuse (a school of Nichiren sect which asserts fuse can be received even from those who believe in other sutras than Hokke-kyo Sutra) and became in 1602 the 21st chief priest of Minobusan Kuon-ji Temple.

column1: 紀伊国紀州藩主徳川頼宣の帰依を受け、頼宣の援助により駿河国蓮永寺を再興している。

column1: 恵運（えうん、延暦17年（798年）－貞観_(日本)11年9月23日(旧暦)（869年10月31日））は、平安時代前期の真言宗の僧。

column1: 『般若心経秘鍵』（はんにゃしんぎょうひけん）は、818年頃に空海によって書かれた『般若心経』の注釈書である。

column1: まず、『般若心経』の鳩摩羅什訳と大遍覚三蔵（玄奘）訳との異同点を指摘し、次いで『般若心経』を般若菩薩の大心真言による深い禅定に入るための教えと定義している。
column2: It points out the similarities and differences between Kumaraju's translation of "Hannya Shingyo" and Daihenkaku Sanjo's (Xuan Zang) translation and it also defines "Hannya Shingyo" as a teaching to dive into deep meditation with the help of Daishin Shingon mantra of Hannya-bosatsu.

column2: It preaches that "Hannya Shingyo" should not be mixed with "Daihannyaharamitta-kyo Sutra," because they contain the same phrases, just as dragons shouldn't be considered the same as snakes because both have the same scales.

column2: It also pays attention to Shingon granted to the last part and recommends that you should not read "Hannya Shingyo" but make it the object for kansho (meditation based on Shingon nenju) and practice it.

column2: He was known as an ascetic Buddhist monk who was good at such rites like Buccho Sonsho ho and Fudo ho and it has been passed down that his rites conducted during Taira no Masakado's War (Johei War) had a miraculous effect.

column1: 年齢は、数え年。

column2: In order to ensure consistency with those of his books, dates will be shown based on a lunar calendar (except for the year, month and day of birth and death) and gengo (an era name) during the period of Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) will be shown by those of the Northern Court.

column1: 文永7年12月28日(旧暦)（1271年2月16日）、京都に生まれる。

He was then five years old in 1274.

column1: この頃より仏門の道を志すようになる。

column1: 延慶(日本)2年（1309年）7月、青蓮院により大谷廟堂留守職は、覚如に継承される事が裁定される。
column2: In July, 1309, it was decided by Shoren-in Temple that Rusushiki of Otani Byodo Mausoleum should be succeeded by Kakunyo.

column1: 敗れた唯善は、大谷廟堂を徹底的に破壊し、御影像（親鸞の木像）と遺骨の一部を奪い、鎌倉へ逃亡する。
column2: Yuizen, who was defeated, destroyed Otani Byodo Mausoleum thoroughly, took Mieizo (wooden statue of Shinran) as well as a portion of Shinran's remains and ran away to Kamakura.

column1: （唯善事件、決着。）
column2: (Yuizen Incident was concluded.)

column1: しかし東国門徒は、大谷廟堂留守職継承を血縁に限定されるのを嫌い、無条件には覚如を認めなかった。
column2: However, Togoku Monto (believers in Kanto region) didn't unconditionally admit Kakunyo as the successor because they didn't like that the successor of Rusushiki of Otani Byodo Mausoleum was limited to a person who was related by birth.

column1: やむなく留守職就任を前提とした十二か条からなる懇望状（同年7月26日付）を記す。
column2: In the face of such a situation, he was forced to write a petition consisting of 12 clauses (as of July 26 in the same year) on the premise of his inauguration as Rusushiki.

column1: この事が切っ掛けで、脆弱な立場の留守職に、限界を感じ「大谷廟堂」の寺院化を考えるようになる。
column2: Triggered by the above incident, he realized the limitation in the weak position of Rusushiki and started to think of the conversion of 'Otani Byodo Mausoleum' into a temple.

column1: 延慶3年（1310年）、東国へ勧進と留守職承認の懇願の為に赴く。
column2: In 1310, he went to the Kanto region for the purpose of soliciting contributions and petitioning believers for approving his inauguration as Rusushiki.

column1: 半年にわたる懇願の末、承認され正式に留守職を継承する。
column2: After a half year of petitioning, his inauguration was approved and he formally succeeded the position of Rusushiki.

column1: 延慶4年/応長元年（1311年）、親鸞五十回忌に当たり、御影像と影堂を再建する。
column2: In 1311, he reconstructed Mieizo and Ei-do Hall (a hall dedicated to sect's founder) on the occasion of the 49th anniversary of Shinran's death.

column1: 正和3年（1314年）、自身の病身と血脈による留守職継承を既成事実とする為、長男の存覚に留守職を譲り、一条大宮に隠居する。
column2: In 1314, he handed over the position of Rusushiki to Zonkaku, his eldest son, and entered into a secluded life at Ichijo Omiya due to his own illness as well as with the aim of making the succession of Rusushiki by a bloodline a fait accompli.

column1: 元亨元年（1321年）、「大谷廟堂」を寺院化し、「本願寺」と号する（本願寺の成立）。
column2: In 1321, he converted 'Otani Byodo Mausoleum' into a temple and named it 'Hongan-ji Temple' (the establishment of Hongan-ji Temple).

column1: 寺院化に伴い留守職は、住持職を含めた別当職となる。
column2: In the wake of conversion to a temple, Bettoshoku (a chief administrator of a temple) was created by combining the role of Rusushiki and Jujishoku (a resident head of a temple).

column1: 元亨2年（1322年）、留守職の血脈継承と東国門徒に対する意見の相違により、存覚を義絶し、別当職に復職する。
column2: In 1322, he severed his relations with Zonkaku and was reinstated in Bettoshoku because of a conflict of opinion concerning the succession of Rusushiki by a bloodline and the attitude toward Togoku Monto.

column1: 嘉暦元年（1326年）、『執持鈔』を撰述する。
column2: In 1326, he wrote "Shuji Sho."

column1: 元弘元年（1331年）、『口伝抄』を撰述し、「三代伝持の血脈（けちみゃく）」を表明し、法灯継承を主張する。
column2: In 1331, he wrote "Kuden Sho" in which he declared 'a bloodline of three generations' and insisted his succession of Hoto (the light of Buddhism).

column1: （法脈…法然⇒親鸞⇒如信⇒覚如、血統…親鸞⇒覚信尼⇒覚恵⇒覚如）自らを本願寺三世と位置づける。
column2: (Religious line: Honen=>Shinran=>Nyoshin=>Kakunyo, bloodline: Shinran=>Kakushinni=>Kakue=>Kakunyo) He defined himself as the third head priest of Hongan-ji Temple.

column1: （親鸞…開祖〈宗祖〉、如信…本願寺二世）
column2: (Shinran: the founder of Hongan-ji Temple <the founder of the sect>, Nyoshin: the second head priest of Hongan-ji Temple)

column1: 正慶元年（1332年）、如信の三十三回忌の勤修の為、陸奥国の大網（現、福島県白川郡古殿町）に赴く。
column2: In 1332, he went to Oami (Furudono-machi, Shirakawa-gun, Fukushima Prefecture) in Mutsu Province in order to preach at the memorial service for the 32nd anniversary of Nyoshin's death.

column1: 同時に有力な東国門徒20人余りに、正統な宗義の相伝者・法灯の継承者である事を認めさせ署名させる。
column2: Taking this opportunity, he convinced 20-odd Togoku Monto to admit that he was the legitimate inheritor of sect's doctrine as well as the successor of Hoto and got them to sign their names.

column1: 建武(日本)3年（1336年）、足利尊氏による戦乱を避け、存覚の居住する近江瓜生津に疎開する。
column2: In 1336, he evacuated to Omi Uriuzu, where Zonkaku resided, in order to keep away from the war initiated by Takauji ASHIKAGA.

column1: 戦火の影響で「本願寺」全焼する。
column2: Hongan-ji Temple was burnt down by the fires of war.

column1: 『本願寺上人伝絵』（初稿本）消失する。
column2: Hongan-ji Shonin Dene (first version) was lost.

column1: 建武4年（1337年）、帰洛し西山久遠寺に居住する。
column2: In 1337, he returned to Kyoto and resided at Nishiyama Kuon-ji Temple.

column1: 『本願鈔』『改邪鈔』を撰述する。
column2: He wrote "Hongan Sho" and "Gaija Sho."

column1: 建武5年/暦応元年（1338年）、近江瓜生津の愚咄の仲裁により、存覚の義絶を赦免し、別当職を譲る。
column2: In 1338, he absolved Zonkaku of gizetsu and handed over Bettoshoku to him through the mediation of Gutotsu of Omi Uriuzu.

column1: 暦応3年（1340年）、『願々鈔』を撰述する。
column2: In 1340, he wrote "Gangan Sho."

column1: 暦応5年、康永元年（1342年）存覚を再び義絶し、別当職に復職する。
column2: In 1342, he again severed his relations with Zonkaku and was reinstated in Bettoshoku.

column1: 康永2年（1343年）、『最要鈔』を撰述する。
column2: In 1343, he wrote "Saiyo Sho."

column1: 『本願寺上人伝絵』（『御伝鈔』）を増補して、十五段とする（「康永本」）。
column2: He supplemented "Hongan-ji Shonin Dene" ("Godensho") and made it a book consisting of 15 chapters (Koeibon (a book written in Koei era)).

column1: 『御絵伝』は、円寂（えんじゅく、浄賀法眼の子）と門人・宗舜（そうしゅん）に描かせる。
column2: He got Enjuku (a son of Joga Hogen) and his disciple Soshun to draw "Goeden."

column1: （拝観の便を考え、詞を『御伝鈔』、絵を『御絵伝』と別仕立てにした。）
column2: (For worshippers' convenience sake, words and pictures were separately compiled in "Godensho" and "Goeden" respectively.)

column1: 貞和6年/観応元年（1350年）、存覚の義絶を赦免する。
column2: In 1350, he absolved Zonkaku of gizetsu.

column1: （一旦は、拒否している。)
column2: (He once had refused.)

column1: 別当職は、覚如の次男の従覚の子、善如が継承する旨の譲り状を記す。
column2: He wrote a letter stating that he would get Zennyo, a son of his second son Jukaku, to succeed Bettoshoku.

column1: 観応2年1月19日(旧暦)（1351年2月23日）、82歳（数え年）にて覚如入滅する。
column2: On February 23, 1351, he died in his 82nd year.

column1: 建仁寺に送葬される。
column2: He was buried at Kennin-ji Temple.

column1: 寛印（かんいん、生没年不詳）は、平安時代中期の天台宗の僧。
column2: Kanin (dates of birth and death unknown) was a Tendai sect priest in the middle Heian period.

column1: 父は紀忠方。
column2: His father was KI no Tadakata.

column1: 丹後国与謝郡の出身。
column2: He was from Yona-county of Tango Province.

column1: 房号は願蓮房。
column2: His priest title was Ganren-bo.

column1: 丹後千徳とも称される。
column2: He was also called Tango-sentoku.

column1: 比叡山良源・源信(僧侶)に天台教学を学んでその学名が高かった。
column2: Kanin learned Tendai doctrine under Ryogen and Genshin (priests) at Mt. Hiei and was famous for his academic accomplishment.

column1: 宮中や貴族の法会にしばしば列席し、正暦年間（990年－995年）に内供奉（ないぐぶ）となった。
column2: He often attended Buddhist meetings held in the Imperial court or by aristocracy, and served as naigubu (a special monk who holds a position in the Imperial court) from 990 to 995.

column1: 源信の迎講（むかえこう）には当初批判的であったがその後帰依し、源信の教を奉じて台密龍禅院流を形成した。
column2: Although Kanin was at first critical of Genshin's Mukae-ko, he came to believe in it and established the Daimitsu Ryuzenin-ryu school under the teaching of Genshin.

column1: その後、諸国教化のため遍歴し、丹後国では天橋立において迎講をおこした。
column2: He visited many places for an enlightenment campaign, and established Mukae-ko at Amanohashidate in Tango Province.

column1: 皇慶（こうげい）の要請により舎利講を行い、また大乗寺を再興した。
column2: He gave Shari-ko, a lecture on Shari (Buddha's relics), at the request of Kogei and reestablished Daijo-ji Temple.

column1: 桓舜（かんしゅん、天元(日本)元年（978年）－天喜5年9月9日(旧暦)（1057年10月9日））は、平安時代中期の天台宗の僧。
column2: Kanshun (978 - October 9, 1057) was a Buddhist monk of the Tendai sect who lived during the mid Heian period.

column1: 父は備後国守源致遠（文徳源氏）。
column2: His father was 致遠 MINAMOTO (Montoku-Genji (Minamoto clan)), the Kokushu (governor) of Bingo Province.

column1: 月蔵房と号する。
column2: His pseudonym was 月蔵房 (moon storage).

column1: 天台座主慶円に天台教学を学び、貞円・日助・遍救とともに比叡山の四傑と称された。
column2: He learned about the Tendai doctrine from Kyoen, the head priest of the Tendai sect, and was called as one of the four masters of Mt. Hiei along with Teien, Nichijo, and Henkyu.

column1: 一時世俗を嫌って伊豆国で修行していた時期もあるが後に比叡山に戻る。
column2: For a period of time he practiced asceticism in Izu Province hating the worldly affairs, but returned to Mt. Hiei.

column1: 1016年（長和5年）藤原道長の法華三十講の講師となって以来、朝廷の貴族の間で活躍した。
column2: Since he had served as the lecturer at the Thirty Lectures of the Lotus Sutra held by FUJIWARA no Michinaga in 1016, he was active among the Imperial Court aristocrats.

column1: 1035年（長元8年）権律師、1039年（長暦3年）極楽寺座主、ついで法性寺座主と昇任し、1054年（天喜2年）権大僧都に至った。
column2: In 1035 he got Gon-Risshi (generally in Shingon sect, fifteenth-ranking Buddhist priest, literally, "supernumerary master of discipline"), in 1039 became the zasu (temple's head priest) of Gokuraku-ji Temple, followed by being promoted to the head priest of Hossho-ji Temple, and reached Gon dai sozu (the provisional second highest position, upper grade, of priest) in 1054.

column1: 寛信（かんしん・かんじん、応徳元年（1084年）－仁平3年3月7日(旧暦)（1153年4月2日））は、平安時代後期の真言宗の僧。
column2: Kanshin (also known as Kanjin) (1084 - April 2, 1153) was a Shingon sect priest in the late Heian period.

column1: 父は参議藤原為房。
column2: His father was Sangi (councillor) FUJIWARA no Tamefusa.

column1: 勧修寺法務とも称される。
column2: He was also called Kaju-ji Homu.

column1: 東大寺覚樹に三論教学を学び、勧修寺厳覚から真言宗小野流の奥義を受けた。
column2: He learned San-lun Teachings from Kakuju at Todai-ji Temple, and esoteric points of the Shingon sect Ono school from Genkaku at Kanshu-ji Temple.

column1: 1110年（天永元年）勧修寺別当に就任し、勧修寺における法華八講の整備に力を注いだ。
column2: He assumed the post of Betto (the superior of a temple) of Kanshu-ji temple in 1110 and worked hard for the provision of Hokke hakko (ceremonial series of eight lectures on the eight scrolls of the Lotus Sutra) at the temple.

column1: 南都三会已講（さんえいこう）の功により1134年（長承3年）権少僧都に任じられ、その後権大僧都に至った。
column2: In 1134, he was awarded the position of Gon shosozu (Junior lesser prelate) for Nanto Sanei-ko and later became Gon daisozu (Junior prelate).

column1: この間東寺長者・法務、東大寺別当を歴任している。
column2: During that time, he served successively as To-ji Choja (the chief abbot of To-ji Temple), To-ji Homu (the director of To-ji Temple Affairs) and Todai-ji Betto.

column1: 真言密教における事相に関する多くの著作を残した。
column2: He left various writings concerning the practical trainings of Shingon Esoteric Buddhism.

column1: 顕真（けんしん、天承元年（1131年）－建久3年11月14日(旧暦)（1192年12月20日））は、平安時代後期の天台宗の僧。
column2: Kenshin (1131- December 20, 1192) was a Tendai sect priest in the late Heian period.

column1: 号は宣陽房。
column2: His pseudonym (pen name) was Senyo-bo.

column1: 父は右衛門権佐藤原顕能。
column2: His father was FUJIWARA no Akiyoshi, Uemon Gon no suke (provisional assistant captain of the Right Division of Outer Palace Guards).

column1: 母参議藤原為隆娘。
column2: His mother was a daughter of FUJIWARA no Tametaka, Sangi (councillor).

column1: 比叡山で天台教学・密教を学んだあと、1173年（承安(日本)3年）大原別所に隠棲した。
column2: After learning Tendai doctrine and Esoteric Buddhism at Mt. Hiei, Kenshin lived in seclusion at Ohara-bessho in 1173.

column1: 浄土信仰へ傾き1186年（文治2年）勝林院に法然・重源・貞慶・明遍・証真らの碩学を集めて大原問答を行ったとされる。
column2: It is said that Kenshin was influenced by Jodo-shinko (the Pure Land faith), and in 1186 conducted Ohara Mondo (Ohara Debate) with great scholars, including Honen, Chogen, Jokei, Myohen, and Shoshin.

column1: 参加者については異説もある。
column2: However there were heretics in the participants.

column1: 翌1187年（文治3年）勝林院で不断念仏をはじめ、1190年（建久元年）には第61代天台座主に就任した。
column2: In 1187, he initiated Fudan nenbutsu (continual chanting of Buddhist invocation) at Shorin-in Temple and in 1190, became the 61st Tendai-Zasu (the head priest of the Tendai sect).

column1: 最勝会（金光明最勝王経を講じ、国家の安泰を祈願する勅会）の証義もつとめている。
column2: He also served as Shogi judge of Saisho-e (Buddhism meeting held by the imperial order to lecture on Golden Light of the Most Victorious Kings Sutra and to pray for the peace and security of the nation).

column1: 1192年（建久3年）、比叡山円融房で没した。
column2: In 1192, he passed away in Enyu-bo, Mt. Hiei.

column1: 日政（にっせい、元和(日本)9年2月23日(旧暦)（1623年3月23日）－寛文8年2月18日(旧暦)（1668年3月30日））は、江戸時代前期の日蓮宗の僧・漢詩人。
column2: Nissei (March 23, 1623 - March 30, 1668) was a Buddhist monk of the Nichiren sect and a poet of Chinese poetry who lived in the early Edo period.

column1: 山城・深草瑞光寺を開山した。
column2: He founded Zuiko-ji Temple in Fukakusa, Yamashiro.

column1: 俗名は石井元政（もとまさ）。
column2: His lay name was Motomasa ISHII.

column1: 幼名は源八郎、俊平。
column2: When he was small, he was called Genpachiro one time, and Toshihira at another time.

column1: 号は妙子・泰堂・空子・幻子・不可思議など。
column2: His pseudonyms included Myoshi, Taido, Kushi, Genshi, and Fukashigi.

column1: 京都一条に地下（じげ）官人・石井元好の五男として生まれる。
column2: He was born as the fifth son of Motoyoshi ISHII, a low rank official, in Ichijo, Kyoto.

column1: 姉は彦根藩主井伊直孝の側室・春光院である。
column2: His elder sister, Shunkoin, was a concubine of Naotaka II, the lord of Hikone Domain.

column1: 9歳の時に建仁寺・大統院に入り、九厳和尚の薫陶を受ける。
column2: When he was nine years old, he entered Daitoin of Kennin-ji Temple and was taught by a priest named Kugon.

column1: 後に近江・彦根に移り、13歳から城主の井伊直孝に仕える。
column2: Then he moved to Hikone, Omi, and at the age of thirteen he began serving Naotaka II, the lord of the castle.

column1: 幼少から山水を愛し、たびたび京都に赴いていたところ、泉涌寺・雲龍院の如周が法華経を講ずるのを聴いて感ずるところあった。
column2: From childhood he loved literature and often visited Kyoto, and when he listened to lectures on the Lotus Sutra by Nyoshu of Unryuin, Senyo-ji Temple, he was extremely impressed.

column1: 病弱なこともあって1649年（慶安2年）に職を辞し、出家して日蓮宗・妙顕寺の日豊について僧となる。
column2: Also because he had been sick, he resigned his post in 1649 and became a monk under Nippo of Myoken-ji Temple of the Nichiren Sect.

column1: 中正院の日護・本性寺の日徳と交流し日蓮宗の秘奥を究めた。
column2: He had close relationships with Nichigo of Chujoin and Nittoku of Honsho-ji Temple, and studied Nichiren sect Buddhism in depth.

column1: 明暦元年33歳で伏見深草に称心庵（後の瑞光寺）を営み、竹葉庵と号し仏道の修行に励んだ。
column2: In 1655 when he was thirty-three, he founded Shoshin an (later Zuiko-ji Temple) in Fukakusa, Fushimi, named himself Chikuyo (bamboo leaf) an, and began applying himself to study Buddhism.

column1: 翌年、79歳になる母の妙種を伴い身延山に参詣し、帰り道に江戸の井伊邸に母を託し、自身は日本橋に宿を取った。
column2: The next year he visited the temple of Mt. Minobu with his seventy-nine-year-old mother, Myoshu, and on his way back home, in Edo he brought his mother to the mansion of Ii family while he himself stayed in an inn at Nihonbashi.

column1: 甥にあたる井伊直澄はたびたびその屋敷に招待したが日政はそれを固辞し母を連れて京に帰った。
column2: He stubbornly refused the frequent invitations to the mansion from Naozumi II, his nephew, and came back to Kyoto with his mother.

column1: その年に庵のそばに仏殿などを開き、深草山瑞光寺を開山し、法華経修行の道場とし、門下の宜翁を上座としてともに修行した。
column2: In the same year, he added buildings including one where a Buddhist image was enshrined, established Shinsozan Zuiko-ji Temple as a school for studying the Lotus Sutra and practicing Buddhism, put his disciple Seno as his senior, and studied together.

column1: 修行の合間に詩歌を楽しみ、熊沢蕃山・北村季吟など多数の著名人と交友関係があった。
column2: Between the study and practices, he enjoyed poetry and mixed with many celebrities such as Banzan KUMAZAWA and Kigin KITAMURA.

column1: 寛文七年に母の妙種の喪を営み、摂津の高槻にいたり一月あまり留まるがその翌年正月に病を得て、自ら死期を悟って深草に帰る。
column2: In 1667, after he held the funeral of his mother Myoshu, he went to Takatsuki, Settsu, and stayed there for more than a month, where he became sick in January the next year, and knowing that he was about to die, came back to Fukakusa.

column1: 日燈に後事を託して寂す。
column2: He asked Nitto to take care of the school, and died.

column1: 享年46歳。
column2: He was forty-six years old.

column1: 遺体は称心庵のそばに葬られ、竹三竿を植えて墓標に代えたという。
column2: It is said that his body was buried beside the Shoshin an with three bamboos planted as his grave marker.

column1: 辞世として「鷲の山　常にすむてふ　峰の月　かりにあらはれ　かりにかくれて」という歌がある。
column2: His last poem was, 'Over the mountain of eagles the moon is supposed to dwell, appearing one time and disappearing at another time above the peak.'

column1: 日政には校訂したものや著作が多い。
column2: Nissei left many writings of his own and revisions of others' writings.

column1: 校訂者としては、『訓点天台三大部輔正記』・『大智度論』・『涅槃経会疏』・『法苑珠林』・『釈門章服義』・『袁中郎全集』・『宝物集』などの業績がある。

column2: There were many outstanding disciples called 'Gazan niju-go tetsu' (25 hoshi (a successor to an abbacy) of Gazan), and he had Taigen Soshin, Tsugen Jakurei, Mutan Sokan, Daitetsu Soryo and Jippo Ryoshu open sub temples, with the five of them rotating as the chief priest of Soji-ji Temple.

column2: In 1340, he concurrently served as the chief priest of Eiko-ji Temple, and expanded the teachings of Buddhism throughout Japan, traveling between the two temples for 20 some years until his death.

column2: There is a legend that early every morning, after finishing his morning duty at Eiko-ji Temple, he walked 52 km of the mountain road to perform his morning duty at Soji-ji Temple.

column1: 陣門流では、三宝の第一を、仏陀は久遠実成本仏釈迦牟尼世尊とし、法(仏教)は正法ととらえている妙法蓮華経（法華経）とし、僧は日蓮（陣門流の使用する日蓮の呼び方）とする。
column2: At the Jinmon school, it has been defined that the first of Sanpo (or Sanbo, 3 treasures of Buddhism: Buddha, sutras and priesthood) 久遠実成本仏釈迦牟尼世尊 being Buddha, Horenge-kyo (or Hokekyo) perceived as the correct teachings of Buddhism being sutra and Nichiren being the Priest (as referred to as Nichiren at the Jinmon school).

column1: 教義は釈迦本仏論で勝劣派である。
