column1: 奝然が請来した釈迦如来立像は、奝然が宋にわたる前に伽藍の建立を誓った愛宕山麓の地に清凉寺が建立され、奝然の没後に完成してそこに安置された。
column2: The seated statue of Shakya Nyorai, that was brought into Japan by Chonen, was enshrined in Seiryo-ji Temple, at the foot of Mt. Atago, where Chonen vowed to build a temple to enshrine Shakya, which began its construction before Chonen left for Sung and was completed after his death.

column1: 超然（ちょうねん、寛政4年12月23日(旧暦)（1793年2月3日）－慶応4年2月29日(旧暦)（1868年3月22日））は、江戸時代後期の浄土真宗の僧。
column2: Chonen (February 3, 1793 - March 22, 1868) was a Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) priest in the late Edo period.

column1: 父は近江国円照寺の僧大涛。
column2: His father was Daito, a priest of Ensho-ji Temple, in Omi Province.

column1: 号は虞淵。
column2: His pseudonym (pen name) was Guen.

column1: 諡は高尚院。
column2: His shi (posthumous name) was Kosho-in.

column1: 1808年（文化(元号)5年）本寺にあたる西本願寺で得度。
column2: In 1808, he became a priest at Nishi Hongwan-ji Temple, the head temple.

column1: 1821年（文政4年）本願寺学林の義諦と雲幢との対論を調停し、また三業惑乱後の宗論の混乱を収束させた。
column2: In 1821, he reconciled the debate between Gitai and Undo of Hongwan-ji Temple Gakurin (school) and brought an end to the confusion in the religious debate after The Sango Wakuran Controversy (The Incident that Disturbed the Three Deeds).

column1: 嘉永年間（1848年－1854年）には本願寺広如の命により、「真宗法要典拠」を著している。
column2: From 1848 to 1854, he wrote 'Shinshu Hoyo Tenko' under the order of Konyo, Hongwan-ji Temple.

column1: 幕末期には尊王論を主張し、頼三樹三郎や周防国妙円寺の月性らと交流した。
column2: He insisted on Sonnoron (imperialism) at the end of the Edo period and got on with Mikisaburo RAI, Gessho of Myoen-ji Temple in Suo Province and others.

column1: 1917年（大正6年）勧学が追贈されている。
column2: In 1917, he was promoted to Kangaku ranking after his death.

column1: 真観（しんかん、建治元年（1275年）-暦応4年/興国2年6月2日(旧暦)（1341年7月16日））は、鎌倉時代末期から南北朝時代(日本)の時宗の僧。
column2: Shinkan (1275 - July 16, 1341) was a Ji sect priest from the end of the Kamakura period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

column1: 正式には浄阿弥陀仏。
column2: His formal name was 浄阿弥陀仏.

column1: 号は真観。
column2: His go (pseudonym) was Shinkan.

column1: 出身は上総国牧野氏。
column2: He was from the Makino clan of Kazusa Province.

column1: 時宗四条派の祖。
column2: He was the priest of the Ji sect, in the Shijo school.

column1: 幼少で出家し、初めは鎌倉極楽寺の忍性から戒律を学んだ。
column2: He entered priesthood at a young age, first learning perseverance and religious precepts of the Gokuraku-ji Temple in Kamakura.

column1: ついで紀伊国由良興国寺の心地覚心から禅を学び、熊野新宮で霊告を受けて一阿と名を改めた。
column2: Then he learned Zen from Kakushin SHINCHI of the Kokoku-ji Temple at Yura, Kii Province, received the prophecy at Kumano Shingu and changed his name to 一阿.

column1: 1300年（正安2年）上野国板鼻で時宗遊行上人第2世他阿真教に師事し、相模国当麻無量光寺に住した。
column2: In 1300, he studied with the Tokimune Yugyo Shoni, the second generation Ta Shinkyo (the second Traveling Saint) at Itabana, Kozuke Province, and lived in the Muryoko-ji Temple in Toma, Sagami Province.

column1: 1309年（延慶(日本)2年）上洛して祇陀林寺に住し、1311年（応長元年）後伏見天皇の女御広義門院藤原寧子の安産を願って霊験があり、京都四条京極の地を賜り、祇陀林寺を金蓮寺(京都市)とあらためた。
column2: In 1309, he went to Kyoto and lived in Gidarin-ji Temple, and in 1311, while he prayed for the safe delivery of the baby for Kogimonin FUJIWARA no Yasuko, the high ranked lady of court for Emperor Gofushimi, for which he was awarded the land of Shijo Kyogoku in Kyoto, and then changed the name of Gidarin-ji Temple to Konren-ji Temple (Kyoto City).

column1: その後金蓮寺歴代住職は浄阿弥陀仏を襲名した。
column2: Thereafter, the successive chief priests of the Konren-ji Temple assumed the name 浄阿弥陀仏.

column1: 無関普門（むかんふもん、建暦2年（1212年）－正応4年12月12日(旧暦)（1292年1月3日））は、鎌倉時代中期の臨済宗の僧。
column2: Mukan Fumon (1212 – January 3, 1292) was a Buddhist priest of the Rinzai Sect in the mid-Kamakura Period.

column1: 諱は玄悟。
column2: The real name of Mukan Fumon was 玄悟.

column1: 房号は普門房。
column2: His priest name was 普門房.

column1: 諡号は大明国師。
column2: His posthumous name was Daimyo Kokushi.

column1: 出身は信濃国。
column2: Mukan Fumon was from Shinano Province.

column1: 13歳の時越後国正円寺で出家して剃髪。
column2: At age 13, he entered the priesthood taking the tonsure at Shoen-ji Temple in Echigo Province.

column1: 信濃国塩田の講席に列し、数年後正円寺に戻り叔父の寂円に仕えた。
column2: Mukan Fumon attended lectures in Shioda in Shinano Province and, several years later, returned to Shoen-ji Temple to work for his uncle Jakuen.

column1: 19歳のときに上野国長楽寺で栄朝から菩薩戒を受けている。
column2: At age 19, Mukan Fumon received Bosatsu-kai (Bodhisattva Precepts) from Eicho at Choraku-ji Temple in Kozuke Province.

column1: その後、関東や北越の講席を遊歴し、京都東福寺の円爾（弁円）に参禅した。
column2: Afterwards, Mukan Fumon attended various lectures in the Kanto and Hokuetsu regions in addition to practicing Zen medications with Enni (Benen) at Tofuku-ji Temple in Kyoto.

column1: 1251年（建長3年）中国の宋(王朝)にわたり、1261年（弘長元年）に帰国するまで禅宗寺院を巡歴して参禅した。
column2: In 1251, Mukan Fumon visited the Sung (Dynasty) in China and traveled around to visit various temples of the Zen sect until returning to Japan in 1261.

column1: その後1281年（弘安4年）に東福寺の住持となった。
column2: Afterwards in 1281, Mukan Fumon became the chief priest of Tofuku-ji Temple.

column1: 1288年（正応元年）亀山天皇の離宮に出没する妖怪を降伏（ごうぶく）した功により、南禅寺第1世となっている。
column2: In 1288, in recognition of his service for exorcising specters that haunted the detached palace of Emperor Kameyama, Mukan Fumon was made the first resident priest of Nanzen-ji Temple.

column1: なお、南禅寺の塔頭である天授庵は虎関師錬（こかんしれん）により無関普門の塔所（墓所）として建立されたものである。
column2: Additionally, Tenju-an Temple, the subtemple of Nansen-ji Temple, was built as the pagoda (graveyard) of Mukan Fumon by Kokan Shiren.

column1: 瑞渓周鳳（ずいけいしゅうほう、明徳2年/元中8年12月8日(旧暦)（1392年1月2日）－文明(日本)5年5月8日(旧暦)（1473年6月3日））は、室町時代中期の臨済宗の僧。
column2: Zuikei Shuho (January 2, 1392 – June 3, 1473) was a Buddhist priest of the Rinzai sect in the mid-Muromachi Period.

column1: 和泉国の出身で、俗姓は大伴氏。
column2: Zuikei Shuho was from Izumi Province with his secular surname being that of the Otomo clan.

column1: 諱は周鳳。
column2: The real name of Zuikei Shuho was Shuho.

column1: 字は瑞渓。
column2: His surname was Zuikei.

column1: 臥雲山人とも称される。
column2: He was also referred to as Gaunsanjin.

column1: 諡号は興宗明教禅師。
column2: The posthumous name of Zuikei Shuho was 興宗明教禅師.

column1: 10歳のとき応永の乱で父を失った。
column2: At age 10, Zuikei Shuho lost his father who was killed during the Oei War.

column1: 1406年（応永13年）京都相国寺の無求周伸（むきゅうしゅうしん）に師事して出家し、その法を継ぐ。
column2: In 1406, Zuikei Shuho became a pupil of Mukyushushin at Shokoku-ji Temple in Kyoto entering the priesthood.

column1: 1440年（永享12年）相国寺の住持に就任し、1446年（文安3年）相国寺鹿苑院の院主となり、僧録に任じられた。
column2: In 1440, Zuikei Shuho assumed the post of the chief priest of Sokoku-ji Temple and, subsequently in 1446, was made the Inju (the chief of the temple) of Shokoku-ji Temple Rokuon-in whereby being appointed as Soroku (the highest-ranking priest of the Gozan, the leader of the Zen sect).

column1: 6代将軍足利義教、8代将軍足利義政に重用され、文筆の才により室町幕府の外交文書の作成にあたった。
column2: He was given important posts by the sixth shogun Yoshinori ASHIKAGA and the eighth shogun Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA and, by using his talent in writing, was assigned to develop diplomatic correspondence for the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

column1: 外交史書の『善隣国宝記』を編集し、足利義満の明との朝貢形式の外交を非難している。
column2: Zuikei Shuho compiled a book on diplomatic history "Zenrin Kokuhoki," criticizing the diplomatic style practiced by Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA with Ming in which Yoshimitsu sent gifts to Ming.

column1: 『臥雲日件録』という日記も著す。
column2: He also wrote a journal entitled "Gaunnikken-roku."

column1: 蘭坡景茝（らんぱけいし、応永26年（1417年）－文亀元年2月28日(旧暦)（1501年3月17日））は、室町時代中期から戦国時代(日本)にかけての臨済宗の僧。
column2: Ranbakeishi (1417 – March 17, 1501) was a Buddhist priest of the Rinzai sect between the mid-Muromachi and Sengoku periods (Period of Warring States).

column1: 別号は雪樵。
column2: His other name was Sessho.

column1: 近江国の出身。
column2: Ranbakeishi came from Omi Province.

column1: 南禅寺に入り大模梵軌（だいもぼんき）に師事してその法を継ぎ、希世霊彦（きせいれいげん）や瑞巌龍惺（ずいがんりゅうせい）らに漢詩文を学んだ。
column2: Upon entering Nanzen-ji Temple, Ranbakeishi became a pupil of Daimobonki, carrying over his master's dharma and studying Chinese poetry under various people including Kiseireigen and Zuiganryusei.

column1: 1475年（文明(日本)7年）臨川寺の住持となり、その後は相国寺・等持院・常在光寺などの住持を歴任し、南禅寺内に仙館軒（のちに仙館院）を創建している。
column2: Subsequent to becoming the chief priest of Rinsen-ji Temple in 1475, Ranbakeishi successively held the post of chief priest of various temples such as Shokoku-ji Temple, Toji-in Temple and 常在光寺 and created 仙館軒 (later called 仙館院) on the grounds of Nanzen-ji Temple.

column1: 後土御門天皇に重用され、詩などを進講している。
column2: Ranbakeishi was given an important post by Emperor Gotsuchimikado, and gave lectures on various subjects including poetry to the emperor.

column1: 隆寛（りゅうかん、久安4年（1148年）－安貞元年12月13日(旧暦)（1228年1月21日））は、平安時代後期から鎌倉時代前期にかけての浄土宗の僧。
column2: Ryukan (1148 - January 21, 1228) was a Jodo sect priest from the late Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

column1: 父は少納言藤原資隆。
column2: His father was FUJIWARA no Suketaka, Shonagon (Minor Counselor).

column1: 字は皆空無我・道空無我。
column2: His azana (popular names) were Kaiku Muga and Doku Muga.

column1: 浄土宗長楽寺派の祖。
column2: He was the founder of the Choraku-ji school of the Jodo sect.

column1: 幼い頃に比叡山に登って延暦寺に入り、伯父の皇円に師事して天台教学を学んだ。
column2: In his childhood, Ryukan entered Enryaku-ji Temple on Mt. Hiei and learned Tendai doctrine under his uncle, Koen.

column1: 天台座主慈円とも和歌を通じて交流があった。
column2: There was an interchange between Ryukan and Jien, Tendai-zasu (head priest of the Tendai sect) through waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables).

column1: その後日本浄土宗の祖法然の門にくだり、1204年（元久元年）3月には法然から「選択本願念仏集」を授けられた。
column2: After that, he became a pupil of Honen, the founder of Japan's Pure Land sect, and was given 'Senchaku Hongan Nenbutsu Shu' by Honen in March, 1204.

column1: 嘉禄の法難では専修念仏を広めた中心人物の一人とみられて陸奥国に配流となった。
column2: Ryukan was regarded one of the major people who spread Senju Nenbutsu (the Single-Minded Recitation of the Nenbutsu) in the Karoku Persecution and was exiled to Mutsu Province.

column1: その途中で関東の武士を教化しが、相模国飯山（現在の神奈川県厚木市内）で没した。
column2: On the way, he edified Kanto warriors and passed away in Iiyama, Sagami Province (present day, Atsugi City, Kanagawa Prefecture).

column1: 了庵桂悟（りょうあんけいご、応永32年（1425年）－永正11年9月15日(旧暦)（1514年10月3日））は、室町時代中期から戦国時代(日本)にかけての臨済宗の僧。
column2: Ryoankeigo (1425 - October 3, 1514) was a Buddhist monk of Rinzai Sect in the mid-Muromachi period and Sengoku period (Period of Warring States) (Japan).

column1: 諱は仏日禅師。
column2: His imina (real personal name) was Butsunichizenji.

column1: 山城国真如寺の大疑宝信の法を継ぎ、伊勢国安養寺を経て、1478年（文明(日本)10年）東福寺の住持となった。
column2: He succeeded the teachings of Daigihosin, a monk of Shinnyo-ji Temple in Yamashiro Province, and became the chief priest of Tofuku-ji Temple in 1478 after serving at Anyo-ji Temple in Ise Province.

column1: 三条西実隆の推挙によりその名を高め、朝廷でしばしば禅を説いた。
column2: He established his reputation thanks to the recommendation of Sanetaka SANJONISHI and often preached Zen teachings at the Imperial Court.

column1: 1506年（永正3年）遣明使の正使に任じられて1511年（永正8年）明に渡り、貿易品の価格交渉や文人との交流を行った。
column2: He was appointed as the senior envoy of Kenminshi (Japanese envoys to Ming Dynasty China) in 1506 and in 1511, he went to Ming and was involved in the price negotiation of trade products while exchanging with cultured persons there.

column1: 1513年（永正10年）に帰国し、その後は南禅寺や東福寺大慈院に住した。
column2: He returned to Japan in 1513 and from then, he resided at Nanzen-ji Temple and Tofuku-ji Temple Daiji-in.

column1: 徹通義介（てっつうぎかい、承久元年2月2日(旧暦)（1219年2月18日）-延慶(日本)2年9月14日(旧暦)（1309年10月18日））は、鎌倉時代中期の曹洞宗の僧。
column2: Tettsugikai (February 18, 1219 - October 18, 1309) was a Buddhist monk of Soto Sect in the mid-Kamakura period.

column1: 越前国の出身。
column2: He hailed from Echizen Province.

column1: 初め比叡山に登って授戒したが、1241年（仁治2年）山城国深草興聖寺の道元に師事して参禅した。
column2: After receiving Buddhist precepts at Mt. Hiei, he became a disciple of Dogen, a monk of Kosho-ji Temple at Fukakusa in Yamashiro Province, and practiced Zen meditation under him.

column1: 以後道元に従い、永平寺で典座などの要職をつとめた。
column2: Since then, he followed Dogen and held important posts, including Tenzo (one of six administrative posts at a Zen temple), at Eihei-ji Temple.

column1: 道元の没後は懐奘について永平寺の規則や儀式の整備などを行った。
column2: After Dogen died, he streamlined the regulations and rituals of Eihei-ji Temple under Ejo.

column1: その後永平寺第3世に就任するが、懐奘の没後は加賀国に移り、大乗寺を真言宗寺院から禅院に改めその開山となった。
column2: He was thereafter inaugurated as the third chief priest of Eihei-ji Temple, but after the death of Ejo, he moved to Kaga Province and became the founder of Daijo-ji Temple by converting it from a Shingon Sect temple to a Zen temple.

column1: 弟子には曹洞宗発展の基礎を築いた瑩山紹瑾がいる。
column2: Keizanjokei, who laid the foundation of the development of Soto Sect, was his disciple.

column1: 義空（ぎくう、生没年不詳）は、平安時代前期唐から渡来した禅僧。
column2: Giku (date of birth and death unknown) was a Zen-sect priest from Tang China in the early Heian period.

column1: 中国杭州海昌院斉安国師に師事。
column2: He learned under 海昌院斉安国師 in Hang Zhou, China.

column1: 835年（承和2年）皇太后橘嘉智子が恵萼（えがく）を使者として唐に送って唐の禅僧を招聘した際、斉安の推挙により来日した。
column2: When Empress Dowager TACHIBANA no Kachiko invited a Zen sect priest from Tang China by sending Egaku as the messenger in 835, Giku came to Japan due to 斉安's recommendation.

column1: 初め東寺西院に住したが、その後嘉智子が創建した檀林寺に移ってその開基となった。
column2: At first Giku lived in To-ji Saiin (the western part of To-ji Temple) and then moved to Danrin-ji Temple, which was established by Kachiko, becoming the founder of the temple.

column1: 仏道を問う者は多かったというが、禅宗自体は不振で数年で唐に戻った。
column2: It is said that a lot of people visited him for Buddhism, but the Zen sect itself didn't become popular and Giku returned to Tang after a few years.

column1: 後に恵萼が再び唐に渡った際、その事績を日本国首伝禅宗記として碑に刻み、日本に送り京の羅城門脇に建てたという。
column2: It is said that when Egaku revisited Tang China, he engraved Giku's accomplishments on a monument, sent it to Japan, and built it beside Rajomon Gate in Kyoto.

column1: 喜海（きかい、治承2年（1178年）－建長2年12月20日(旧暦)（1251年1月13日））は、鎌倉時代中期の華厳宗の僧。
column2: 1178 - January 13, 1251) was a Kegon sect priest in the middle of the Kamakura period.

column1: 号は義林房。
column2: His pseudonym (pen name) was Girin-bo.

column1: 山城国栂尾高山寺に入って明恵に師事し華厳教学を学んだ。
column2: He entered Tsuganoo Kozan-ji Temple in Yamashiro Province and learned Kegon Thought under Myoe.

column1: 明恵とともに華厳教学やその注釈書「華厳経探玄記」の書写・校合に携わった。
column2: Together with Myoe, Kikai engaged in copying and collating Kegon Thought and its commentary, 'Kegon-kyo Tangen-ki.'

column1: 明恵の置文に高山寺久住の一人として高山寺の学頭と定められ、明恵の没後も高山寺十無尽院に住した。
column2: In the Okibumi (Will and Testament) of Myoe, Kikai was approved as the head student of Kozan-ji Temple as one of the Kuju disciples of Kozan-ji Temple, and lived in Kozan-ji Jumujinin Temple after Myoe's death.

column1: 明恵の行状を記した「高山寺明恵上人行状」は有名である。
column2: Kozan-ji Myoe-shonin Gyojo,' which described Myoe's conduct, was famous.

column1: 弟子には静海・弁清などがいる。
column2: His disciples included Jokai and Bensei.

column1: 木食養阿（もくじきようあ、生年不詳－宝暦13年11月21日(旧暦)（1763年12月25日））は、江戸時代中期の真言宗の僧。
column2: Mokujikiyoa (year of birth is not clear - December 25, 1763) was a Buddhist monk of Shingon Sect in the mid-Edo period.

column1: 京都の出身。
column2: He hailed from Kyoto.

column1: 初め泉涌寺雲龍院の慧雄に師事して出家したが、1711年（正徳(日本)元年）高野山に上って木食恵昌について十穀を絶つ木食行を学んだ。
column2: He initially studied under Eyu, a monk of Sennyu-ji Temple Unryu-in, and became a monk, but in 1711, he went to Mt. Koya and practiced Mokujikigyo, the ascetic practice of abstaining from eating ten kinds of grains, under Mokujikiesho.

column1: 諸国を行脚した後京都に戻って念仏活動を行い、洛北の狸谷不動院や五条坂安祥院を開創したほか、橋や道路の土木工事を行った。
column2: After travelling to various provinces, he returned to Kyoto and there he practiced nenbutsu (Buddhist invocation) activities, founded Tanukidani Fudo-in in Rakuhoku and Gojozaka Ansho-in Temple and was engaged in the civil engineering work of roads and bridges.

column1: 1741年（寛保元年）には法橋上人位に任じられ養阿を名乗った。
column2: In 1741, he was conferred Hokkyo-shonin-i (a honorable title that is given to Buddhist sculptors, painters and poets etc.) and called himself Yoa.

column1: 安慧（あんえ、延暦13年（794年）－貞観_(日本)10年4月3日(旧暦)（868年5月2日））は、平安時代前期の天台宗の僧。
column2: Ane (794 - May 2, 868) was a Buddhist monk of Tendai Sect in the early Heian period.

column1: 俗姓は大狛氏。
column2: His secular family name was Okoma clan.

column1: 河内国大県郡の出身。
column2: He hailed from Ogata County, Kawachi Province.

column1: 下野国小野寺の広智（こうち）に師事して出家、ついで比叡山に登って最澄・円仁について顕教・密教を学んだ。
column2: After studying under Kouchi, a monk of Ono-dera Temple in Shimotsuke Province, and becoming a monk, he went to Mt. Hiei and studied Exoteric Buddhism as well as Esoteric Buddhism under Saicho and Ennin.

column1: 遮那業学生（密教専攻の学僧）として得度し、規定により12年篭山修行を行った。
column2: He entered the Buddhist priesthood as Shanagyo-gakusei (a learned monk who majors in Esoteric Buddhism) and according to the regulations, he practiced Rozan-shugyo for 12 years (ascetic practices of confining oneself in a temple for 12 years).

column1: その後、844年（承和(日本)11年）出羽国の講師に任じられ、その地の法相宗徒の多くを天台宗に改宗させたという。
column2: In 844, he was appointed as a lecturer in Dewa Province and it is said that he converted many local Hosso Sect believers into Tendai Sect believers.

column1: 848年（承和13年）延暦寺定心院十禅師に任じられ、内供奉十禅師を経て、864年（貞観6年）天台座主に就任した。
column2: He was selected in 848 as one of Juzenji (ten selected excellent priests) of Enryaku-ji Temple Joshin-in and after being selected as one of Naigubu Juzenji (ten selected excellent priests for a Buddhist service conducted at the Imperial court), he was finally inaugurated as the head priest of the Tendai Sect in 864.

column1: 良尚入道親王（りょうしょうにゅうどうしんのう、元和(日本)8年12月16日(旧暦)（1623年1月16日）－元禄6年7月5日(旧暦)（1693年8月6日））は、江戸時代前期の京都曼殊院の門跡。
column2: Ryoshonyudo Shinno (January 16, 1623 - August 6, 1693) was the Monzeki (head priest of temple who was a member of the Imperial Family) of Kyoto Manju-in Temple in the early Edo period.

column1: 父は八条宮智仁親王。
column2: His father was Imperial Prince Hachijonomiya Toshihito.

column1: 母は丹後国宮津藩主京極高知の娘常照院。
column2: His mother was Joshoin, a daughter of Takatomo KYOGOKU who was the lord of Miyazu Domain in Tango Province.

column1: 幼称は二宮。
column2: His childhood name was Ninomiya.

column1: 俗名は勝行・寛恒。
column2: His secular name was Katsuyuki/Hirotsue.

column1: 曼殊院宮の付弟（ふてい）となり、1632年（寛永9年）後水尾天皇の猶子となった。
column2: He became a disciple of Manjuin no miya and also became the adopted child of the Emperor Gomizunoo in 1632.

column1: 1634年（寛永11年）8月に親王宣下を受け、9月に曼殊院で得度している。
column2: He was conferred the title of Imperial Prince by the Imperial proclamation issued in August 1634 and in September, he entered the Buddhist priesthood at Manju-in Temple.

column1: 1646年（正保3年）3月には天台座主に任じられ、1656年（明暦2年）現在の京都御所近くにあった曼殊院を洛北一乗寺村へ移転し、伽藍を整備している。
column2: After he was appointed as head priest of the Tendai Sect in March 1646, he moved Manju-in Temple, which had been located at a place near to the current Kyoto Imperial Palace, to Ichijoji village in Rakuhoku in 1656 and improved its garan (ensemble of temple buildings).

column1: 1687年（貞享4年）4月に曼殊院を退院して天松院と号した。
column2: He resigned from his post at Manju-in Temple in April 1687 and called himself Tenshoin thereafter.

column1: 絵画を狩野探幽・狩野尚信兄弟に学び、池坊華道を納めて古典に通じるなど文化人としても知られた。
column2: He was known as a person of culture since he learned paintings from the brothers Tanyu and Naonobu KANO, practiced Ikenobo-school flower arrangement and was well versed in classical literature.

column1: 日講（にっこう、寛永3年3月27日(旧暦)（1626年4月23日）-元禄11年3月10日(旧暦)（1698年4月20日））は、江戸時代前期の日蓮宗の僧。
column2: Nikko (April 23, 1626 - April 20, 1698) was a Buddhist monk of Nichiren Sect in the early Edo period.

column1: 号は安国院。
column2: His go (pen name) was Ankokuin.

column1: 京都の出身。
column2: He hailed from Kyoto.

column1: 妙覚寺(京都市)（京都府）日習を師として出家し、下総国の飯高檀林（現在千葉県匝瑳市飯高寺）、中村檀林（現在千葉県多古町日本寺）で不受不施派の思想を学んだ。
column2: He studied and entered the Buddhist priesthood under Nisshu, a monk of Myokaku-ji Temple (Kyoto City) (Kyoto Prefecture), and thereafter learned the philosophy of Fujufuse school (a school of Nichiren Sect which held philosophy insisting that nothing could be received from or given to people who believe in sutras other than Hokke-kyo Sutra) at Hanko Danrin (seminary) (Hanko-ji Temple in Sosa City, Chiba Prefecture) and Nakamura Danrin (Nichihon-ji Temple in Tako-machi, Chiba Prefecture).

column1: 幕府は不受不施派の取締りを強化していたことから、1665年（寛文5年）日蓮宗の寺院に対し、幕府からの朱印地は国主が寺院に対し、供養したものと認める手形の提出を命じた。
column2: In line with the policy to strengthen its control over the Fujufuse school, bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) ordered in 1665 temples of Nichiren Sect to submit a written oath stating to the effect that they admit shuinchi (land granted to temples and shrines by bakufu) is the offering to temples by Kokushu (lord of domain).

column1: しかしながら、当時の不受不施派の池上本門寺（東京都）日樹らはこれを拒否した。
column2: However, Nichiju of Ikegami Honmon-ji Temple (Tokyo) and other monks who belonged to Fujufuse school at the time refused to submit.

column1: 日講はこの政策に「守正護国章」を呈上して幕府を非難している。
column2: Nikko condemned this policy of bakufu by submitting 'Shusho Gokoku Sho.'

column1: 1666年（寛文6年）幕府はさらに地子・寺領だけでなく、飲み水や行路にいたるすべてが国主の供養である旨の手形の提出を命じたが、日講はこれも拒否した。
column2: Bakufu further ordered in 1666 to submit a written oath admitting that not only land tax/temple estate but also drinking water and roads were offerings by Kokushu, but Nikko refused again.

column1: この結果、日講は日向国佐土原に配流となったが、島津氏の帰依を受け、この地に布教している。
column2: In the wake of this incident, Nikko was banished to Sadowara in Hyuga Province but he was embraced by the Shimazu clan and conducted propagation there.

column1: 日講の著書「録内啓蒙」はこの時書かれたものである。
column2: Nikko wrote his book 'Rokunaikeimo' during that time.

column1: 1682年（天和2年）、岡山で起きた不受不施派内の論争は、不受不施派を導師派と不導師派に二分し、不導師派の日講の系統は不受不施日蓮講門宗となる。
column2: The internal debate in the Fujufuse school, which occurred in 1682 in Okayama, led to the split of Fujufuse school into two schools, namely the Doshi school and the Fudoshi school, and the Fudoshi school to which Nikko belonged became independent as Fujufuse Nichiren Komon Sect.

column1: 勝覚（しょうかく、天喜5年（1057年）－大治4年4月1日(旧暦)（1129年4月21日））は、平安時代後期の真言宗の僧。
column2: Shokaku (1057 - April 21, 1129) was a Buddhist monk of Shingon sect in the late Heian period.

column1: 父は源俊房。
column2: His father was MINAMOTO no Toshifusa.

column1: 立川流(密教)の祖仁寛の弟。
column2: He was a younger brother of Ninkan, the founder of Tachikawa school (Esoteric Buddhism).

column1: 醍醐寺座主定賢から灌頂を受け、また義範・範俊に師事して真言密教の奥義を伝授された。
column2: He received kanjo (ceremony to be the successor) from Joken, the chief priest of Daigo-ji Temple, and was given instruction about the esoteric points of Shingon Esoteric Buddhism by Gihan and Hanshun.

column1: 醍醐寺三宝院に住し、1085年（応徳2年）醍醐寺座主に就任し、1092年（寛治6年）に広隆寺、ついで1104年（長徳元年）には東大寺に移った。
column2: While residing at Daigo-ji Temple Sanpo-in, he was inaugurated as the chief priest of Daigo-ji Temple in 1085 and thereafter, he moved to Koryu-ji Temple in 1092 and to Todai-ji Temple in 1104.

column1: 1107年（嘉承2年）に権少僧都に任じられる。
column2: In 1107, he was conferred the title of Gon no Shosozu (a title of high-ranking priest).

column1: 度々神泉苑で祈雨法を修し、1120年（保安(元号)元年）に少僧都に任じられた。
column2: He often conducted prayer for rain at Shinsenen and was conferred the title of Shosozu (a title of high-ranking priest which is senior to Gon no Shosozu) in 1120.

column1: 以後東寺長者・同寺法務・同寺寺務を経て権僧正に任じられて東寺別当に至った。
column2: Thereafter, he successively served as the chief abbot, director of temple affairs and the director of temple operations at To-ji Temple and ultimately he was conferred the title of Goon no Sojo (a title of high-ranking priest which is senior to Shoos) and appointed to Betto (chief priest) of To-ji Temple.

column1: 弟子には三宝院流の祖定海・理性院竜の祖賢覚・金剛王院流の祖聖賢などがいる。
column2: Jokai, the founder of Sanpoin school, Genkaku, the founder of Riseiin school, and Shoken, the founder of Kongooin school, were his disciples.

column1: 尋禅（じんぜん、天慶6年（943年）－永祚(日本)2年2月17日(旧暦)（990年3月16日））は、平安時代中期の天台宗の僧。
column2: Jinzen (943 - March 16, 990) was a Buddhist monk of Tendai Sect in the mid-Heian period.

column1: 父は藤原師輔、母は醍醐天皇皇女雅子内親王。
column2: His father was FUJIWARA no Morosuke and his mother was Imperial Princess Gashi, a princess of the Emperor Daigo.

column1: 諡号は慈忍。
column2: His shigo (posthumous name) was Jinin.

column1: 974年（天延2年）天台宗で初めて尋禅が一身阿闍梨となり、981年（天元(日本)4年）には権僧正に任じられている。
column2: In 974, he became Isshin-ajari (a special class of teaching priest) for the first time among the monks of Tendai Sect and in 981, he was conferred the title of Gon no Sojo (a title of high-ranking priest).

column1: 比叡山良源は藤原師輔の外護を受けて、比叡山を再興し中興の祖とされるが、そのことは比叡山の世俗化を招いた。
column2: Although Ryogen of Mt. Hiei was known as Chuko no So (father of restoration) of Mt. Hiei since he restored it with the support of FUJIWARA no Morosuke, this also secularized Mt. Hiei.

column1: その結果師輔の10子である尋禅が、良源のあとを受けて985年（寛和元年）に天台座主となっている。
column2: As a result, Jinzen, the 10th son of Morosuke, succeeded the position of head priest of Tendai Sect from Ryogen in 985.

column1: 989年（永祚元年）に隠退して飯室に篭った。
column2: In 989, he resigned and confined himself at Iimuro.

column1: 没後の1007年（寛弘4年）慈忍の諡号が贈られている。
column2: After his death, he was given in 1007 the posthumous name of Jinin.

column1: 明尊（みょうそん、天禄2年（971年）－康平6年6月26日(旧暦)（1063年7月24日））は、平安時代後期の天台宗の僧。
column2: Myoson (971 - July 24, 1063) was a Buddhist monk of Tendai Sect in the late Heian period.

column1: 祖父は小野道風。
column2: His grandfather was ONO no Tofu.

column1: 幼いときに園城寺（三井寺）に入り、余慶から顕教・密教の2教を学び、慶祚からその奥義を伝授された。
column2: He entered into Onjo-ji Temple (Mii-dera Temple) in his childhood, learned Exoteric Buddhism as well as Esoteric Buddhism from Yokei and was instructed in the esoteric points of these two Buddhism's by Keiso.

column1: 円満院に住して園城寺法務を兼ね僧正まで至っている。
column2: While residing at Enman-ji Temple, he also served as Homu (director of temple affairs) of Onjo-ji Temple and was ultimately conferred the title of Sojo (the highest title of priest).

column1: 1038年（長暦2年）天台座主に任じられると、円仁の門徒がそれに激しく反対し、翌1039年（長暦3年）関白藤原頼通に強訴した。
column2: When he was appointed as the head priest of Tendai Sect in 1038, believers of Ennin were furiously offended and petitioned directly to kanpaku (a chief advisor to the Emperor) FUJIWARA no Yorimichi in the following year, 1039.

column1: そのため、座主を辞さるを得ず円仁派の教円が座主に就任した。
column2: In the face of such situation, he was forced to resign from the head priest of Tendai Sect and Kyoen, who belonged to Ennin's faction, was inaugurated as the head priest.

column1: その直後園城寺は延暦寺とは別に戒壇を設けることを奏上したが、山門派の反対にあい実現しなかった。
column2: Soon after the above incident, Onjo-ji Temple reported to the Emperor its intention to establish kaidan (Buddhist ordination platform) independently from that of Enryaku-ji Temple, but this was not realized due to the objection of the Sanmon school (supporters of Enryaku-ji Temple).

column1: 1045年（寛徳2年）園城寺長吏、1048年（永承3年）天台座主に就任したが、山門派・寺門派の対立により3日で座主職を辞職せざるを得なくなた。
column2: He was appointed to the chief priest of Onjo-ji Temple in 1045 and to the head priest of Tendai Sect in 1048, but he was forced to resign as the head priest of Tendai Sect only three days after his inauguration because of the confrontation between the Sanmon school and the Jimon school (supporters of Onjo-ji Temple).

column1: 1053年（天喜元年）牛車を許され、翌1054年（天喜2年）平等院検校に任じられている。
column2: He was allowed to use gissha (ox-drawn carriage) in 1053 and was appointed to the administrative director of Byodo-in Temple in the following year, 1054.

column1: 明尊に帰依していた頼通は、1060年（康平3年）明尊の90歳になったのを祝賀している。
column2: In 1060, Yorimichi, who embraced Myoson, celebrated Myoson's 90th birthday.

column1: 余慶（よけい、延喜19年（919年）－正暦2年2月18日(旧暦)（991年4月5日））は、平安時代中期の天台宗の僧。
column2: Yokei (919 - April 5, 991) was a Buddhist monk of Tendai Sect in the mid-Heian period.

column1: 俗姓は宇佐氏。
column2: His secular surname was Usa clan.

column1: 筑前国早良郡の出身とされるが、一説によれば日向国の出身ともいう。
column2: Though he is believed to have hailed from Sawara County in Chikuzen Province, some say that he hailed from Hyuga Province.

column1: 諡号は智弁。
column2: His posthumous title was Chiben.

column1: 観音院僧正とも言われる。
column2: He was also called Kannonin Sojo.

column1: 比叡山の明仙から天台教学を学び、行誉から灌頂を受けた。
column2: He studied Tendai doctrine under Myosen, a monk of Mt. Hiei, and received kanjo (ceremony to be the successor) from Gyoyo.

column1: 979年（天元(日本)2年）に園城寺長吏となり、981年（天元4年）には法性寺座主となっているが、円仁の流れを組む山門派の反対により辞任している。
column2: Although he was appointed to the chief priest of Onjo-ji Temple in 979 followed by the chief priest of Hossho-ji Temple in 981, he resigned from his post due to the objections of the Sanmon school, which was descended from Ennin.

column1: 989年（永祚(日本)元年）延暦寺座主に就任しているが、これも山門派の反対にあい3ヶ月で辞任している。
column2: He was inaugurated as the chief priest of Enryaku-ji Temple in 989, but due to the objections of the Sanmon school, he again resigned three months after his inauguration.

column1: しかし、同じ年には権僧正に任じられている。
column2: He, however, was conferred the title of Gon no Sojo (a title of high-ranking priest) in the same year.

column1: 当時の宣命（天皇の命令書）の文中には山門派の門徒のことを獅子身中の虫と断じている。
column2: In Senmyo (written Imperial edict) issued at that time, believers of Sanmon school were likened to parasites in a lion.

column1: 円珍の門流である寺門流は余慶によって発展し、その後山門派・寺門派の対立が激しくなるきっかけとなった。
column2: Although the Jimon school, which was descended from Enchin, increased its influence thanks to Yokei, this became the beginning of the subsequent severe confrontation between the Sanmon school and the Jimon school.

column1: 尊純法親王（そんじゅんほっしんのう、天正19年10月16日(旧暦)（1591年12月1日）－承応2年5月26日(旧暦)（1653年6月21日））は、江戸時代前期の天台宗の僧。
column2: Sonjun Hosshinno (December 1, 1591 - June 21, 1653) was a Buddhist monk of Tendai Sect in the early Edo period.

column1: 父は応胤法親王。
column2: His father was Oin Hosshinno.

column1: 母は福正院。
column2: His mother was Fukushoin.

column1: 1598年（慶長3年）天台宗青蓮院第48世の門跡に入る。
column2: In 1598, he entered Shoren-in Temple of Tendai Sect as the 48th monzeki (a chief priest who is a member of the Imperial Family).

column1: 1604年（慶長9年）権少僧都・権大僧都を歴任し、1607年（慶長12年）良恕法親王から灌頂を受けた。
column2: He was successively conferred the title of Gon no Shosozu (a title of high-ranking priest) and Gon no Daisozu (a title of high-ranking priest which is senior to Gon no Shosozu) in 1604 and received kanjo (ceremony to be the successor) from Ryojo Hosshinno in 1607.

column1: 1615年（元和(日本)元年）大僧正に任じらる。
column2: In 1615, he was conferred the title of Daisojo (the highest rank of Buddhist monks).

column1: 1640年（寛永17年）に親王宣下を受け、尊純と号した。
column2: In 1640, he became Imperial Prince by Imperial proclamation and called himself Sonjun.

column1: 1644年（正保元年）天台座主173世となり、日光山法務を兼帯、日光東照宮の営繕をつとめた。
column2: In 1644, he was inaugurated as the 173rd head priest of Tendai Sect cum Homu (director of temple affairs) of Mt. Nikko and repaired Nikko Toshogu Shrine.

column1: 1647年（正保3年）には二品に叙せられ、1653年（承応2年）天台座主177世に就任している。
column2: In 1647, he was conferred the title of Nihon (the second court rank for Imperial Princes) and was inaugurated as the 177th head priest of Tendai Sect.

column1: 書に秀でていた。
column2: He excelled in calligraphy.

column1: 行玄（ぎょうげん、承徳元年（1097年）－久寿2年11月5日(旧暦)（1155年12月1日））は、平安時代後期の天台宗の僧。
column2: Gyogen (1097 - December 1, 1155) was a Buddhist monk of Tendai Sect in the late Heian period.

column1: 父は藤原師実。
column2: His father was FUJIWARA no Morozane.

column1: 母は源師房の娘或いは藤原隆家の孫藤原忠俊の娘で、同母弟に尋範がいる。
column2: His mother was a daughter of Minamoto no Morofusa or a daughter of FUJIWARA no Tadatoshi, a grandchild of FUJIWARA no Takaie, and Jinpan was his half younger brother with the same mother.

column1: 比叡山に上って出家し、1116年（永久(元号)4年）20歳の時良祐から灌頂を受けた。
column2: He became a monk at Mt. Hiei and received kanjo (ceremony to be the successor) from Ryosuke in 1116 when he was 20 years old.

column1: 1135年（保延元年）中宮の病気平癒の加持を修し、その賞として法務に任じられている。
column2: In 1135, he conducted incantation for curing chugu's (the second empress's) disease and was appointed to Homu (director of temple affairs) as a reward.

column1: 1138年（保延4年）僧正となり、1142年（康治元年）鳥羽天皇・藤原忠実に授戒を行う。
column2: He was conferred the title of Sojo (the second highest title of monks) in 1138 and gave Buddhist precepts to the Emperor Toba and FUJIWARA no Tadazane in 1142.

column1: 1145年（久安元年）には大僧正にいたる。
column2: He was conferred the title of Daisojo (the highest title of Buddhist monks) in 1145.

column1: 1150年（久安6年）最勝寺経供養の日を祈祷により晴天にしたことにより、住房を皇后の祈願寺とし、青蓮院と称された。
column2: In 1150, after he successfully made the weather fine by his prayers on the day of Keisho-ji Temple's Buddhist service, he converted his living house into a temple where the empresses prayed and named it Shoren-in Temple.

column1: 1153年（仁平3年）には延暦寺・法勝寺・景勝寺などの職を辞し、2年後青蓮院で没した。
column2: He resigned from his posts at Enryaku-ji Temple, Hossho-ji Temple and Keisho-ji Temple etc. in 1153 and died two years later at Shoren-in Temple.

column1: 覚快法親王（かくかいほっしんのう、長承3年（1134年）－養和元年11月16日(旧暦)（1181年12月23日））は、平安時代後期の天台宗の僧。
column2: Cloistered Imperial Prince Kakukai (1134 - December 23, 1181) was a Buddhist monk of Tendai Sect in the late Heian period.

column1: 父は鳥羽天皇。
column2: His father was the Emperor Toba.

column1: 13歳の時比叡山に上り、行玄大僧正に師事して出家、顕教・密教を兼学した。
column2: He entered Mt. Hiei when he was 13 years old, and became a monk and studied Exoteric Buddhism as well as Esoteric Buddhism under Gyogen Daisojo (the highest title of Buddhist monk).

column1: 1150年（久安6年）に権律師となり、翌1151年（久安7年）行玄から伝法灌頂をうけ、法印に任じられた。
column2: He was conferred the title of Gon-Risshi (a title of Buddhist monk) in 1150 and in the following year, 1151, he received denpo-kanjo (the consecration for the transmission of the Dharma) from Gyogen and was conferred the rank of Hoin (the highest court rank given to a Buddhist monk).

column1: 1160年（永暦元年）宮中において日蝕の祈祷を行い効験があったという。

column2: Though its origin is not clear, it is contemplated that Oeshiki was held as early as in the Edo period because it appears in "Meisho Edo Hyakkei" (a hundred scenery spots in Edo) painted by Hiroshige UTAMARO, an Ukiyoe artist.

column1: 日蓮の命日の前夜（10月12日）は、お逮夜（おたいや）と呼ばれ、各地から集まった信徒団体の集まり（講中）が、行列し万灯や提灯を掲げ、纏を振り、団扇太鼓や鉦を叩き、題目を唱えながら境内を練り歩くのである。
column2: On the eve of Nichiren's anniversary (October 12) called Otaiya, groups of believers (kochu) gathered from around the nation parade inside the precincts hoisting mando candles (candles for Buddhist service) and chochin (a lantern), waving matoi (firemen's flag), beating uchiwa-daiko (a round fan drum) and shoko drums and chanting daimoku (Nichiren chant).

column1: 古来は、提灯に蝋燭を灯し、団扇太鼓を叩きながら、参詣する簡素なものであった。

column1: 纏を振るようになったのは、明治時代の町火消の人達が、講中の人達と共に参詣に訪れた事による。

column1: 近年は、万灯の明かりとして、蝋燭の替わりに、発電機を持ち込み、電球や蛍光灯や発光ダイオードなどを取り付け、発光させている。
column2: In recent years, light bulbs, fluorescent lamps and/or light -emitting diodes that are connected to a generator are used for mando in lieu of candles.
